PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. The present Australian national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag falsely proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.
5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australia's loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.
6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52% of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.
7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.
8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australia's bicentennial celebrations in 1988.

The document read as follows-

This Bill contains amendments to the Migration Act 1958 to implement decisions taken in the Budget context to recover some of the costs associated with the provision of various services under the portfolio for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The 1987/88 Budget expands the level and quality of services provided to the community and to the clients of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In order to help fund these improved services some existing fees for Departmental services are to be increased, and this legislation introduces some new fees. This reflects the Government's concern that some of the costs of the services of benefit to clients should be borne by the user, and not the community as a whole. The increased revenue proposed also reflects the demand by clients that the Government provide faster and more efficient services. Such improvements are not always possible without resources being increased-resources which have to be funded.

As announced on Budget night, there will be a fee, which will be set initially at $240, for reconsideration of certain decisions taken under the Migration Act. This is the same amount as the fee for lodgment of appeals with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In order to protect public revenue, the clause of the Bill that relates to the Scheme-Clause 9 (a)-will, on enactment of the Bill be taken to have come into operation on 16 September 1987.
The details of the scheme will be prescribed by regulations, which will specify
The types of decisions which will be able to be reconsidered under this procedure;
Who will have standing to apply for reconsideration;
The time limit in which such a request will have to be made; and
The limited circumstances in which the fee will be refundable,

The Budget also provides for an augmentation of the resources devoted to reconsideration of decisions under the Act. The membership of the Immigration Review Panel has been increased from 32 to 157 and the Panels now meet in all mainland state capitals. The resources of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs allocated to the Review Task have been more than doubled. These steps have been taken to provide improved service and overcome the present backlog of cases.

As honourable senators know, the Immigration Review Panel was established in 1982. It is independent of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and recommends to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs whether decisions which have been appealed should be maintained or changed.

The Review system is essentially directed to providing an avenue for Australian Citizens and permanent residents affected by a refusal decision made overseas in respect of an application by a close relative or a sponsored employee, to seek the reconsideration of that decision. In some cases, the actual person who is the subject of the refusal decision-especially where that decision is made in Australia-will have a right to seek a review under these arrangements, provided that he or she was legally in Australia at the time the refused application for further temporary stay, or resident status, was lodged.

Simultaneously with the introduction of the fee, the range of reviewable decisions has been significantly widened. Among the decisions that will be prescribed as reviewable, following a request by an eligible appellant, will be:
Refused migrant entry applications, with the exception of people applying to settle in Australia under the refugee or special humanitarian programs;
Refused applications for permission to come for a temporary stay in Australia, apart from those in relation to persons coming to study;
Unsuccessful applications for the grant of resident status; and
Refused applications for extension of stay by persons in Australia on a temporary basis.
Decisions not prescribed will not be reviewable under the legislation, but will be subject to existing arrangements.

The fee that has now been introduced is refundable to appellants where the decision-maker on appeal is of the view that, on the basis of the information available to the earlier decision-maker, a favourable decision should have been made by the earlier decision-maker.

To explain these new arrangements, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs recently wrote to all members and senators. Representations concerning these prescribed migration decisions-if they are to be effective-will need to relate to a formal request for reconsideration. That is, no effective action on a request for reconsideration will be taken unless statutory requirements have been fulfilled, including the payment of the notified fee.

Where a valid request for reconsideration has been made, representations from honourable senators will be able to be considered by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and by the Immigration Review Panel.

As I have mentioned, the introduction of the fee is in the context of the new arrangements to provide a much improved and speedier service for reconsideration of decisions. The estimated cost of providing the review mechanism in 1987-88 is $5.9 million dollars. The estimated revenue from the fee is $1.44 million dollars in 1987-88 and $1.92 million dollars in a full year.

These changes are not meant to affect the recommendations about the review process made in 1985 by the Administrative Review Council. Those recommendations will be considered afresh following the report of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies.

Clause 7 of the Bill establishes the mechanism whereby a new immigration clearance fee-for-service can be collected and paid to the Commonwealth. At present, the full cost of undertaking immigration clearance services at ports of entry is borne by the Australian taxpayer. These costs are increasing dramatically each year, because the number of persons travelling to Australia is increasing, and because of improved clearance services. In order to recoup part of these costs, it was announced in the Budget package that passengers over 12 years of age arriving on international flights and who require immigration clearance on arrival will, from 1 January 1988, be required to pay a $5 immigration clearance fee. The fee is to be collected by international airline operators who bring the passengers to Australia. In turn, the operators will pay the fees collectable by them to the Commonwealth. The amount of the fee payable by airlines will be a debt due to the Commonwealth.
Revenue generated from the fee is estimated to total about $17 million dollars in a full year. It will be used to offset
The cost of immigration inspection of passengers at airports;
The costs relating to passengers who are refused entry;
The cost of facilities to detect fraudulent immigration documentation;
The cost of issue of visas;
The salaries and other costs of airport staff; and
General administrative overheads.
Consultation with the airline operators is taking place to ensure that the legislation and mechanisms to impose the charge will impose as small an administrative burden as necessary on the airlines.

The Bill also seeks to introduce a system of ``on-the-spot penalties'' for airline and shipping companies bringing foreign nationals to Australia without proper immigration documentation. At present, carrier companies commit an offence under the Act and, if found guilty by the courts, are liable to a maximum penalty of $2000, for each foreign national they bring into Australia without proper immigration documentation. Clause 6 (b) provides that the maximum penalty will be increased to $3000. The level of the maximum penalty has stood at $2000 since the offence provision was established in 1979. Clause 9 (c) of the Bill will provide power to establish a mechanism whereby, as an alternative to proceeding in courts, it will be open to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to serve a notice on the carrier stating that it is in breach of the Act and requiring it to pay a prescribed amount as a penalty. The system, which is to operate from 1 January 1988, will provide that the maximum penalty will not exceed $1500-which will be half the maximum penalty which can be imposed by the courts. As publicly announced on Budget night, it is intended that initially the penalty will be $1000. The option will, however, still be open to the Department to institute proceedings before the Courts under Section 11c of the Act. Clauses 6 and 8 make amendments to section 11c and section 57 to facilitate the production of evidence in court in the event of prosecution under section 11c.

The present system of instituting prosecutions is both time consuming and costly, even though the factual issues are relatively straightforward and simple. The number of prosecutions able to be initiated by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is very small, which is of concern given that the number of people arriving without documentation is increasing. Overseas experience indicates that a system of ``on-the-spot'' fines acts as a powerful incentive for international carriers to check more adequately their passengers' documentation prior to boarding and helps to reduce the number of inadequately documented passengers arriving at borders. It is not, of course, proposed to impose the penalties where a carrier can show that it had taken all reasonable steps to ensure that passengers had valid documentation when they boarded the aircraft or ship.

A final matter dealt with in the Bill is that amendments are to be made to the provisions in the Act dealing with requests for entry permits and visas. In order for a valid request to be made, it will be necessary for any prescribed fee to be paid, and the request to be made in writing in accordance with the relevant form approved by the Minister. This was also announced on Budget night and will, on enactment of the Bill, be taken to have come into operation from 16 September 1987. The amendments-Clauses 3, 4 and 5-will clear up an anomaly identified in a recent court case, which cast doubts on the requirement that the prescribed fee actually was payable.

The need to lodge applications in accordance with the relevant form will help overcome problems which officers of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs have experienced in identifying whether in fact a person is making an application. Of course, in the vast majority of cases, applicants have always paid the relevant fee and lodged their application on an official form. This amendment is merely designed to help underpin that practice. Similar arrangements will be put into place, by way of Regulations, in relation to requests for reconsideration of decisions.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. This contains details of the amendments I have outlined.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of legislation before the Senate at the moment deals with a number of proposed changes to provisions in the taxation laws and laws relating to the Medicare levy. The package consists of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987 and, in addition, a less controversial piece of legislation, namely, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) contains measures that are designed primarily to prevent abuses of the new dividend imputation system introduced as part of the Government's tax reform package. That package has been an ongoing package since this Government took office and in many areas it has received a considerable amount of support from the Australian Democrats. There were certainly a significant number of inequities in the tax legislation when the Hawke Government took over. The introduction of, for example, capital gains tax legislation and fringe benefits tax legislation received our full support. Indeed, I have been interested to note in recent editions of magazines such as Personal Investment Monthly that industry has accepted quite well now things such as the fringe benefits tax because in many instances it has meant more certainty in salary packages for senior employees.

Of course, we also supported the end of negative gearing when the Government introduced that, accepting the argument that was put by the Government at the time that it was unfair to have a tax concession of that sort which essentially assisted the wealthy in the community and provided no direct benefits to the needy. It was with some concern, therefore, that we noted in the recent Budget that the Government moved to reintroduce negative gearing for property developers on the ground that there was a shortage of rental property on the market for low income people. It is our argument that, had the Government used the several hundred million dollars annual savings that it got from the abolition of negative gearing to provide direct assistance to those in need at the low income end of the housing market, it would have achieved a far better result than has the reintroduction of the negative gearing capacity for people involved in property speculation, which provides tax assistance to those whose incomes in the main are well over $50,000 a year and provides very little opportunity for access to low cost rental housing for those people who are currently living in poverty.

One of the other measures that the Government introduced, which I think had the support of everybody in this place, was a dividend imputation system to allow shareholders to receive dividends tax free where the company paying the dividends has already paid company tax. That was well overdue and, as I have said, received considerable support in this place. Unfortunately, what that did in turn was to provide an opening for a potential tax abuse. It provided an opening for new avenues of tax avoidance for dividend strippers who seemed to think they were in a position to get the double benefit of both a tax deduction for the cost of shares purchased in a dividend strip and a rebate on the dividends distributed on those shares.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) seeks to prevent such abuses by denying the tax benefit of dividend imputation where the dividends are paid as part of a dividend stripping enterprise or operation. We certainly support the Government's intention to put a stop to that sort of loophole that it could have opened up through the introduction of dividend imputation. I add in passing that the legislation also includes changes to the capital gains tax area, superannuation deductions and gift provisions of the income tax law. The main problem, as far as the Opposition parties are concerned, appears to be the starting date that is stipulated in clause 8 of the new provision relating to stripping. I do not think anybody in this place supports real retrospective tax legislation; that is, I think very few people would feel that there is a need to introduce legislation that would make retrospectively illegal something that was legal, if somewhat questionably moral, at the time it was undertaken. Several governments in the past have tried to introduce retrospectivity in tax legislation, with varying degrees of success.

In general, I think we all acknowledge that what governments should do when they run across an area of tax abuse is move immediately to indicate that they are aware of that area of abuse and announce that they intend to close it off. Of course, the proper thing for them to do then is to announce that they will be closing off that area of abuse as of the day that they make the statement about their awareness of it, even if sometimes, because the issue is complex, it takes a little while to get the legislation drafted and before the Parliament. To make people aware of the fact that a government is going to close off a loophole, and then allow people to take advantage of that loophole during the time that the Government is preparing the legislation is outright idiocy. I do not believe that a general warning, or even a specific warning, by a government with regard to its intention to close off a loophole or loopholes is an element of retrospective legislation. It is appropriate in the area of tax avoidance that governments announce immediately what their plans are with regard to closing those off.

I think it is important that we realise that the ingenuity of tax lawyers and accountants is such that it is often clearly necessary for a government to offset potential losses to revenue by signalling or foreshadowing amendments to tax laws. The announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 4 June of this year, with regard to abuses of the new imputation system of company tax, fits into this category. Indeed, the Press release specifically pointed out that the Government was doing this. In that Press release the Treasurer said:

In deciding to release the draft Bill, the Government was conscious of the legitimate needs of business to be able to plan for and order their affairs without the uncertainty of not having seen safeguarding provisions which would, of necessity, have to operate from 1 July or earlier. The decision to release the draft has accordingly been taken even though some technical provisions are not fully settled.

For example, the draft Bill would deny the intercorporate dividend rebate on dividends paid out of profits on the revaluation of assets which are effectively disposed of in certain avoidance arrangements. These provisions will be extended to also apply in situations where entities are interposed between a company that revalues its `taxable' assets and the company shareholder which disposes of shares in that company.

I cannot, therefore, understand the Opposition's attitude in this regard. Had the Bill attempted to make the relevant or operative clause, that is clause 8, operate from 10 December of last year, the date of the imputation legislation announcement itself-that is, prior to the announcement that the loophole was to be closed off-there could have been an acceptable argument that a retrospective element applied. I do not agree with the Opposition that there is any element of retrospectivity in having the date of 4 June operate as distinct from 23 September, which is the Opposition's preferred date because that was the date that the Bill was introduced into the Parliament. The Press release issued at the same time as the draft Bill, and presumably to the same people as received the draft Bill, gave clear guidelines regarding the Treasurer's intention to cut off further avoidance via the imputation provisions.

I think it would be appalling if any government were discouraged or dissuaded from releasing draft legislation for comment if it felt that, after consultation, the Parliament would only agree to the contents of the Bill as specified in the Press release rather than a new and improved model. A draft Bill, I suggest, is just that, and governments of all persuasions issue draft Bills. They issue them for comment, they accept those comments and they then make whatever adjustments are necessary. When a Press release indicating that an additional loophole is to be closed off is issued at the same time as a draft Bill, I think that it would be a very stupid tax lawyer or accountant indeed-in fact, an incompetent one-who would continue to advise clients to rearrange their affairs in a way that was likely to leave them open to a charge of tax avoidance.

The Opposition amendments, as I say, are therefore designed to change from 4 June to 23 September the date from which the legislation takes effect. We will not, as I have already indicated, support that proposition because I believe in this case, in respect of a specific instance of tax avoidance, it is appropriate for that 4 June Press release to be taken into account, since it specifically foreshadowed the changes that would be taking place to the draft Bill at the same time as that draft was released. As I said, I would hate to do anything that would discourage a government from taking the perfectly proper action of consulting the industry concerned-the people likely to be affected-through the use and release of a draft Bill. Tax evasion ought not to be tolerated and I think the method that the Government has used to go about this matter in this case is reasonable.

On the general issue of tax avoidance and inequitable taxation systems, I mention that there has been comment recently about the need for a wealth inquiry, to be followed, some would suggest, by a wealth tax. I would like to make it perfectly clear that there is no way that we would support a wealth tax either following or introduced instead of or before some kind of wealth inquiry. But I do think, notwithstanding any talk to the contrary by other people in the last week or so, that we still need in this country to have some sort of inquiry into wealth-not into who owns it and what ought to be done to take it away from them, but into how some people are able to take advantage of what are basically inequitable tax law while others cannot. At that stage we ought to look at further problems in tax legislation, of which I suggest negative gearing is one, that distort the system so that some people are able to avoid or evade their taxation responsibilities while others are not.

There is a problem, too, that has been raised with my office with regard to clause 42 in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). I point out that that clause clarifies section 14zka of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 and is intended to guard against a potential total loss of revenue of the order of some $250m annually due to problems that the Commissioner of Taxation is having with regard to collecting penalties from people who have avoided paying tax. That is largely due to problems with the statute of limitations.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has made no comment at all on this clause although it has made passing reference to clauses 38 and 43 with regard to the retrospective element that legislation by Press release introduces. I will be saying more about this matter in the committee stage. The changes that the Government proposes in clause 42 are probably reasonable ones for this Parliament to accept.

The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, which is the second of the Bills we are debating cognately today, amends the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to declare and impose the basic rate of Medicare levy for 1987-88 and all subsequent income years. It does something similar to what the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) does in changing the status of legislation and in doing so removing from the Parliament its capacity to debate some fairly important issues with regard to health care and the taxation system. Both in this Bill and the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) imposing income tax rates for 1987-88, the Government is attempting to change legislation which must currently be introduced into the Parliament on an annual basis into standing legislation which would have to be introduced into the Parliament only when the rate scales are changed.

In another place the Opposition parties made quite appropriate comment about the need for parliamentarians, in doing their duty as representatives of the people, to fully debate issues of the day. Not to have significant legislation introduced as it ought to be introduced denies parliamentarians that possibility. For example, not to allow an annual debate on the Medicare levy and tax rates is to increase the power of the Executive at the expense of the Parliament. I believe that it is our responsibility to conduct a thorough debate to make the community aware of the policies of the Executive. There is something faintly hypocritical about some Opposition members, who have taken the stance they have with regard to this matter, claiming that it is essential that members of parliament have the opportunity to bring these issues before the attention of the people, because in recent years they have very rarely done anything more than talk about the problems. In attempting to confuse the electorate generally about the difference between money Bills and supply Bills and Budget Bills generally, they have quite frequently bleated about the impact of certain pieces of legislation, including Medicare levy Bills, on the community but they have not done anything at all to mitigate that problem. Even last year, when the hike in the Medicare levy specifically broke one of the Government's election commitments that the levy would remain at one per cent, the Opposition was not prepared to do anything except carry on about it when it has constitutionally and quite properly the capacity to act to prevent the Government from taking that course of action.

The levy, even at its increased level, does not raise anything like the full amount of money spent by the Government on health care although, contrary to what the Opposition and some sections of the media would have us think, there has not been a huge blow-out in health spending in Australia. However, I would argue that what health expenditure there is is often inappropriately directed. Health care expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic product runs at something like 7 per cent in Australia and that figure is currently lower than that of many Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. We certainly do not spend nearly as much money as we should be spending on preventive health services. Indeed, governments generally do not like to spend money on prevention in any area at all because it has a hidden value and, if anything comes out of it, they cannot point to specific achievements in the same way as they can, I imagine, when it is after the event expenditure.

The number of services provided per capita annually has remained largely constant since before the introduction of Medicare, and the expenditure predicted by the Government each year in Budget estimates has remained pretty close to those assessments. One value of Medicare is that it has made available to several million people-some 16 per cent of the population-health insurance which otherwise would have been out of their reach through the private sector because they simply could not afford it. The major health costs which have increased dramatically over recent years have been those in relation to diagnostic services. That is due, at least in part, to the fact that the American disease of litigation appears to be creeping in here, in combination with increased patient demand, technological advances and the popular misconception that health resources are not finite and people are getting in for their share. To its credit, I believe that the Government has taken some small steps to reduce the misplaced financial incentives in the existing system which have encouraged the trend of charging pathology fees, for example, which were out of all proportion to the work involved in particular services.

Given the fact that doctors are concerned about potential litigation and the increase in personal liability insurance costs, I can understand that they would want to try to cover all aspects through pathology services, but it has got out of hand and I think that in the main the Government has taken suitable and appropriate action to limit this. I understand that the Opposition will be moving amendments similar to those moved in another place with regard to removing the change of status to standing legislation of both the Medicare levy legislation and the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2). We will support those amendments. It is important that these Bills are introduced into the Parliament annually, giving members of parliament an opportunity to discuss matters of interest to them and to their constituents. The introduction of a Bill such as the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 gives members of parliament the opportunity to debate fully government policies in the tax and economic areas in particular.

At a time such as this, with the so-called stock market meltdown of the past week, it would have been quite inappropriate had the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) not been introduced because it had been reduced to the status of standing legislation. I point out that the problems experienced by the stock market here and elsewhere have been, at least in part, the result of taxation policies that have encouraged speculation and discouraged productive investment to produce goods and services which Australia can export, thereby reducing our reliance on imports. We have heard much comment in this place recently about the need for Australian investors to put money into plant and equipment so that we can develop a manufacturing sector and get away from our dependence on commodities, which, according to this morning's media at least, has been responsible for the lack of confidence in the Australian dollar and caused its drop against the American dollar when the American dollar was also dropping against other currencies.

I agree that we need to move away from our historical dependency on commodities and move into areas where we improve our export markets and where we can replace our dependency on imports. Nevertheless, recent governments-not just the current Labor Government-have encouraged speculative short term investment rather than long term investment in more productive areas. As I said earlier, the capacity for some people to continue negative gearing is a very serious area that needs to be attended to by this Government. People who were able to use negative gearing to borrow heavily to invest on Australian stock exchanges have not only had their fingers burnt but also caused many other people to lose money. That sort of gambling mentality, encouraged through the existence of negative gearing in that area alone, has a lot to answer for.

There is no doubt that our tax regime has encouraged debt financing. There has been a distinct move away from equity to debt financing in recent years, allowing negative gearing on funds borrowed to take over other companies, even when those funds are borrowed from overseas. This has had a significant impact on the Australian economy across the board, if only because it has helped to increase our foreign indebtedness, some 60 per cent of which is owed by the private sector. It has also reduced the contribution that companies make to total revenue, because the tax deductibility of the interest on the borrowing has been used to reduce, or in some cases to negate entirely, company profits and hence company tax liabilities. So the average worker in this country is paying 24c to 30c in tax when major companies, through the use of negative gearing and other tax concessions, have been able to get their actual liability down to the range of 10c, 11c and 12c in the dollar. That is made worse when one considers that it is often the principals in those companies who argue that company tax and tax generally in this country are too high and who threaten to take their bat and ball to some other country, taking their companies essentially off-shore and denying Australia the productive capacity and employment opportunities that they currently offer.

I suggest to those gentlemen that they look at the tax systems in a number of other countries, particularly our major trading partners, and look at some listings in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. If they do they will find that Turkey is the only place they can go which will give them any real sort of tax advantage, and that in itself will provide a number of other problems. A lot of the failure of confidence in the Australian economy has been a result of some of the less than helpful comments which have been made by some people who are already benefiting from the inequitable taxation system in Australia that allows wealthy companies and wealthy individuals to benefit in a way that ordinary families and individuals cannot.

The system has contributed to the speculation in shares which drove the share market to crazy heights before the collapse that occurred last week. For example, people have stopped buying shares according to yield and, instead, have been buying according to whether or not they have been able to make quick and short term profits by buying and selling. If the Government abolished negative gearing on company borrowings and taxed the superannuation funds and other life funds which have invested overseas rather than in Australia, it would have the funds to encourage productive investment in labour intensive export and import competing industries. If the Government had done this earlier, Australia might have avoided the speculative domestic and foreign investments which promoted a share market boom. We might then have missed out on the disastrous effects of the share market bust, which may yet reduce the savings and take away the jobs of many Australians.

Insofar as foreign investment came into Australia to profit from this speculative madness, it has now begun to leave Australia, not helped by the fact that the Hong Kong exchange was closed down, thus leaving many investors who had also invested there with only the Australian end of the market to sell out of. This has driven down our dollar and added to the serious liquidity problems of our financial institutions. I indicate now that the Democrats will support the Opposition's amendment to ensure that this legislation does not change status-that is, that it remains annual legislation, thus giving the Parliament the opportunity to discuss these issues of importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it three Bills which deal with a wide area of taxation. The Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 formally sets the tax rates for 1987-88 and all subsequent financial years according to the levels announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the September 1985 taxation package. The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987 sets a basic rate for the Medicare levy at 1.25 per cent for this year and subsequent years. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 deals with this very wide range of issues, again relating to taxation measures.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) is to amend the Income Tax Act 1986 to impose the rates of tax for 1987-88 and subsequent financial years. In effect, this Bill provides that income tax rates need not be debated on an annual basis by Parliament if no change in the rates is proposed by the Government. This practice of an annual review was actually introduced in 1976 by the late Eric Robinson when income tax indexation was introduced. I suggest that the Government should give consideration to the reintroduction of income tax indexation as it has the effect of keeping taxes down and keeping governments honest. Without such indexation, inflationary pressures and wage increases tend to force up the tax receipts of the Government and put undue pressures on individuals.

It is important that the Opposition's proposed amendment to maintain the facility of annual scrutiny of the tax rates be supported. I commend the Australian Democrats for their support of our proposed amendment. Unfortunately, parliamentary scrutiny of the efficiency of government operations is being constantly eroded by this Labor Government. Let us look at a number of areas. Firstly, the Auditor-General is constantly obliged to operate with inadequate resources. Secondly, steps have been taken to transform the Loan Bill from an annual Bill to a standing Bill to reduce the opportunity for debate and therefore the chance for members of parliament to examine how moneys are actually being spent. Thirdly, the activities of our Joint Committee of Public Accounts are being checked. Recently we were informed that the staff of the secretariat would have to be reduced to one-third of its former level. This is despite the fact that the work load of the Committee has continued to increase and that it has a significant number of statutory responsibilities. Surely it is false economy to constrain the operations of the very committee that can keep a check on the inefficiencies and waste of public money. The Government appears to be doing everything in its power to keep from the public and the Parliament the details of its receipts and expenditures. What does it have to hide? That is the question that we surely must ask ourselves.

Let us look at the increase in company tax rates to 49 per cent. In this Bill the rate of company tax is being officially raised to 49c in the dollar. This increase in the corporate rate is occurring at a time when other countries are in the process of reducing their company tax rates. In fact, I think British companies pay something like 35 per cent corporate tax at the moment. But still we find that the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in its publication Australia Reconstructed, and the Government are surprised by the lack of investment by business in new plant and equipment. It is not surprising that businesses are not investing as the Government and unions would have hoped, because we have increased the rate to 49 per cent tax at a time when other countries are lowering their tax rates. If Australia's huge overseas debt is to be reduced, investment in export industries is absolutely essential. The Government will not encourage such investment by putting up tax rates. The manufacturing industry is crying out for investment dollars to enhance its capacity to compete in the export area. However, with a corporate tax rate of this order, a fringe benefits tax, a capital gains tax, the disallowance of certain legitimate deductions and the multitude of other new taxes it is small wonder that investment is being constrained.

Confusion over exchange rates and Australia's poor inflation rate has further affected investment in this country. It has been said many times in this chamber, and it bears repeating, that the Hawke Government is the biggest taxing government in Australia's peacetime history, despite its claims to have reformed the taxation system. Time will tell that the real impact of these new taxes will be on the economy. One has to look only at the profit result of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, which is down substantially as a result of many of the policies of this Government, including the fringe benefits tax.

In July 1985 the Government removed the Medicare levy limit and paved the way for a backtrack on the promise that was made to the people of Australia. I think that is rather sad. When Medicare was first introduced, we were told that the levy would remain at one per cent and that it would be fully self-supporting. But it has since become obvious that both of those claims have proved to be entirely false. The increase in the Bill of the levy to 1.25 per cent will substantially increase the cost to taxpayers for little apparent benefit. The Government should stand condemned for the confusion it has caused, for its mismanagement of Medicare and for backtracking on a promise that it made earlier to the Australian people.

I turn to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). The thrust of these amendments has the right intent of trying to overcome certain shortcomings in the existing legislation. That philosophy, as such, has some merit. Many of the measures will be welcomed by those who have been struggling with ambiguities in income tax law for some time now. But many of these provisions should have been included in earlier Bills. Unfortunately, the Government's enthusiasm for tax change is streets ahead of its ability to comprehend the consequences these revisions will have upon people, the business community and the level of taxes raised. One of the biggest indictments of this Labor Government is that its enthusiasm for change is such that it is unable to comprehend the consequences.

This Bill makes quite a number of consequential changes. The Government intends to make amendments relating to gift provisions, provisional tax, dividend stripping, the introduction of certain income tax deductions and tax arrangements for certain educational allowances, and there are some inconsequential changes to what are known as the capital gains provisions. The fact that many of these amendments relate specifically to capital gains indicates what the coalition parties have been saying for some time about the capital gains tax-that it is riddled with uncertainties and ambiguities. In the two Acts that outline the capital gains tax we already have 124 pages of legislation. The Commissioner of Taxation has been required to make seven separate rulings in relation to the capital gains tax. Currently, amendments to the Act are before the Senate. This gives some indication of the vagueness of the original legislation and of the fact that the Government went into this without fully comprehending all its ramifications and unintended consequences.

Unfortunately, these amendments are very complex by nature and tend further to complicate the income tax law, despite what I call their good intent. In new section 46e, for example, the Government appears to be operating on the basis of what Senator Walsh has referred to in another area in the Senate as an uneven playing field. He has referred to the uneven playing field in an economic sense in another area, not in relation to new section 46e. The whole scope of tax amendments should not be to raise additional revenue under these provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act; rather they ought to be revenue neutral. Their aim should be to establish whether certain transactions are liable for assessment rather than to raise additional revenue.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) which is now before us is not a taxing provision, but unfortunately it now has that impact. This attempt to make what I term clarifying clauses into taxing clauses is an unfortunate element that all too often is creeping into our Income Tax Assessment Act. If the Government persists in introducing what I term these new types of sections into the principal Act it will only cause further distortion in what has become a very distorted piece of legislation. The three clauses that give rise to these complications are clauses 8, 15 and 37. I am disappointed that everybody has spent so little time in trying to analyse and understand the impact of these sorts of clauses but, rather, has made dissertations about the economy.

As I have said, clause 8 proposes the insertion of a new section 46e into the Income Tax Assessment Act to counteract schemes involving the payment of dividends after 4 June 1987 out of asset revaluation reserves. The complexity of this section is such that a full understanding of an earlier section, section 46a, is necessary before the meaning of section 46e becomes clear. The principal problem with this clause is that its application is considerably wider than that of clause 8 of the original draft Bill which was distributed by the Treasurer in June this year. Simply put, the new Bill that is before us today has a much wider scope than the earlier draft. I believe that it was either dishonesty or a negligent oversight on the part of the Government that this fact was not made clear in the second reading speech. Those taxpayers who, of necessity, have become accustomed to reorganising their business operations in line with what I term the constant flow of Press releases which have been issued by this Treasurer could well find that the changes they have made to keep in conformity with this constant stream of Press releases have put them behind the eight-ball. While people have made changes to their own affairs in good faith, in accordance with these Press releases, they suddenly find, when the new Bill comes forward, that these changes are deficient and that they will be up for a penalty tax and all the liabilities that will be imposed on them. This is just not fair and this is what I term the uneven playing field. It is loaded too much in favour of the Tax Commissioner and not enough consideration is being given to ordinary individuals who will have to work under this Act.

The June Bill sought to deny the intercorporate dividend rebate to a company where a shareholder was in receipt of a dividend and subsequently sold his shares in the asset holding company. According to the legislation before us, this section has actually been extended to include the sale of shares by a person other than the shareholder to companies that are related to the asset holding company. This means that the intercorporate dividend rebate is now denied to a company where a shareholder receives a dividend and he or any other person or entity-and those are the relevant words-subsequently sells his share in the asset holding company or a company related to the asset holding company.

This certainly represents a significant expansion of the conditions that were outlined in June this year. In addition, the first Bill applied only where a shareholder disposed of the share after the revaluation of the asset, whereas under new section 46e, paragraph (2) (a) (ii), the conditions of the new section 46e apply where the shares were disposed of after the revaluation of the assets concerned and, at the time of the revaluation, and even before the time of the revaluation. As a result of these revisions a situation may arise where unfortunately double taxation can occur. Again the dice has been loaded against the taxpayer. I cite an example of circumstances where there has been an undervaluation of assets, which is possible because stock, depending on its nature, can be transferred at a value a lot less than it was earlier. Given the vagaries of the primary industry market, we could imagine agricultural machinery stock being involved in such a situation where there is change in the ownership and structure of a business. In these sorts of circumstances of the undervaluation of assets at the time of transfer to a shareholder, this undervaluation may be taxed in the hands of the company-it certainly is-and the revaluation may then occur. Subsequently a shareholder may then receive an unfranked dividend and, therefore, would be required to pay full tax on that subsequent transaction.

The revisions that I have referred to are significant and, if they are applied from 4 June, as the Bill provides, the Bill will be retrospective in nature. This is quite repugnant. The Opposition's amendment for a new operative date should be supported-not 4 June, as required in the Bill, as it is retrospective in character. People had no way of being able to work out their affairs; if they had followed those earlier Press releases, they would have been caught. This is completely unfair. It is bad legislation and it is certainly a bad practice. Irrespective of whether one accepts the revisions, fairness and equity surely dictate that these new conditions should apply from the date on which they were first announced. That operative date is not 4 June, but 23 September. No one should be condemned for carrying out his business in a fashion that he believed and knew to be within the law at the time. Therefore, I seek the support of this Senate for the coalition's amendment to alter the date of application of these provisions to 23 September.

Legislation by Press release is simply not acceptable in this form, certainly when it comes to the complex issues which deal with income tax. It is a false assumption to accept that these piecemeal announcements make life easier for the taxpayer. More often than not, they merely increase the confusion surrounding the issues, especially when the legislation passed by the Parliament is different in substance from the original Press release. On too many occasions the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has had cause to remind this Government of the impact of using Press releases as a form of ad hoc legislation. Some consideration should be given to those who are struggling to comply with the increasingly complex tax legislation, particularly those who are called upon in a professional capacity to advise their clients on these sorts of matters.

Let me turn briefly to clause 15. The purpose of this clause is to repeal sections 108 and 109 of the principal Act and replace them with the revised provisions which have been outlined in this clause. Sections 108 and 109 are actually designed to prevent tax avoidance by private companies and their shareholders through the use of what we might term disguised dividend distribution. It is a quite necessary provision and one that has been there for some time. This is a principle with which I have absolutely no quarrel whatsoever. However, I believe that the complexities involved in the drafting of this new piece of legislation have led to certain consequences unfortunately being overlooked. Some aspects of the clause remain ambiguous despite the fact that this Bill has been designed to explain more fully the aspects of the principal Act that have hitherto presented some very limited loopholes, which have been exploited and which have enabled evasion to take place.

Therefore, I believe that the following matters deserve consideration. Let us look at the change in wording. In section 108 (1) of the principal Act the word `income' is used in the description of the term `dividend distribution'. It states:
Distributions of income shall, for the purposes of this Act, be deemed to be dividends paid by the company . . .

It is interesting to note that in the corresponding clause of this Bill, which is to replace the old section 108, the word `profits' is used in the same context. To identify such a distinction may appear to some to be a bit overenthusiastic. However, for the accountants who may read this speech or who may try to evaluate the clause, or for anybody with an interest in economic or financial matters, this is a significant distinction. I appreciate the problems that the Commissioner of Taxation may have had in circumstances where sections 108 and 109, or the proposed new section 46e, must be read in conjunction with section 44 (1) of the Act, in which it states `dividends can only be paid out of profits'. That is where there was a loophole because they had to be read together and one section related to income and the other to profits. Of course, we have to acknowledge that the Commissioner does have the absolute discretionary power to say that profits are deemed to have been made even though they have not been made. This is a quite extraordinary provision and shows the lengths to which the legislators have to go, or are prepared to go, in an attempt to squeeze the last dollar of tax out of taxpayers.

So there is an inconsistency between the original section and the proposed new section that could possibly open another loophole for evasion. I believe that, as a result of these changes, we must now expect further amendments. I will certainly be asking for a ruling from the Taxation Commissioner in future to explain fully the Government's intent and the Taxation Commissioner's intent with respect to this clause, because it is quite unclear. The business community, the financial community, deserves more, particularly when the Government says that it is designing the legislation to improve an old provision.

Already since January this year the Taxation Commissioner has been required to make 121 rulings. Honourable senators should note that. We are now up to ruling 2,450 in the list of income tax rulings alone. Honourable senators should take note of that. Miscellaneous rulings have reached a total of 2,037. The fact that we have over 2,000 rulings from the Tax Commissioner just shows how complex our Income Tax Assessment Act has become. In other words, as I mentioned with regard to the insurance legislation, the Government is abrogating its legislative responsibility and passing it over to the bureaucrats, in this case the Taxation Commissioner. The fact that he has given over 2,450 rulings is indicative of the fact that we are losing the opportunity to legislate and requiring the Tax Commissioner to determine more and more cases at his discretion.

The question is: what is a legitimate intercorporate loan? Most people would agree that the thrust of the Bill, to overcome the shortcomings in existing legislation, obviously has some merit. It is only correct that tax avoidance tactics should be deterred. It is also correct that legitimate arrangements should not be restricted or hampered by regulations designed to prevent tax avoidance. However, there is some danger that the measures outlined in this Bill may-I submit that they will-create uncertainty as to what is legitimate activity and what is not. This is especially so with respect to intercorporate loans.

This Bill does not tell us what constitutes a legitimate intercorporate loan. I appeal to the Tax Commissioner to give us a further ruling as to what constitutes a legitimate intercorporate loan. According to proposed new section 46e in the Bill, the Commissioner has the power to rule on the legitimacy of such loans. But I believe the open-ended nature of the discretionary powers of the Commissioner in this instance could well bring about a level of uncertainty sufficient to cause further investment uncertainty. At the very least in this case, another ruling should be issued by the Tax Commissioner to clarify in which circumstances intercorporate loans will be deemed legitimate. The circumstances should be outlined with all possible speed so that investment in this uncertain climate will not be hampered.

The ability to decide on the legitimacy of intercorporate loans is not a unique exercise for the Taxation Commissioner. Many situations, outlined in the Income Tax Assessment Act, are determined at the Commissioner's discretion. In many of those cases, I submit that that is appropriate. It is also true that there are some cases in which the Tax Commissioner is given some extraordinarily wide powers. For example, under section 44 of the principal Act the Tax Commissioner has the power, in a situation where no profit has been made by a company, to decree for his own purpose that profits have been made. That is a quite extraordinary power-far too wide and quite unnecessary.

The powers of the Tax Commissioner were further extended when the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) was passed in the last session of the Parliament. I spoke on that Bill and I remind the Senate briefly of the Bill's consequences. Under section 62 of that legislation, taxpayers are required to give assistance to the Australian Taxation Office rather than just to allow right of access. I accept the proposition that adequate measures need to be taken to make sure that tax avoidance is uncovered. However, these sorts of increased investigatory powers, and their extension to pay as you earn provisions, open up avenues through which people's civil liberties are threatened. That is wrong. The regulatory powers under section 62 of that Act went far beyond the original intention of this legislative chamber. My concern, therefore, is that the extension of those investigatory powers may foster an attitude of officialdom; that is, that, pursued to the extreme, they may infringe civil rights.

The powers that I have mentioned are considerable and, unfortunately, we are increasing those powers quite unnecessarily. Therefore, I believe that the time has come for some thought to be given as to how far we are prepared to extend the already discretionary powers of the Tax Commissioner. By amending sections 108 and 109 in the manner outlined in this Bill, we are reinforcing the principle of giving the Tax Commissioner further extraordinary powers and reinforcing the unacceptable principle, outlined in section 44(1), of the Tax Commissioner being able to deem profits to have been made even when profits have not been made. That is an important issue that should be given further consideration.

Unfortunately, I will not have time to go through all the detailed provisions of the other changes. Let us look briefly at clause 37 relating to provisional tax. This clause provides that for 1987-88 provisional tax shall be calculated on the basis of 1986-87 taxable income, increased by 11 per cent, and by applying the 1987-88 rates of tax and the Medicare levy. If we are to accept that this 11 per cent increase in provisional tax is to make allowance for the inflation rate, surely we must question the Treasurer's Budget projection that the inflation rate will fall from 9 per cent to 6 per cent by the middle of 1988. Therefore, there seems to be an excess tax recovery relative to what might be expected, given Mr Keating's estimate for the inflation rate. Are we to assume that the income of those people who pay provisional tax, that is, our entrepreneurs, is expected to increase at a much greater rate than that of wage and salary earners? The facts just do not bear that out. Is the Government trying to crib extra taxation revenue through provisional tax? That is the issue in question. I notice that people are tending to ignore that issue. The tax Bills that we have before us today are indeed complex and many unintended consequences could arise from them. I suggest that honourable senators take careful note of what is before us today. I urge the Taxation Commissioner to give rulings at the earliest opportunity to clarify three areas of ambiguity that have arisen as a result of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Senator Watson's most interesting and pungent speech, I took note of four matters which he raised and which I think had already been raised by others during this debate. I think it is worth commenting on them. The first matter he raised was about the announcement of legislation by media release. The second was that the company tax rate of 49 per cent is somehow bringing ruin to our financial and manufacturing industries. The third concerned the amendments in the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987 which fix rates not only for this year but for subsequent years. The fourth comment he made was about tax rulings by the Commissioner of Taxation.
—It's just a discretion.

—That is right. Announcing proposed policy changes by media release can be bad but it can be necessary. For example, nobody would object, when a Budget is brought down, if the thrust of that Budget is announced to the world by media release. Indeed, that is the only way it can be done. So, to make a universal condemnation of announcing policy changes by media release is not to the point. Each case has to be looked at in the circumstances that arise at the time. The second point made was that the company tax rate of 49 per cent is the reason for Australia's economic problems. I think that is manifestly incorrect.
—I said `in association with'.
—Associated with what? That is the problem. If the Opposition had wanted to develop that argument, it should have looked at our real problems.
—The Labor Government.

—I will tell Senator Baume what we are doing to help the economy of this country. Page 4 of this morning's Australian Financial Review reports on a survey by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures which indicates that the real problem is a lack of skills in Australia. If we compare Japan and Australia, we see that Japan is much more highly skilled than Australia. What this Government is doing, and doing with great vigour and, as will be seen in the future, with great success, is ensuring that Australia is properly equipped with the educational and skills base that is so necessary to develop our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to quote from a speech given by the Hon. John Dawkins, MP, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, on 16 October 1987, which no doubt all honourable senators have read:

It is no coincidence that the recent ACTU report is entitled `Australia Reconstructed'. There is now a general public perception, largely due to the Government's efforts, that Australia today must undertake a process of structural adjustment at least as profound as that experienced during the 1940s.
The deterioration of our external economic situation caused by our failure to compete in traded goods and services threatens our standard of living to an extent unparalleled since the war.

Productivity improvements are essential. Education and training can play a vital role, directly conditioning the quality, depth and flexibility of our labour force skills. The Government is determined that our education and training systems will contribute to the process of economic adjustment, to the benefit both of individuals and of the nation as a whole.

This Government is intervening, if you like, in those areas which are necessary for a successful economic recovery in this country. I must say with some sadness to those opposite who say that the whole thing should be left somehow to the market-place, where, by some process of good luck and good fortune, things will come good, that this Government does not take that approach. It looks at the areas of need, it looks at the situation as it is, and it sets out to provide for what is actually the richest resource any country has-its labour force, the citizens of the country-the education and the skills needed. To, as it were, belittle Australia's problems by saying that we are in our present situation because the Government collects a 49 per cent tax on the profits of companies really misses the point.
I come to the third point. Both Acts I have mentioned are being amended to fix the levy for this year and for the future. Great objection is taken to that by both Senator Watson and Senator Haines--

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Baume, too.

—And Senator Baume. If he takes an objection, it must have considerable force and therefore it must be answered. It is a little hard to see what the objection is. The Government, in effect, is saying, `We are now fixing rates which we undertake will persist, not for one year but for this year and the year after that, so that people can go about their business and do the planning that is so necessary for a stable economy and for the economic recovery of this country'. What is wrong in principle with a government saying that it will fix tax rates which will persist into the future-not only for the next year but for the year after that? If anyone is planning to invest in a company, to put a mortgage on a home, to take an overseas trip or to send children to school, he can be assured of the tax rates and the Medicare levy not only for next year but for years after that. But the Opposition says no--
—If you followed that logic, you would have tax indexation.

—No. Tax indexation has nothing to do with this amendment one way or the other. When the Opposition raises the question of tax indexation, in effect it is speaking against its own amendment and supporting the original legislation. Certainty should be given to the people of this country about the tax they will have to pay, not only for one year but for subsequent years. But the Opposition is not saying that. It is not saying it wants tax indexation; it is saying that it wants to have a go at this each year and keep the people of Australia in a terrible state of uncertainty so that they will never know what they will have to pay by way of taxation for more than a year at a time. I would have thought that, if the people of Australia wanted to plan for their future, they would be better off knowing what they have to pay by way of taxation than under the capricious system put forward by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. Under that system, there would be a toss of a coin each year, and the amount of tax people had to pay would depend on how the coin landed.
—I have never heard parliamentary scrutiny described as the toss of a coin.
—That is the reality. I do not know whether Senator Baume has spoken yet, but I would like to know what he has in principle against giving certainty to the taxation system.
—I have a very strong objection to the way you are doing it. It is certain death your way.

—No, it is not certain death. I will tell the honourable senator what people will have to pay under our system, because it makes fairly good reading. From the very high rates of taxation that we inherited from the Fraser Government, and that we have struggled valiantly and persistently to overcome, we have got down to what we have now. At the low end of the scale for resident taxpayers no tax is payable on taxable incomes up to $5,100. So people can earn up to $5,100 and pay no tax.
—Adjust it for inflation and see what you get.

—I will come to that. There has been an increase in the tax free threshold from the 1986-87 level of $4,890. On taxable incomes in the range of $5,101 to $12,600 the rate is 24 per cent. On incomes in the range of $12,601 to $19,500 the rate is 29 per cent. The rates for incomes from $19,501 to $28,000 and $28,001 to $35,000 have been reduced from 43 per cent and 46 per cent respectively to 40 per cent. The top marginal rate has dropped from 55 per cent-originally 60 per cent-to 49 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson asked about inflation. I will tell him two things about inflation. Inflation is coming down under the Government and the honourable senator can be assured that, with this Government's history and with the concern it has for all its citizens, if in fact there ought to be an adjustment for particular economic conditions that arise, it will act. The argument that says that we should not have a system which sets rates for more than one year is really based on the concept that somehow those rates are fixed as if in a written constitution. They are not; they are fixed by legislation, and if changes are to take place they can be accommodated in legislation. If honourable senators opposite want to debate tax rates at any stage they can; they do not need a Bill to do so. I am unable to see why we cannot go ahead on the basis of fixing rates over a period of time.

Having been condemned for the fixing of rates for a particular period, we were then taken to task for allowing the Commissioner to make tax rulings because it was suggested that that leads to uncertainty. So in one breath the Opposition condemns a provision that would lead to certainty in tax rates over the years; in the next breath it condemns the practice of the Commissioner of issuing tax rulings because of the uncertainty that that causes. Let us have a look at the tax rulings. The tax rulings were and are internal rulings by the Taxation Commissioner for the purposes of his staff. Because of freedom of information legislation they have become public, and the public certainly acts upon them now. The point about the rulings is this: they have been going on for years and they are necessary for the operation of a proper taxation system. They are not new, and to suggest in some way that having the Commissioner make rulings is something new that this Government has introduced is just not correct.

The Opposition has complained that the Taxation Commissioner has wide powers-and indeed he has. The reason he has wide powers is that that is the only way that tax avoidance schemes can be countered. Such schemes grew up because of the black letter law approach taken by His Honour the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, Sir Garfield Barwick, when he was interpreting tax legislation during the 1970s. Such legislation was tolerated, unfortunately, by honourable senators opposite and this has led to a tax avoidance industry which this Government has struggled to overcome. One of the weapons it has used is the giving, by necessity, of a wide range of powers to the Taxation Commissioner so that he can make sure that taxation avoidance does not go on in the way that it did while it watered the system in the past.

They were the four points raised by earlier speakers. All of them seem to me but damp squibs when they are analysed out. Perhaps the major point made related to the question of how the economy is affected by the 49 per cent rate. It is major because it does at least turn our minds to the real issue that we in this country have to face-the development of a vibrant and growing industrial sector. The Government, as I say, is doing considerable amounts of work in that area, particularly in the field of education. It is an area where the government must intervene at particular levels.

When we talk about how industry has developed over the years-say, from the 1966-67 period to the present-we should look at the rates of return on capital for all industries over that period because the figures are very interesting. The lowest return on capital for private trading corporations over that period was in the year 1982-83, when it was down to 10.7 per cent. With the advent of the Hawke Government the rate has increased ever since. It must, of course, increase more. One of the problems is that the capital investment itself over that period was very slack, so that Australian industry has been left with equipment that has not been sufficient for the task. This Government is turning that around. It has encouraged industry to develop. It is in that area where this Government will proceed to reconstruct Australia and Australian industry.

To talk in terms, as it were, of turning the economy off and on in the way that the Opposition seeks to do is not a sufficient answer to that point. To oppose, as I say, a fixing of rates for the Medicare levy and taxation levels for an extended period, as is intended to be done by the Bills as a way of giving certainty to the whole system, and to proceed on the Opposition's amendment, is really to bring uncertainty to the system, which everybody agrees is not good. So the Opposition, in opposing this legislation and amending it to cut out the fixing of rates for a number of financial years, is bringing around the very disaster-that is, uncertainty-which it purports to want to avoid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the committee stage I shall move an amendment relating specifically to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). That amendment will relate to the tax deductibility of advertising of tobacco and tobacco products. Of course, it bears also on the matter of the Medicare levy because, as I will show, the tobacco induced diseases cost this country very dearly both in terms of health and in terms of the direct financial burden on the health care system. Honourable senators will have noticed that recently the Victorian Government has moved to ban certain forms of advertising and to raise a tax on tobacco products so as to support sport and the arts which are currently supported more directly through the advertising of tobacco products in relation to those activities. Indeed, similar moves have been mooted in South Australia and Western Australia. It seems to me, therefore, very appropriate that a Labor Federal government should support these moves by removing centrally the tax deductibility from tobacco advertising.

SPEECH.PARA: Tobacco and tobacco related diseases at present constitute one of the most serious forms of drug addiction in Australian society. The recent drug initiatives taken by the Federal Government indicated that roughly 80 per cent of drug related deaths in Australia are directly or indirectly related to the consumption of tobacco and tobacco products. Only 10 per cent were related to alcohol and only 2 per cent were in fact related to the taking of hard drugs. So, undoubtedly in the case of tobacco, we have an addiction problem of monumental proportions-one which is directly responsible for 23,000 deaths each year in Australia. Some 63 people each day die in Australia as a consequence of smoking. That is almost the number of senators in this chamber; it is certainly many more than the number of senators sitting in it at present. It is not only lung disease of which these people die, although that is one of the most common causes of death. Because tobacco contains a number of carcinogenic substances, there is an across the board increase in the incidence of cancer among those who smoke, particularly in relation to bladder and, to a lesser extent, bowel cancer. The likelihood of getting most cancers is increased in smokers.

It is well known that heart disease is one of the consequences of smoking. There is a substantial increase in heart disease among those who smoke and this contributes substantially to the reasons for wanting to increase the Medicare levy. It is well publicised in literature the Senate received just recently that smoking is one of the risk factors which rate very heavily in relation to heart disease. I have seen photographs of peripheral arterial disease and recently I treated patients who lost limbs as a consequence of smoking. At various times one has seen quite peculiar pictures of people who have lost both legs and both arms and yet they are still continuing to smoke. It is a very serious and very disabling disease.

Perhaps less well known is the fact that most diseases associated with the aging process reveal themselves at an earlier age among smokers. This is a consequence of the number of mutagenic agents which are present in tobacco, and a substantial body of opinion suggests that the aging process represents the increase in the number of mutations which occur in the body throughout life. Moreover, it is well known that tobacco products act as synergistic agents with respect to a number of other hazardous substances in the environment. Two which are well known are asbestos and uranium. It is well known that those who are exposed to asbestos and who also smoke suffer far more than just the simple additive risk of developing lung, bowel and bladder cancers-and a similar situation exists in relation to uranium mining.

A number of other conditions exist. For instance, one could point to the general problem of photochemical smog in cities. Epidemiological studies show quite clearly that smokers in cities also have a higher expectation of developing those diseases related to smoking because of the synergistic effect of the other agents, coming largely from car exhausts but to some extent from industries which are present in cities.

It is almost universally recognised that children of smoking mothers are more likely to be born undersize; they are more likely to be less mature at birth; they are more likely to be aborted; and they are more likely to suffer from and die of neonatal disease. There has been quite an extensive advertising campaign to try to convince mothers that they should not smoke during pregnancy. What is not so generally known is that because tobacco smoke contains a number of mutagenic agents the children of smoking fathers-that is, fathers who have smoked before they are responsible for the birth of a child-are more likely to be aborted and are more likely to be born with birth defects. As an aside, I refer to the sexist nature of the advertising which aims the anti-smoking campaign at women whereas it should really be aimed, to a large extent, at fathers before they father children.

Having laid out that background, I turn directly to the cost which this imposes on society and, more particularly, the dollar cost because that is my reason for wishing to move an amendment which will effectively remove tobacco advertising from the area of tax deductibility. Much has been said about making the Australian economy more productive. Members of the Opposition in particular have remarked recently, in the light of the stock market crash, that it is terribly important to make the Australian economy more productive. The advertising of tobacco products is not adding to Australia's productivity. Even without the adverse effects on health, every honourable senator would recognise that advertising tobacco products is a useless activity in terms of productivity. Advertising tobacco products does not do one jot to increase productivity in this country. The second point I make is that the taxation law should not be seen in isolation-it should not be seen simply as a revenue raising measure-but should be integrated into other social and economic objectives. Therefore, it should be seen as an instrument of social policy.

At present the company tax rate in Australia is 49 per cent. So the effect of tax deductibility for tobacco advertising is that 50 per cent of the cost of advertising tobacco and tobacco products is essentially paid for by the community because it is paid for out of avoided tax. That is a fact which many people, even in the anti-smoking groups, do not recognise. It seems quite remarkable that we should give tax deductibility to an activity which promotes the sale and consumption of a product which kills 63 Australians every day, seven days a week and 52 weeks a year and yet-honourable senators will recall that I asked a question of Senator Walsh about a week or so ago to verify this point-any public spirited person who wished to advertise the dangers of smoking would have to pay for that advertising out of the income on which he had paid tax. A gross distortion is built into this tax system in that those who profit from the sale of something which will kill 63 Australians every day are entitled to tax deductibility for the advertising costs of such a product whereas those who, for no other reason than a sense of public spirit, wish to advertise the hazards do not get tax deductibility.

The tobacco industry and tobacco related diseases, through the morbidity and mortality they cause, are placing a crippling financial burden on Australian society.
