It is estimated that each smoker costs business in Australia $940 per year in sick leave and decreased productivity. That is a direct burden on the productivity of Australian industry. In 1981-82 the Medical Journal of Australia broke down those figures and suggested that more than $1,000m in social, health and medical costs was related to smoking induced diseases. It was made up as follows: $400m in the provision of hospital beds and care in hospital; $250m in costs related to deaths; and $350m in the social costs related to lost wages, lost productivity and so on.

Directly in terms of advertising it is difficult to derive a reliable figure, but it is believed that somewhere between $100m and $150m a year is spent advertising tobacco and tobacco products. So the increased revenue that would result from the measure contained in my amendment-that is, to remove tax deductibility from tobacco advertising-would mean increased government revenue of $50m to $75m per year. However, to the extent to which this move would be successful in reducing the incidence of the diseases about which I have been speaking, there would be further substantial savings to the Australian Government by way of tax and other revenue. The tobacco industry is on record as saying repeatedly-and I think this point needs to be interpreted carefully-that curtailing advertising has not led to a reduction in tobacco consumption. In fact, just recently the tobacco industry claimed that various curbs on advertising had been associated with an increase in tobacco consumption. If for the moment one accepted that assertion at face value-which I do not-it would doubly prove that advertising as such is a useless activity, that we could do without it and there would be no decrease in the consumption of tobacco products.
With that preamble, I think it appropriate that I read the amendment that I will be moving at the committee stage. My amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 provides:
Page 10, after clause 9, insert the following clause:
``Losses and outgoings
``9a. Section 51 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end the following sub-section:
`(8) A deduction is not allowable under subsection (1) in respect of expenditure for the purpose of the advertising or promotion of-
(a) tobacco, substances containing tobacco, synthetic tobacco or any substance intended or designed for smoking;
(b) cigarettes, cigars or other items intended or designed to be used for smoking; or
(c) smoking pipes or any other accessories, items or devices intended or designed to be used principally for or in association with smoking.'.''.

I would have liked to have included in the amendment a mechanism to prevent tobacco companies from advertising the advantages to tobacco advertising, because that is a move which the industry in Victoria has foreshadowed. Time and the difficulty associated with wording such an amendment preclude that, so my amendment simply seeks to abolish the tax deductibility of tobacco, tobacco products and smoking facilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987 and a cognate Bill. However, I will refer specifically to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, which will entrench the Medicare levy at the rate of 1.25 per cent, which has been effective since 1 December 1986. At that time the rate was increased from one per cent by an announcement in the 1986-87 Budget, despite the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of 13 November 1984 when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: And I now give this undertaking that for the term of our next Government the Medicare levy will not be increased.

Of course, that was not the only broken promise but it brought in considerable revenue for the Government. It was an extension of the concept of Medicare, of providing universal health care for all people. That would not have been so bad perhaps if it was not for the fact that the Medicare system has failed completely and that health care consumers who have relied on Medicare have been let down absymally. That is why I want to discuss it this morning-because I think it is important that people who have not faced the failure of Medicare understand what those in this country who are sick have been putting up with for some years.

I will discuss the reality of Medicare. Fortunately many people in the community have not been sick and have not experienced the problems suffered by so many others. There is a waiting list for elective surgery in the vicinity of 100,000, which the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) rather cutely calls a booking list as though booking in for surgery is something one does if one thinks it is going to be a wet weekend or there is nothing better on. People on the list are waiting for surgery which they need to assist them to get on with their lives. For example, people are having to wait 18 months to two years for such things as hip replacements. A two year wait for surgery can have a serious impact on a family. What it really amounts to is that the very people that Medicare needs to help most-the elderly and the poor-have been left stranded by what is really a crumbling excuse for a health system.

The Government has recognised that Medicare is in a parlous state because it recently allocated $25m extra to the States for their public hospitals to try to reduce these huge waiting lists and get the system moving a bit. So there is a clear recognition by the Government that the system that it set up has not been working and has not provided what is needed. At the same time, of course, we know that there are private hospitals with space, with beds and places that people could go to if they had private cover. Of course, many of them did have private cover until, unfortunately, they allowed themselves to be taken in by the rhetoric of this Government that the Medicare levy would provide all and that one did not need private cover; that is, if one was paying the Medicare levy and was in the system, one had no need to look beyond that for health care. The reality is that people have had to look beyond that, and the consequences for many have been serious indeed.

Those people who could afford private health care cover but opted out of that system are also now on waiting lists for surgery in public hospitals. They need not be on those waiting lists for public hospitals but, because they are, they are keeping to the back of the waiting lists people who rely on the public hospital system and who are entitled to rely on it. The system is totally out of kilter and the people who are suffering most are those least able to help themselves in this area. Those who were receiving good health cover previously are now being messed around at every turn. Many people have dropped their private health care cover-many of them because, as I said, they believed in the rhetoric and many of them because they could not afford to pay the levy and maintain their cover. In December 1983 over nine million Australians, or 61 per cent, had private health care cover. It is now under eight million, or 48 per cent of the population, which is a reduction of some 1.8 million people. That has made the difference and has caused the incredible delays in the provision of proper medical treatment through the public hospital system.

I will refer specifically to what has happened in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). The ACT is a defined area where we can comprehend what has happened. It is a small area. I believe that the same thing has happened throughout the rest of Australia, but by looking at the ACT we can encapsulate what has occurred. There has been a chronology of disasters right from the beginning. I will not go back to the beginning, but I will set the scene in relation to what has happened this year, including the problems that nurses have had in getting their career structure and new pay structure put in place. The award was handed down in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on 7 May and only in the past week has a settlement been reached. The nurses have had to take industrial action and they have been continually frustrated while working towards getting the Arbitration Commission award put into effect. At the same time there has been the dispute with the doctors who have been servicing the Medicare system, their services being withdrawn from March this year. That dispute is not yet finally settled. At the same time recently there have been problems in the area of service industries to the hospitals over the disposal of rubbish. There have been problems in the kitchens, problems with the doctors employed in the hospital system and problems in other areas involving professionals.

I have decided to go through just one month in order to give a resume of various happenings, and the list is incredible. I start with 22 October when nurses threatened to strike in the ACT hospitals, the relevant Minister refusing to see them. They had walked out of the Royal Canberra Hospital at 3 o'clock that morning. On 24 October nurses walked out of several wards at Woden Valley Hospital over their pay and career structure arising from the award given on 7 May this year. On 25 October elective surgery was stopped indefinitely at Woden Valley Hospital after the ACT Health Authority stated that adequate health care could not be relied on there. On 26 September members of the ACT branch of the Professional Officers Association working in pathology laboratories of the Health Authority reimposed bans on the installation of a new computer system. That dispute had been going on for some time. On 2 October the Hospital Employees Federation (HEF) refused to collect hospital waste, nauseous waste being left in the hospital.

Interspersed is the story of a 74-year-old patient being taken from Woden to Wagga Wagga Hospital. There have been many instances recently of patients being taken from the Australian Capital Territory to New South Wales-to Sydney if they can get a bed there, to Wagga if not. Of course, the doctors who treat Medicare patients in New South Wales are paid at a rate higher than the Government is prepared to offer to doctors treating Medicare patients in the Australian Capital Territory. That is the crux of the story. It is arguable that the amount being paid in New South Wales and the amount the doctors are seeking in the Australian Capital Territory is too high, and that has been stated. But how does the Government justify paying doctors treating Medicare patients in New South Wales at a higher rate than it is prepared to offer them to do the same work in the Australian Capital Territory? That has most of the community somewhat bemused.

On 3 October Salvation Army volunteers fed patients, providing meals for 300 of them. On 4 October an HEF picket line was hampering undertakers doing their work in and out of the hospitals. On Monday of the long weekend garbage was piled up and food and cleaning were still being done by volunteers. On 7 October the dispute with the HEF ended and garbage was being collected. The bans had also affected the Jindalee Nursing Home and families had had to take meals in for their relatives. On 8 October the health inspectors threatened to impose bans in connection with the implementation by the Authority of a new career structure. On the same day there were disputes with the community nurses, who had a stop-work meeting to protest against the failure of the Health Authority to provide information on staff numbers to their union.

On 9 October the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) attacked the demands of private doctors for parity with New South Wales. That was not a particularly helpful intervention, but at least we knew that he knew that we had problems in our health care system. On 15 October the doctors passed a unanimous vote of no confidence in the Health Authority's running of medical services in Canberra's hospitals. On 16 October we were told that discussions with the nurses were continuing, and that it was believed that the dispute was near the end and that the career structure may be implemented.

On 19 October we had the problem over the closure of beds. The Health Authority denied that it planned to close beds in the hospitals. Subsequently that issue expanded and the Health Authority admitted that it had not had detailed consultation with the unions over what was to happen. I believe that there is uncertainty as to how many beds are to be opened. We were told in the Estimates committee hearings that Royal Canberra Hospital was to be significantly refurbished, and for that reason some of the wards are being closed. On 20 October the HEF and the Royal Australian Nursing Federation (RANF) banned ward closures and wanted discussions with the Health Authority as to what was going on. Subsequently to that, we had the admission that there had not been adequate consultations. Then there was an announcement on 23 October that the Authority was conducting an investigation into an allegation that a private nappy service had been operated, without the Authority's knowledge, from the Authority's laundry facility at Mitchell.

The local newspapers are filled daily with stories about the health situation. It cannot be said that the system is working smoothly or providing the service that people require and are entitled to rely upon. However, with the resolution of the nurses' dispute, there is some relief and the hope that things may settle down. But I think that we in Canberra will not for some time have a hospital service such as that which we have had in the past and on which we have relied. People in the surrounding region relied on that service and many came to Canberra for medical assistance. A recent newspaper article told of an anaesthetist who had moved to Canberra from Tasmania nine or 10 months ago and had expressed his despair at the system here, saying that he was thinking of returning to Tasmania, because he had never come across anything quite like the system that operates in the ACT or its inconvenience. It has had a serious effect on the services provided. Many doctors, and anaesthetists in particular, have left Canberra. That is one of the difficulties in having sufficient specialists in these areas to provide the service that is needed. That is why I suggest that we may not return to the sort of health care system that we have become accustomed to, and indeed have been used to.

Individual patients continue to suffer, and I have had many such examples. At times the health care system is virtually non-existent. There are many other instances beyond the ones that I know about, such as that of a woman being transferred from one hospital to another while certain procedures were taking place. Another involved a little girl aged seven whose parents did not have private health insurance-they told me that they did not believe that they needed it and that Medicare would provide the services they needed. That young child had severe ear problems and her father had to go to the expense of having her treated in a private hospital. He had to pay for treatment to which he believed he was entitled as he was paying the Medicare levy.

I know of a cancer patient in his late thirties who also had no private insurance. He told me subsequently that he could have afforded it, but did not believe he needed it because he believed that Medicare provided the health care service. He was diagnosed as having a particular type of cancer that was likely to spread rapidly and quickly. It was said that he should have a CAT-scan and surgery and get on with the treatment process. He was unable to do that in Canberra Hospital, and ended up going to Calvary private hospital and having the surgery, but had to pay $270 a day. He had to discharge himself from hospital after this major surgery at the end of a week because he could not afford to stay in the hospital any longer. At that stage he took himself home. It may be that, if he had waited for as long as it would have taken for the service to be available through the Medicare system, it would have been quite pointless in any event.

These are the things that have been happening. There is the story of an invalid pensioner who was scheduled to have an implant in her right eye on 4 June. It still has not been done. The shortage of anaesthetists has meant that she is still waiting. As a consequence of her problem she overbalances easily and falls over. She is a widow who lives alone. Her son has now made arrangements for her to have the operation carried out privately in November. He will be paying for the operation so that his mother can get the help she needs-help that she cannot get from the Medicare system in the ACT at present. These stories are just the tip of the iceberg of problems faced by the people of Canberra.

In addition, we should look at the reduction in the services available under Medicare. There have been many changes to the system and people are not getting as much as they were when it was first introduced. For example, there has been a reduction in rebates on fees paid for visits to consulting physicians. This is particularly significant for seriously and chronically ill patients who must go to follow-up surgery. It will cost them significantly more under these new arrangements. I have been contacted by people who can give proof of what it will mean to them. I was contacted by a man whose wife is suffering from brain tumours and requires frequent visits to specialists. People out there who are sick know what they cannot get now by way of health care which they were able to get in the past. I do not know what this Government assumes it should provide or what standard of care it regards as adequate, but it is very clear that the service provided now is far inferior to that which was available in the past.

Another example is the reduction in rebates for treatment of certain types of skin cancer and warts. When one considers the figures existing in this country for skin cancer, one feels that that is a particularly foolish course to adopt. Many pharmaceuticals have been removed from the free list. There was the particular incident when those containing aspirin were removed. I understand that that decision was subsequently reversed by the Government. There has been the increased charge for prescriptions-from $2.50 when this Government came to office, then to $5 and now to $10. There has also been a reduction in the schedule fee for cataract removal, from $650 to $450, and for lens replacement, from $345 to $250. These are serious and significant matters for the people who suffer and who hope to rely on the Medicare system.

It is little wonder that, when Government Ministers boast of the achievements of Medicare, their boasts have a very hollow ring for many Australians, particularly those in the ACT, who have come to know how little they can rely on Medicare for their health care cover. This Bill increases the financial burden on Australian taxpayers and families who must keep funding a clearly defective health care system. It is time that the Government recognised the failure of the Medicare system. It should re-examine the way in which health care is being delivered and set about restoring the system so that all families can have proper cover and can rely on getting the treatment they need when they are sick and when they need it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, want to refer to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987 in this cognate debate. I was very sad and sorry to hear the litany of horror stories that Senator Reid has just put before the Senate. Of course, all of them were predictable and predicted as long ago as the introduction of the old Medibank system when Mr Hayden was the Minister for Social Security. I was sorry to hear those stories. This Bill is breaking Government promises by increasing the Medicare levy from one per cent to 1.25 per cent and removing the ceiling on the amount that people have to pay. The higher their taxable income, the more they have to pay and, of course, this applies to all taxpayers, whether they want Medicare or not. Their private medical insurance is not deductible and gap insurance is prohibited by law. There is no incentive at all for people to look after themselves. This is despite the fact that many people are still privately insured, which shows that they want their choice of doctor and hospital.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the distortions and disruptions that this has caused-particularly in the public hospitals-we now see fewer numbers of out-patients. The casualty departments are full, but the out-patients departments-where people can get specialist and consultant care-are now right down because the application of the Medicare rebates encourages people to see consultants in their private surgeries. This means that we have less teaching material and a different type of patient going into hospitals, so that the medical students are seeing an atypical cross-section of illnesses in the community. As has been mentioned, literally thousands of beds have been closed in public hospitals in Australia, but not in Queensland, I might add. The effects of all these medical horror stories are not so bad in Queensland because we have maintained our free public hospital system in spite of the reductions in funding that we have suffered from the Commonwealth because of it. The delays in surgery have been mentioned and they are monumental, particularly in the southern States. The Government is putting money towards this now to try to cover the weeping sore that it has created. No doubt this will have a temporary ameliorating effect; but it is only treating symptoms, not the disease.

General practice has suffered a gradual erosion and fragmentation but, more particularly, there has been a decrease in the scope of work that is done by general practitioners. We have seen enormous changes in the family general practice with the advent of entrepreneurial and business consortia in the profession. Specialised clinics are developing throughout the country and we are seeing the advent of alternative health sources. One of the worst features for general practice is that the development and delivery of new health initiatives-particularly in the high technology area-have been bypassing the general practitioners. The transfer of patients from the out-patients departments of public hospitals to the consultants' private offices has caused a jump in the incomes of consultants, which has caused government computers to cough. The Government decided that it wanted to reduce the incomes of consultants. The way it chose to do that was to restrict the benefits it paid to the patients. In doing so, of course, it threw the baby out with the bath water and this has turned out to be a most cruel and inhuman means of attacking the problem.

The treatment of many chronic and serious illnesses has been restricted. Many of those patients need more than three visits to a consultant in any one year and their interim management cannot be handled adequately by their general practitioner. I refer to the treatment of diseases such as leukaemia, particularly today with the advent of bone marrow transplantation; to chemotherapy treatment; and to the treatment of certain cases of diabetes, arthritis and epilepsy. In fact, a whole list of these conditions came out of Estimates Committee D. Officers from the Department of Community Services and Health recognised that they had created enormous problems for many of the patients. I hope and trust that the Government is looking into ways of fixing these problems, but I hope it does not fix them with another distortion because government interference over many years has distorted health care more and more. Instead of the Government reducing its role in health care, it keeps increasing it. So the distortions and dislocations increase.

Bulk billing has turned many doctors into surrogate public servants without, I might say, the commensurate benefits that accrue to public servants-the `fat cats' to whom Clyde Cameron referred, who receive retirement benefits, study leave, trips and travel, compassionate leave, maternity leave or responsibility loadings. Instead of private medicine being in a position to lift the load from government, the costs of private medicine have been loaded on to the Government under the Medicare arrangements. We need to stop the rot. We need a clear division between private and public health care. The bulk of the people can and should look after the bulk of their illnesses for the bulk of the time. They have shown that they are willing and able to do so. The mechanism by which it can be done is private medical insurance. People have been prevented from doing so by the activities of successive governments.

The principles of health care free at the point of delivery and community rating have been exposed as the rocks upon which all national health schemes would have foundered. National health schemes that have been instituted around the world, promising health care free at the point of delivery, all have one thing in common-they are all failures.

There are four main divisions in medicine: medical education, medical research, preventive medicine and curative medicine. The more the Government puts into medical education, medical research and preventive medicine, the less it will have to put into curative medicine. It is in the area of curative medicine that private enterprise can lift the load from government. As I said, the machine by which to do this is private medical insurance. But the Government has thrown a spanner in the machine and kept it there for many years. Health is the most important priority of every person, but it is only about twelfth on the list of priorities of every government.

The promise of health care free at the point of delivery will generate an enormous vote from the people but at the same time it will generate unlimited demand. The Government is then faced with funding it from a limited budget. An unlimited demand and a limited budget just cannot meet. They diverge. As demand increases and the money gets spent the Government finds itself in more and more trouble. The only way it can rectify the situation is to restrict services. That is what has been happening in Australia today and that is why Senator Reid was able to relate a litany of the real horror stories which abound in the community today.

As costs go up and restrictions increase we wind up with dissatisfied patients, doctors, nurses, therapists and administrators. That is the swamp we have shambled into. Health services in Australia today are worst in the Australian Capital Territory. We are seeing doctors strikes, nurses strikes, staff strikes, all of which were unheard of before the medical profession started to negotiate with governments.

Health care in the States is in an equally bad way except, as I say, for Queensland. The Government is directing doctors as to which tablets they can prescribe for which diseases, how many tablets they can prescribe, how many repeats they can prescribe, what conditions they can put people in hospital for, and how long they can keep them in hospital. We are talking about the Government's patients. The Government is controlling the situation by the benefits it pays to patients. There is no need for the Government to be involved. The Government is involved in paying. Once a third party operates between patients and doctors, therapists or any member of the medical services, we wind up with the dreadful distortions we are seeing in health care today.

The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill is putting up the cost of medical services to the people in the country. Services are becoming progressively restricted. I do not know of anywhere in Australia where people are happy with the health care services they are receiving and the costs they are paying for them. This Bill entrenches the increase in the Medicare levy and removes the ceiling on what people have to pay. There is no encouragement for people to take out private medical insurance-in fact, quite the opposite. Attendance at hospitals has been distorted. Medical education is being interfered with in no small way, something that will be bad for the country. There is a lack of development in the new areas of technology in general practice, technology which would help patients immeasurably and make their access to care easier, quicker and more satisfying. The whole health care establishment is going the wrong way.

Previously, under private medical insurance the movement of patients was from their homes to hostels, nursing homes and hospitals. Now the Government has decided that that is the more expensive way to fund medical care and so has turned it around, altering the insurance rebates. So the flow of patients is now out of the hospitals, into nursing homes and hostels and back into the patients' homes. Not that I disagree with that. All I disagree with is that the Government has put us through those hoops for all these years at such a great cost. I express my disappointment. I hope that after many years of predicting what would happen the Government will learn its lesson and reduce its role in the provision of curative medical services and concentrate on the areas where it really belongs, that is, medical education and research and preventive medicine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a particular aspect of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 which has been raised by a constituent, a solicitor from the Victorian town of Swan Hill, Mr Richard Dwyer. Mr Dwyer's concern is with clauses 42 and 43 of the amending Bill which deal with section 14zka of the Taxation Administration Act. I will find it necessary to quote extensively from Mr Dwyer's letter to me, which I think is probably better than simply incorporating the letter. As I say, Mr Dwyer's concern is with the amendments to section 14zka of the principal Act. He claims that the amendments proposed would retrospectively give power to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation to take legal action outside the statutes of limitation to recover additional or penalty tax on income tax under section 207 of the Income Tax Assessment Act where he presently does not have that power.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Dwyer points out that, following a 1986 Queensland Supreme Court case called Jonrich, section 14zka of the Taxation Administration Act was enacted to extend the time allowed to the Commissioner to institute legal proceedings for the recovery of primary tax. Mr Dwyer points out that he has no argument with that philosophy as it relates to primary income tax. Mr Dwyer said:

But Section 14zka specifically did not extend the time for proceedings for the recovery of additional or penalty tax payable under section 207. The Court decisions clearly held that period to be two years from when the primary tax was due and payable under the Commissioner's assessment and the 1986 amendments did not alter that legal position.

In introducing this amending Bill in the House of Representatives on 23rd September, 1987 the Minister assisting the Treasurer said the earlier ``modification'' was necessary-and by implication therefore this present ``modification'' is also necessary-``to counter abuses of the objection and appeal processes by those persons who sought to defer payment of taxes as long as possible and to then rely on the Limitations Laws to avoid payment of the taxes altogether''.

Mr Dwyer is pointing out that that is fair comment as far as the primary tax is concerned, but his concern is with regard to the additional or penalty tax. He points out that the comments of the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Holding) show an appalling lack of knowledge of the objection system, to use Mr Dwyer's words, `as it has been manipulated, not by the taxpayer but by the Commissioner of Taxation'. Mr Dwyer then goes on in his letter to me to give the example of his own case where assessments going back as far as five years have been made. He gives the examples in his letter to me and then says:
For all those periods ranging from 2 years and 5 months to 5 years and 3 months the Commissioner took away my rights to have my objections to his assessment considered within our legal system.

And in each case when the Commissioner finally ruled on my objections and I then requested him to refer the objections to Boards of Review he took until 28th February 1986-a further delay on his part of 2 years and 4 months-to do so. Still to this date my objections have not been heard by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, through absolutely no fault of mine nor from any manipulation whatsoever of the system by me.
There is a very old saying in the Law ``Justice delayed is justice denied''.

I think Mr Dwyer makes out a fair case with regard to many of the objections and problems that people have in getting their taxes assessed and their appeals dealt with. I come now to the problem Mr Dwyer alleges in relation to retrospectivity. He states:

Now as the law stands today the Commissioner, if he has not chosen to do so-and he has not in my case until he issued Supreme Court proceedings against me on the 12th June, 1987-sue successfully in the Courts for recovery of additional tax in relation to any of those years, as all are well and truly statute barred-the first being 9 years old. That clearly is the law as it stood on the 12th June, 1987 and as it stands today.
Yet this proposed amending legislation will it seems, change that law retrospectively and enable the Commissioner to sue me for additional tax going back for all of those nine years.
Such retrospectivity-in relation to additional or penalty tax as distinct from primary tax is absolutely obnoxious and offends against all fairness and justice.
If any fairness or justice is to prevail in the taxation system:
(a) Why did the Commissioner not rule upon my objections within a reasonable time-is 5 years and 3 months reasonable?
(b) Why did the Commissioner not refer my requests for Boards of Review hearings within a reason- able time-is 2 years and 4 months reasonable?
(c) Why did the Commissioner wait till June 1987 to sue for what he claims was due in 1978, 1979, 1980, 1981 and 1982?.

Mr Dwyer has his arguments with the Commissioner of Taxation and, no doubt, in due course they will be dealt with by the judicial system. My concern is this problem of whether this section creates a change of law retrospectivity in relation to the collection of penalty tax. The Opposition had a look at this and found it a very difficult question to answer. Of course, our problem is that we do not have the departmental expertise that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his officers have. Ultimately, I went to the Treasurer's office and spoke to one of his staff, who apparently sought some additional departmental advice. I have now received a response from the Treasurer dated 29 October 1987 and I seek leave to incorporate that response in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Treasurer
Parliament House
Canberra 2600
Senator A. Lewis
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator

I refer to your representations of 26 October 1987 on behalf of Mr Richard J. Dwyer LL.B of Dwyer Bennett and Mahon, Barristers and Solicitors of Swan Hill, Victoria concerning amendments to section 14zka of the Taxation Administration Act that are included in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 at present being debated in the Senate.

Section 14zka was enacted in 1986 to overcome the decision of the Full Court of the Queensland Supreme Court in the case of D. C. of T v Moorebank Pty Ltd. The decision is at present on appeal to the High Court. The Moorebank decision overturned an established principle that State or Territory limitation laws did not apply to the recovery of taxation debts.

Section 14zka sought to extend the period under which action may be commenced under various State and Territory limitation laws to recover outstanding taxes and penalties. It was intended that this extension apply in relation to additional tax for late payment but for the lesser period that the limitation laws generally provide for the recovery of penalties. This would mean that action for recovery of additional tax for late payment could be commenced up to a date after the resolution of any dispute relating to primary tax depending on the period provided by the relevant State or Territory law for recovery of penalties. However, a technical argument has been put forward to the effect that section 14zka does not achieve this result in relation to additional tax for late payment. The amendments now proposed will do no more than clarify the intended operation.

If the limitation periods specified by State and Territory limitation laws were not extended in the case of additional tax for late payment, there would be a clear incentive for taxpayers to continue to abuse the objection and appeal processes in the knowledge that, although the primary tax may be outstanding for several years, payment of the additional tax could be enforced in respect of only 2 years, with the effect that they have the use of interest free funds for a substantial period at the expense of the revenue.

Additional tax for late payment will not, of course, be payable in the event that the taxpayer's objection or appeal against the primary tax is upheld. Accordingly, the clarifying amendments can only have application to statutory additional tax that accrues in respect of taxes that are found to be correctly payable. The amendments do no more than ensure that a taxpayer with a tax debt statutorily imposed by existing laws for the late payment of primary tax will not escape payment on a legal technicality. The same result will be achieved if the Moorebank appeal is decided in the Commissioner's favour. The amendments clearly do not impose a retrospective tax liability. They merely restore to the Commissioner the right to recover additional tax for late payment on the same basis as was accepted to be available to him prior to the Moorebank decision.

Mr Dwyer proposes that where primary tax is paid before resolution of a dispute the Commissioner may commence legal action for recovery only within the relevant limitation period commencing on the date of payment of the primary tax.

Mr Dwyer's proposal would have the effect that the Commissioner would be obliged, in order to protect the revenue, to commence recovery of additional tax for late payment within that period notwithstanding that it may be some time before the dispute is resolved.

Agreement to the proposal would confer an unjustifiable benefit on taxpayers who may have entered into tax avoidance schemes and paid their primary tax rather than run the risk of a dispute being resolved in the Commissioner's favour and being exposed to additional tax for late payment at the rate of 20 per cent per annum (10 per cent per annum up to 14 February 1983).

The proposal would do nothing for taxpayers who, in consideration for payment of half the tax in dispute under arrangements entered into prior to 1983, were allowed to defer payment of the balance of disputed tax pending resolution of the matters in dispute. They may well have incurred additional tax for the late payment prior to entering into such arrangements and would be entitled to claim discrimination if they did not also get some relief if the amendment proposed by Mr Dwyer, against the background of his own circumstances, were to be adopted.

Mr Dwyer criticised the Taxation Office for the time taken to determine objections and refer decisions to the Tribunals or Courts. The Commissioner of Taxation, whose views I sought on this matter, advised that the delays must be viewed against the background of the volume of objections and appeals resulting from the tax avoidance scheme era of the late '70s and early '80s. In the early days the Commissioner's policy was to determine objections in representative cases with the view to obtaining decisions from the Boards of Review or Courts which would be acceptable to taxpayers with similar disputes. This meant that consideration of large numbers of objections was deferred pending Board or Court decisions in representative cases. In the event, appeals in many of the selected cases were abandoned by taxpayers at the last minute. Additionally, decisions in selected cases were frequently not accepted by taxpayers as applicable to the facts of their particular case. The present practice is to determine objections promptly and forward appeals against the Commissioner's decision to the Courts (or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal) as soon as possible.
I trust the above explanation will assist you in replying to Mr Dwyer.
Yours sincerely
P. J. KEATING

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again the Senate is debating the need for expenditure increases in the Government's Medicare policy that are way above the inflation rate. We all remember the gung ho days when the Australian Labor Party introduced Medicare. I wish to quote from Dr Blewett's news release at that time, because it is very interesting to go back to that period to see what this Government thought it would be able to introduce. Dr Blewett said:

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of Medicare is the biggest step ever taken by the Australian Government to ensure that every Australian has the best and cheapest medical and hospital care.

He went on to say that Medicare would be funded by a one per cent levy or tax contribution. He said that, from 1 February 1984, nine out of 10 Australian families would actually pay less, or at least no more, for their basic medical and health insurance. It sounds beaut; it sounds fine. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) changed that a little when he sent out to every taxpayer a letter in which, in very glowing terms, he said that Medicare was `a system which will lower our inflation rate by reducing the cost of living for most Australians'. Then he said, `Two out of three'-not nine out of ten-`families will pay less for the cover they now enjoy'. That was quite a considerable variation. As I have said, it all sounded too good to be true, and that has turned out to be the case. It was all too good to be true. It was all cosmetics and typical of the rhetoric that this Government is so very keen on.

Let us look at the claim by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). It is interesting to be reminded of what has occurred since the introduction of Medicare. There was to be a one per cent levy on taxable income. We all remember that there was to be a ceiling of $700 of a taxpayer's taxable income. There was to be a threshold for low income earners. Patients were to receive 85 per cent of the schedule fee for every medical service, with a maximum patient payment of $10-do honourable senators remember that?-for each item, with a total maximum gap payment of $150 per annum. Those figures applied if the doctor did not bulk bill. Of course, doctors were encouraged to bulk bill. Private medical insurance was to be abolished and there was to be so-called free treatment at public hospitals for in-patient and out-patient services if they were delivered by the hospital doctors. That is what was supposed to happen. But what has happened since then?

In July 1985 the $700 ceiling was abolished so that, no matter how high earnings may be, the levy remained at one per cent of taxable income. Of course, the levy has now been raised to well above that one per cent; it is now up to 1 1/4 per cent. The maximum patient payment was increased from $10 to $20-a greater increase than that in the rate of inflation. It did not rise with the rate of inflation; it went up by double that rate in August 1986. The pharmaceutical prescription fee increased from $4 to $5 in August 1985. Where are we now with the promised cheapest and best health care? It is no longer the cheapest and it is going up considerably.

This Government is completely unaware, lacks any understanding of and is not willing to consult with the medical profession. It goes in, boots and all, feet first, and then has to back off. General practitioners, who, I believe, have been insulted in an extremely cruel way, have been told that they overservice people at night. TALK.START.PARA: —Sir Richard Arthur Blackburn, a former Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory, died at the Woden Valley Hospital on 1 October 1987. He had a brilliant career and there are many people who mourn his passing. I wish to refer to some of the things that he did during his lifetime. At the time of his death he was 69 years of age. He was born in Adelaide in 1918 and his father was a distinguished soldier, Brigadier A. S. Blackburn. He attended St Peter's College in South Australia and the Adelaide University. He subsequently became a Rhodes Scholar in 1940, attended Magdalen College, Oxford, and was admitted to the Bar in London. His studies were interrupted during the Second World War when he served his country with great distinction. He subsequently maintained his interest in the Services and was the colonel of the regiment at the Adelaide University.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Richard had a distinguished career in all respects. After returning to Australia, he became the Bonython Professor of Law at Adelaide University in 1950 and I came to know him when I was a student of that faculty during the late 1950s. After he had held that position for some time, a position which many people might have thought a man would hold for the rest of his career, he left in 1957 and went into private practice. He was a barrister and solicitor of the Supreme Court of South Australia and an eminent member of one of the legal firms in Adelaide. He followed that path for the next 14 years.

Sir Richard then became a judge of the Northern Territory Supreme Court. I am aware, having known him well, how much he enjoyed the Northern Territory in every respect. I was talking earlier to Senator Tambling, a senator for the Northern Territory, who told me that Sir Richard was the founding president of the Arts Council of the Northern Territory and the founding president of the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation, which subsequently became a foundation totally run by Aboriginal people. He and Lady Blackburn had an aircraft with them during the time that they were in the Northern Territory. They visited just about every possible place and they certainly enjoyed their life there and loved the people they met.

In 1971 they came to Canberra and Sir Richard became a member of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court. He was a judge and then the Chief Judge of that court. In 1982 he became the Chief Justice of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court when the status of the court was changed.

Sir Richard was also closely associated with the Australian National University for some 11 years, for eight of which as Pro-Chancellor. He became Chancellor on the death of Sir John Crawford. Sir Richard resigned from the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory in 1985 because of ill health, but he retained his position as Chancellor of the university until the time of his death.

Many tributes have been paid to Sir Richard. The Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory held a special sitting and speeches were made about him at a meeting of the University Council. Articles have also been written. He will be revered in legal circles for a very long time. I think I can sum up his career by quoting the words of the Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University, Emeritus Professor Peter Karmel. He said:

My strong recollection of Dick Blackburn is of a person of scrupulous fairness and of a total commitment to the world of knowledge and the search for truth. Somewhat conservative in his personal views, he respected people for their contributions to academic life without regard to political and other considerations. He was in every sense an upright man and a true scholar. Sitting suspended from 12.50 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question of the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate follows my question of yesterday. Can he now confirm that the Government is supporting before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission a rise of $6.50 from 1 January? Can he further confirm that the Government's position has not changed, notwithstanding the current severe economic uncertainty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth has this morning started its submission to the Commission. We have submitted our support for a further increase under the first tier of $6.50 to apply as from 1 January 1988. This is the equivalent of a 1.5 per cent increase in average weekly ordinary time earnings of adults and is based on the current published Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates. We could not support the $7 claim presented by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which is a somewhat generous rounding up of the 1.5 per cent increase of its estimate of current earnings. Neither do we believe that a retrospective date of payment for the increase is appropriate.

ANSWER.PARA: In the period since the second tier wage system was introduced, the Commission's expectations for the wages system and its contribution to the task of economic adjustment have been, in our judgment, fulfilled. Support for that system has been forthcoming from both unions and employers. In terms of the amount and timing of a further first tier increase, we have adopted a position which we believe is economically sustainable, prudent in the current economic environment and industrially rational. This is in marked contrast to the Opposition which, consistent with its position in 18 out of the last 20 national wage cases, has stated that there should be no national wage increase whatsoever-which shows how little honourable senators opposite care for the living standards of workers or the industrial realities of the labour market.

—I ask the Minister: To what does he attribute this development in the exchange market unless it does derive from a large capital outflow? If so, does the Minister now agree that one of his critical tests that he stated has been satisfied and that corrective policy measures would therefore now seem to be required?

—I do not know-Senator Stone has given no indication that he knows and I do not believe anybody knows at this stage-what capital movements took place yesterday or even last week. It will be about four or six weeks, if not longer, before there are any official statistics on that. He asked me whether I attributed the developments in the stock market to capital movements. The answer is that I do not because I do not know what capital movements there were. Probably one could attribute them as accurately to animal spirits as to anything else.

—My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to this week's information which showed a very welcome decline in Australia's annual price inflation rate to 8.3 per cent. In view of the fact that for the past two quarters the consumer price index (CPI) has been below 2 per cent and that the December 1986 quarter consumer price index was 2.9 per cent, does the Government expect a further fall in the annual inflation rate in the year to December? What progress has been made by the Hawke Government in keeping down cost of living rises as measured by the consumer price index?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of the question, the Hawke Government made quite spectacular progress in getting the consumer price index, which is usually read as the inflation rate, down. When this Government came into office Australia's annual inflation rate was a staggering 11 1/2 per cent. By the middle of 1985 it had fallen to just over 5 per cent, that is, it was halved in a couple of years.
—Then you put it up again.

—That is true. I am not going to try to hide the facts the way Mr Howard succeeded in hiding them for a while, facts which Mr Stone, the then Secretary to the Treasury, wanted him to reveal in the week before the 1983 election. I refer in particular to the fact that we were facing an impending Budget deficit of nearly $10 billion. In the short term Mr Howard succeeded in hiding that fact which the then Mr Stone wanted to reveal but Mr Howard lost control of the situation in the following week. It is true that after the middle of 1985 the inflation rate moved up again. However, it was not caused, as many people on the ideological Right or the ratbag Right would have one believe, by wages blowing out. It was the consequence of the effect on import prices of the decline in the value of the Australian dollar which, in turn, was very substantially attributable to the decline in Australian export prices. In other words, the same factor which was driving up inflation in Australia was driving it down in some other countries and that common factor was the decline in commodity prices.

ANSWER.PARA: In more recent times, as Senator Maguire said, the annual inflation rate-that is defined as the September quarter rate compared with that of the September quarter of the previous year-has come down to 8.3 per cent. Given the size of the CPI increase in the December quarter of 1986, it is reasonable to expect-indeed I think one could count on it-a further significant fall in the annual rate for the year ending December 1987.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEFENCE PERSONNEL: TESTING FOR ACQUIRED IMMUNE DEFICIENCY SYNDROME

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I refer the Minister to the defence services policy on the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) and ask the following question: Have personnel in any of the three Services ever been tested for AIDS antibodies either with or without their knowledge? Have any positive results of such tests ever been passed on to non-medical authorities such as the person's commanding officer or to service police without the knowledge or consent of the individual or individuals concerned? Were such test results ever used by service police as a basis for questioning service personnel about their sexual contacts? Have any service personnel ever been discharged voluntarily or otherwise as a result of such questioning? Finally, does the Minister agree that, if any of these practices have occurred, they constitute a gross breach of privacy, and will he see that such practices are prohibited in future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that to the best of the knowledge of the Department of Defence no defence personnel have been tested for AIDS without their knowledge of such testing. However, it is conceivable that individual medical officers may have included AIDS testing amongst other tests for purely clinical purposes without the knowledge of such patients but we regard that as a most unlikely event and we do not think it has occurred. It is true that if positive testing occurs information is passed on to two different areas. The honourable senator asked whether that had been done without the knowledge of the person concerned. I have not yet been able to ascertain an answer to that part of her question. There are two areas to which such information would be passed. One would be the administrative management area which deals with the level to which a person is posted because of certain conditions. That is, if someone has a medical condition he may not be suitable to be posted to all areas in the defence forces. That is the first step. The second step is, as the honourable senator would know, if someone is AIDS positive some investigation is made as to the contacts that person has had in order to try to prevent the spread of the disease.
—By the service police?

—I am coming to that. The service police have carried out that role in the past. The honourable senator asked whether people have resigned from the service as a result of the activities of the service police. I am not able to say whether that is true. However, I can say that some personnel have voluntarily resigned, or elected to leave the service, having been identified as AIDS carriers.

ANSWER.PARA: The final point to the honourable senator's question-I think this is her final point; I did not write it down-was whether we will continue the practice of using the service police. We will certainly continue the practice of investigating further contacts made by AIDS carriers and at the moment that will be done by the service police. In view of the concerns the honourable senator has raised in regard to that matter, I will ask the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel whether she will consider a more appropriate method of carrying that out. I think the honourable senator would agree, though, that some attempt has to be made, if we are to contain this particular disease, to carry out further investigations once someone is found to be carrying the disease.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to a letter published in today's Australian Financial Review written by Mr John Hay, the national chairman of the Australian Free Enterprise Foundation, Brisbane? Is it true that Mr Hay, in that letter, recommends a number of fundamental changes to Australia's wage determination system? Does the Government intend to act on any of Mr Hay's recommendations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the more alarming features of the so-called New Right in Australia in general is its intellectual sloth. That is paraded in Mr Hay's letter in an obvious way-in fact it is so obvious that I would have thought that all the ideologues of the far right would have been able to pick it up. If I may digress for a moment, I was asked to speak in Perth just before the Budget was brought down in relation to a Budget essay competition conducted for some years by the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia, I think, for year 12 high school economics students. One of the entries recommended among other things that we should have a completely deregulated labour market and a 15 per cent cut in award wages. That fails to recognise that the two propositions are mutually exclusive. If you have a deregulated labour market, you do not have any award wages. Such right wing prejudices showed through to an alarming degree in all the essays. This same right wing prejudice in relation to wages also shows through in Mr Hay's letter.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Hay's letter contains an eight-point formula for overcoming our economic problems, the first of which states, `Deregulation of the wages market'. The seventh point says, `A minimum 44-hour week and a reduction in annual leave to three weeks'. If we really have a deregulated labour market, we do not have a minimum or maximum working week or any minimum or maximum leave period stipulated at all, as well as not having any wages stipulated. So what Mr Hay betrays as well as intellectual sloth-and again this is a lamentably common attribute of the ideological right-is a belief in certain nostrums regardless of what the evidence from the real world suggests about their validity. It assumes because of that that a deregulated labour market necessarily means a lower wages outcome. That was tried in Australia in 1981-82 when the Fraser-Howard Government walked away from any responsibility for a national wages policy, saying, `Let it be settled in the market place'. As a consequence, wages blew out by, I think, 13 per cent in 1981 and 14 per cent in 1982 because of the 11.5 per cent inflation rate subsequently inherited by this Government and caused by a wages blow-out. That was one flirtation Australia had with a government abandoning any responsibility for a national wages policy.

In the United Kingdom in spite of a high unemployment rate, above 10 per cent and ultimately rising above 13 per cent-and I think it has come down somewhat from 13 per cent since then but not because unemployment has fallen but because of creative accounting and changes in the definitions employed-real wages in the years following 1982 increased by about 5 per cent, I think, from mid-1983 to mid-1985. In Australia in that same period, with the wages accord working very well and with a government which accepted some responsibility for wages policy and worked to have a wages policy successfully implemented in spite of economic growth proceeding at a rate which was high by Australian standards and with unemployment falling to a significant extent, real wages fell by about 5 per cent.

In summary, there are two things. First, the arguments put in the letter are internally unsound and inconsistent to the point of mutual exclusivity. Secondly, the letter betrays again the simplistic and ideological belief of the far right that a wages outcome will necessarily be lower under a free market operation than it would be under a successful national wages policy such as Australia has had in the past few years. They continue to hold tenaciously to that belief regardless of the empirical evidence from all around the world which either calls it into question or flatly refutes it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware that the Commonwealth Banking Corporation annual report tabled yesterday shows a disastrous 40 per cent decline in after tax profit for the Commonwealth Bank despite a significant increase in earnings on overseas transactions and a 28 per cent profit fall for the Commonwealth Savings Bank which it blames principally on the 13.5 per cent housing loan ceiling? Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Banking Corporation has formally requested the Federal Government to provide it with dividend relief for the next two years which on present levels of profitability would amount to some $150m? In view of the extremely parlous state of the Australian economy and the Government's clear unwillingness or inability to expand the capital base of a number of public trading enterprises, what steps does the Government propose to take to enable the Commonwealth banks to compete more effectively with the private banks? Is the Government prepared to consider partial privatisation along the lines of the recent sale by the Bank of New Zealand of 13 per cent of its shares on a non-voting rights basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked whether I was aware of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation's annual report. The answer is no. In fact I must confess that I did not even know that it had been released. In relation to the question of its decline in profitability compared with the previous year, I will take Senator Alston's word on that-for the time being, anyway. I do not know how it compares with other trading banks, and I suspect that not all of them will have yet published their annual reports. However, the financial year 1985-86-and I think that is the financial year used by the Commonwealth Bank but I am not certain about the other trading banks-was a year of extraordinarily high profits. It is no great surprise that the Commonwealth Bank's profits have fallen from that level, any more than it would be surprising if the profits of other trading banks had fallen.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of equity capital, the Commonwealth Bank has approached the Government. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. A clerical industrial dispute in the Aviation Medicine Branch of the Department of Transport and Communications has affected the renewal of flying licences since 14 October. No new medical information is being put into files and no medical clearances will be given over the telephone. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sheil was kind enough to give me some advance notice of his question, and I have to hand advice in the following terms: ACOA members of the Aviation Medicine Branch have placed bans on the entering of results of medical assessments undertaken in the branch on to computer systems. I personally will monitor the situation in the light of its being brought to my attention, and will intervene at some appropriate stage if I feel that it would be helpful to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What economic indicators are available to assess the job prospects of the unemployed in the various States? What do these indicators show?

—The best indicator of job prospects as distinct from the level of unemployment, I think it would be generally agreed, is the ratio of job vacancies to the unemployed-a better indicator of job prospects than the absolute level of unemployment, because it provides a clear picture of the relative slackness of the different labour markets or the same labour market over a period. The September edition of the Australian Bulletin of Labour contains an up to date analysis of those ratios across the States. The highlights of that analysis are that the Australian average number of job applicants for unfilled vacancies is 12. The figure varies very considerably from State to State, and the spectacular State figure is that for Queensland, which has a ratio of 31:1 as against a national average of 12:1. A quick calculation is that, if Queensland were taken out of the rest of the country, the average in the other five States would fall to about 10. In Queensland it is 31. The next highest is Tasmania, with an unemployed to job vacancy ratio of 20. Returning to Queensland, the Bulletin of Labour notes that this vacancy to unemployment ratio for Queensland is the lowest it has been for some time, drawing attention to the fact that the employment prospects in Queensland are particularly gloomy, and have been for a very considerable time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. It follows the Minister's answer to a question asked earlier this week by Senator Knowles, when the Minister acknowledged that local government authorities would lose revenue because of the change to the quarterly system of payments. Does the Minister agree that most councils-I estimate 85 per cent-work on an overdraft basis in the first three months of the financial year because by then the previous year's funds have been used and new rates are not yet forthcoming? Does the Minister further agree that councils were further disadvantaged this year by the fact that the grants were paid later than usual? Finally, if the Government will not change the quarterly payment system, will it at least agree to paying the first instalment in July, even if it is an interim payment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Panizza for his question and I am pleased to hear that there is some interest in local government on the other side of this chamber. In answer to the question, I am afraid that I become very confused about the Opposition's stand on financial management. Senator Stone is always coming into this place and talking to us about how we have to have further economic restraints and cutbacks. He talks about a mini-Budget, yet half an hour later other honourable senators come into this place criticising the Government for taking responsible measures. I explained in a response to Senator Knowles earlier this week that the Government's stand in regard to quarterly payments was economically responsible. It is a stand that has been accepted by a majority of responsible local authorities throughout the country. If Senator Panizza cares to discuss this issue with a number of local authorities, he will find that they are aware of the need for economic restraint and are prepared to contribute to it.

ANSWER.PARA: The third part of Senator Panizza's question related to overdrafts and the regularity of payments. It is true that this year, and following the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, a new system of distribution throughout the country on a much more equitable basis, a needs basis, was introduced. As a result of this, and partly because we had a Federal election in the middle of the year, as I am sure honourable senators opposite recall, there were certainly delays this year because it was the first year of implementation.

I am pleased to advise Senator Panizza and all local authorities that in future payments will be made on a regular basis, because the new system will be in place. The payments will be made by the middle of August, again in November, again in February and again in May. I am sure from the words that I am getting back from local authorities that they accept that they have to act on a responsible basis. It is a pity that members of the Opposition have not decided whether they will back Senator Stone in regard to economic restraint and the number of policies he has always put forward, or whether they will continually attack this Government for sensible economic restraint and sensible measures to achieve this.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women and for the Bicentenary. I refer the Minister to the Heritage 200 program and ask whether she can tell the Senate on what basis the selection is to be made of the 200 Australians to be honoured by memorial plaques in the Parliamentary Triangle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Heritage 200 program is an initiative of the Australian Bicentennial Authority (ABA). Its purpose is to identify and honour 200 Australians who have made the most outstanding contributions to making Australia what it is today. Some 1,800 nominations were received. Nominations are being assessed by the Heritage 200 Committee, which is an independent body appointed by the ABA. ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that I have reassured honourable senators opposite with that last statement, and those who believe in equal opportunity will be reassured. The Committee's decision on the 200 program is proposed to be announced in May 1988 to coincide with the unveiling of the plaques. —I address my question to the Minister for Finance, as the Minister representing the Treasurer and as a farmer. Does he realise the uncertainty for rural taxpayers in the conversion or extension of grazing leases? Under a ruling from the Australian Taxation Office in Brisbane-which differs from rulings of the Tax Office in Canberra and Townsville-will such a taxpayer be subject to capital gains tax upon extension or conversion of such a lease, the original of which was initially granted prior to the commencement date for the capital gains tax on 19 September 1985? If such a conversion or extension is subject to capital gains tax, what basis for the cost price will be adopted by the Tax Office? Has the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy not admitted that this is an unintended consequence of the legislation, and when will this matter be remedied?

—I do not know about the alleged conflicting rulings that have been given by various deputy commissioners of taxation, but I have a note from the Treasurer's office. I understand that the lessees of these pastoral leases have a right or understanding that on or before the expiry of the lease that lease will be renewed. In the event of its not being renewed, compensation is payable to the lessee-in this case, by the Queensland Government, I expect. Comments have been made on that basis. In respect of the renewal of a pastoral lease granted or assigned to the lessee before 20 September 1985, there will be no capital gains tax liability at the time of the renewal of the lease. A later disposal of the lease, following renewal on or after 20 September 1985, may give rise to a capital gains tax liability, calculated on a cost base that includes the market value of the lease at the time of renewal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to inform the Senate that the Office of Local Government is working very closely with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and has prepared a draft regional plan for consultation with local government in regard to the proposed world Heritage area. That plan identifies possible alternative employment and enterprise creation opportunities in the area. I have discussed that draft regional plan with a number of councils. Thirteen of the 14 local councils came to Cairns to a meeting at which my colleague Senator Richardson and I spoke to them about the importance of local government involvement in discussions about the future of the area affected by World Heritage listing. Since that time officers of my Department have met with all local government authorities, regional organisations and Aboriginal communities in the proposed listing area. Information was obtained about possible future employment projects and development strategies for each local area in the short, medium and long term. The input of local councils and other community groups, as well as the advice of other Commonwealth agencies, will be incorporated into a revised regional plan which will be discussed with Senator Richardson.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that Senator Richardson would agree with me when I say that it is a great pity that the Queensland Government has not responded on the same basis as local authorities in the area. Local authorities have been very responsible and concerned to discuss the impact of World Heritage listing. That does not mean that they all agree with Senator Richardson and me. In fact, a number of them have indicated quite clearly that--

TALK.START.PARA: —None of them do.
—That is something that I think you should go and find out for yourself, Senator Boswell.
—I have been up there and I cannot find one person who agrees with you.

—It is strange that whenever anything positive is put forward from this side of the chamber we get this raucous behaviour from the likes of Senator Boswell. I would have thought that Senator Boswell, as a Queenslander-unlike his colleague Senator Stone-would have had some particular interest in this matter. Obviously, he is more committed to playing the larrikin than to listening and learning about the important plans that Senator Richardson and I have in regard to World Heritage listing affected areas. I take this opportunity to again remind the Queensland Government that it is a great pity that local councils have had to show the way in terms of co-operation, consultation and putting forward positive suggestions. The Queensland Government has so much to benefit from a reasonable approach to this issue.
—That is not the truth. That is why they are writing to me.

—I understand that my good friend Senator MacGibbon might be agreeing with me. That is unusual, but I welcome it. All I can say is that local authorities are responding very sensibly and favourably. Senator Richardson and I look forward to working with them and we still hold out some hope that eventually the Queensland Government-probably when it finds itself a new leader-will start to respond to Senator Richardson's initiatives.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I claim to have been misrepre- sented.
—Order! There is no point of order. You may claim to be misrepresented after Question Time.
—Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that only two international carriers other than Qantas Airways Ltd fly into Adelaide-and there are only 11 flights each week?
—You have been on every one!

—I have no vested interest in this question. In such circumstances will the Federal Government not support flights to Adelaide by Thai Airways International Ltd, the Malaysian Airline System and Nippon Airways?
—Are they the next three trips?
—This is actually very serious. With all the consequential benefits to the South Australian economy, what would be necessary to cause the Government to alter its currently obstructive attitude?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main thing that would be necessary is a rational and persuasive case being made out for further flights to Australia as a whole, as well as just to Adelaide, in the context of the current pattern of air service agreements which presently exist and which Australia will continue to negotiate on the basis of reciprocal advantage for the Australian carrier, Qantas. This is sometimes very difficult to achieve, particularly with some of the airlines that Senator Hill mentioned, which are only too happy to take advantage of Australian passengers flying into their particular headquarters locations around South East Asia and carrying them on to Europe without giving compensating advantages by way of access to our own carrier. These are always complex and difficult matters and there are rarely simple and obvious solutions to them.

ANSWER.PARA: The particular problem of Adelaide which has been brought to my attention is one about which I will have discussions with representatives of that city in the near future. By that time I will be in a position to give a more detailed answer. But I simply say that one of the problems that we face in Australia is that rather too many international gateway ports have been established around the continent in recent years to satisfy perfectly understandable local aspirations for direct air services. That makes it very difficult indeed, given the size of our aviation market, to get the kind of frequency into every one of those gateway ports that would be optimal or desirable for the local community.

I understand Senator Hill's concern, and that of a number of other people who bash my ear periodically about the lack of frequency into various others of the 11, I think it is, ports that exist around Australia, but there are practical limitations on the extent to which major increases in frequency can be achieved.

—Mr President, I seek an unreserved withdrawal.
—Senator Evans, will you withdraw?
—I withdraw. Having made that point, may I proceed to clarify the record--

—Christmas Island Casino Resort Pty Ltd has been advised that the Christmas Island aerodrome would require upgrading if it were to support frequent scheduled airline services by large jet aircraft, such as Boeing 727s, 737s, 767s, or Airbus A300s. The developer proposed to the Commonwealth that operations to the island resort be commenced using BAE146 aircraft, pending future airport upgrading. Scheduled passenger flights by these aircraft have been approved subject to certain safety and operational conditions. Operations by other similar aircraft into the Christmas Island aerodrome could also be approved. However, the BAE146, which has four engines, is not subject to over water route limitations which apply to competing twin-engine aircraft such as the F28.
