Regular weekly charter flights by B727 aircraft to the island have been permitted in the past because they have provided an essential transport link to that remote community. Higher frequency operations by these aircraft would not, however, be approved because the travel is not essential in the same way and because alternatives are available, namely, the use of smaller and appropriate over water aircraft like the BAE146 and also the option of upgrading the airport at the developer's expense.

I make it clear, in the light of the allegation which was made without any justification whatsoever in the House of Representatives the other night under cover of privilege and which has been the subject of further questions, I understand, in the other place today, that there is ample technical justification for the decision that has been made. It was made wholly on technical grounds without any reference to any other considerations. Those technical grounds are as I have described them. It is about time that Mr Aldred stopped perpetrating the practice he has made so manifest over the years of making allegations of this kind about sordid, corrupt connections, pay-offs and trade-offs. It is indefensible. It is inappropriate for anyone in parliamentary life to do this as a matter of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order--

He took the specific opportunity to continue talking over the taking of a point of order and to repeat that same practice. I ask that you direct that in future that conduct will not be tolerated in this chamber.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED MONORAIL: AYERS ROCK TO THE OLGAS

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill 1986 was referred to the parliamentary predecessor of this Committee, the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, on 13 May 1987. Both the 1986 Bill and the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee lapsed with the dissolution of Parliament on 5 June 1987.

On 15 September 1987 the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill 1986 was reintroduced, in a virtually identical form, as the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Bill 1987. The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Bill 1987 was eventually referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on 24 September 1987. At the time, Senator Alston, who moved the reference to this Committee, advised the Senate that the Committee would endeavour to report as a matter of urgency.

The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Bill 1987 is intended to make two primary changes to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. Firstly, the Bill would require the Federal Court to refuse to grant an application for review where the applicant possesses an alternative right to seek review unless `the interests of justice require that the Court should not refuse to grant the application'. Secondly, the Bill would place the onus upon any applicant with an alternative right to seek review to satisfy the Federal Court of Australia that `the interests of justice require that the Court should not refuse to grant the application'. In addition, the Bill would require that the Court should exercise this discretion to refuse to hear applications or to stay proceedings at the earliest possible opportunity or, in the Bill's terms, the earliest appropriate opportunity. These latter provisions are essentially statutory formulations of the existing law as it has been developed by the Federal Court.

The Committee has no quarrel with the requirement that the Court exercise its discretion to refuse an application for review or stay proceedings at the earliest appropriate opportunity. Accordingly, the Committee has endorsed proposed sub-sections 10a (2) and 10 (2a) as contained in the Bill. Proposed paragraphs 10 (2) (c) and 10 (2) (d) would apply to virtually every application for review lodged under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) (ADJR) Act. In reality, the requirement that the applicant possesses an alternative right of review is meaningless.

It must be remembered that section 75 of the Constitution entrenches the right to obtain remedies against actions by Commonwealth officials by vesting original jurisdiction in the High Court of Australia over, among other matters, matters in which a `writ of mandamus or prohibition or an injunction is sought against an officer of the Commonwealth'. These common law actions were not, and could not be, abolished by the ADJR Act. The object of that Act was, as it were, to simplify the means of obtaining review. In virtually all cases, a person who could seek review under the ADJR Act could, by way of alternative, initiate common law proceedings. This avenue, therefore, would fall within proposed paragraph 10 (2) (d) of the Bill. Consequently, virtually all applicants would have to satisfy the Court that the interests of justice required that it should not refuse to hear the application. In a sense, this would mean that applicants would have to obtain a type of de facto leave from the Court. The Committee objects to this.

The object of the Act is to provide simple remedies, and to streamline proceedings. As section 10 of the Act stands, the Court is able to dismiss applications where applicants have adequate alternative remedies. But the Court has interpreted this to mean that the application should be dismissed only when the respondent can satisfy the Court that it should dismiss the application. The Committee considers that this is the correct approach. We would have no objection to strengthening section 10 to require, as distinct from simply empowering, the Court to dismiss applications whenever the respondent satisfies the Court that the applicant has an adequate alternative remedy. But we emphasise that the onus should rest upon the respondent. It is unreasonable to require every applicant for review under the AD (JR) Act-the so-called simple method of obtaining judicial review-to satisfy the Court that it should hear his or her case. In many cases, it will be common ground between the parties that there is no need to consider whether the applications should be dismissed, notwithstanding the existence of an alternative remedy.

We recognise that it is possible to abuse the administrative review system, and to exploit the various avenues of review for purely tactical reasons. We in no way wish to endorse or encourage such conduct. We are sympathetic to the need to strengthen the AD (JR) Act against abuse. However, we have concluded that the allegations of abuse of the AD (JR) Act have been exaggerated. The Committee does not dispute that there are examples of abusive litigation. The court cases which arose out of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's inquiries into the grant of a third commercial television licence in Perth are frequently cited as evidence of such abuse. This litigation is discussed in chapter 3 of the report, where the Committee notes that not all of these cases were initiated under the AD (JR) Act, and in no case was there any attempt to have the action struck out as an abuse of process. Without casting aspersions upon any of the litigants involved in the disputes over the Perth licence, I refer to this litigation here to remind honourable senators that would-be litigants who might wish to delay or interfere with other processes are able to initiate action under the common law regardless of what so-called restrictions may be placed upon the AD (JR) Act.

In reality, one of the costs of a system in which natural justice is viewed as an entitlement is that some people will choose to abuse their rights by litigating for tactical reasons, such as to delay proceedings even where they have no hope of success. We have taken the view that it would be an over-reaction to blame the AD (JR) Act for this and to punish all applicants, however meritorious, by placing an additional hurdle in their way. Further, we think that it is important to note that such hurdles, even if imposed, are of little value in preventing abusive litigation. People who really want to hamper administrative action and are blocked from seeking review under the AD (JR) Act will simply resort to the common law to achieve the same end. And that is more expensive for all concerned.
In general, the Committee agrees with the assessment offered by the Administrative Law Committee of the Law Society of New South Wales that provisions such as are contained in the Bill are:

unlikely to have any practical impact on persons or corporations who are intent upon bringing judicial review proceedings for strategic purposes but are highly likely to penalise and discourage ordinary individuals who are genuinely aggrieved by Commonwealth administrative action and who at present have available to them a relatively simple, accessible and inexpensive means of challenging the legality of Commonwealth administrative action in the form of the AD (JR) Act.

The Committee's objections to proposed paragraphs 10 (2) (c) and (d) are less to the general object of the amendment than they are to the means by which the object will be achieved. In the Committee's view, enactment of restrictions of the type proposed is unlikely to reduce the `abusive' use of the AD (JR) Act and, in day to day operation, is likely to discriminate against financially disadvantaged applicants.

The Committee's recommendation, therefore, with Senator Stone in dissent, is that reverse onus provisions of the type contained in clause 2, proposed paragraphs 10 (2) (c) and 10 (2) (d) of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill 1987, not be enacted. However, in the Committee's view, placing the onus upon respondents and thus, as it were, formulating in legislative terms the existing common law would ensure that the Court has the means to dismiss summarily unmeritorious applications without unnecessarily disadvantaging applicants with justifiable applications. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly to the motion moved by Senator Bolkus in his capacity as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I am a new member of that Committee-in fact, the only member who did not serve on the former committee in the previous Parliament. Of course, for that reason, I have not had the advantage that other members of the Committee have had of having been present when evidence was given to members of the Committee at some considerable length on the matters referred to it under this reference. However, having done my best to assimilate the matter during my time on the Committee, I have chosen, as Senator Bolkus has indicated, to dissent from the majority view of the Committee on this matter, and would permit the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Bill to go forward in its original form.

SPEECH.PARA: I must confess that I have been influenced in that view by two considerations that I will mention briefly, apart, of course, from the issue in question itself. The first is that I have the feeling that in matters of administrative law there has grown up in Australia, and particularly in Canberra, I have to say, a somewhat too cosy enclave of persons interested in that subject. I use the term `interested' in both senses. The Administrative Review Council, for example, which has been one of the bodies instrumental in reviewing the question which was the subject of the Bill referred to the Committee, is a rather inbred body. In saying that, I do not wish to cast any aspersions whatsoever upon any member of that Council. They are all extremely upright, knowledgeable and proper people. Nevertheless, the Council does have a certain inbred quality.

I make that comment in a constructive sense because it appears to me that, if we are to have an Administrative Review Council, it ought really to be more representative-I use that word without putting too heavy an emphasis on it-of what one might call ordinary Australia, and not so clearly heavily weighted towards representation from groups and bodies and, in many cases, individuals who are part of the administrative law process. I am saying that it is often the case, and quite properly, that the Administrative Review Council is asked to give advice about questions such as those that were before the Committee on this occasion. One really has to wonder who is guarding the guardians on such occasions. I raise that as a genuine matter of concern, and I leave that point there.

My second observation from the papers that came before the Committee on this reference relates to the advice of the Attorney-General's Department. Again from my previous experience in this city, I had formed the view, which I do not think has been subjected to any basis for change in the interim, that the Attorney- General's Department, particularly that area of it responsible for these matters, had not generally been notable for taking any restrictive attitude towards the provision of avenues of appeal for litigants in the administrative law area or, indeed, in other areas. One might almost go so far as to say that that Department, and this area of it, has leant over backwards to provide as many avenues of appeal as possible in some cases. So, when I note advice from that Department which is in effect in support of the Bill, I am somewhat impressed by that aspect of the evidence before the Committee.

In short, I have taken the view, which I have done with due humility, given my relative inexperience on this Committee compared with that of my colleagues, that I should dissent from the otherwise collective judgment and, in effect, re-commend that the Government's Bill be accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words following what Senator Stone said. I think he has been a very good member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. He has contributed mightily. He is able in expressing his opinions and has no hesitation in doing so. But he is not the only new member of that Committee. Others include Senator Schacht, Senator Powell and Senator Giles. Just as Senator Stone is a very welcome member of the Committee, so are all those honourable senators. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone said that the Administrative Review Council was an inbred body. He said more ordinary Australians ought to be represented on it. I suppose that is the sort of thing we say no matter what body we are talking about, whether it is a committee of economists, psychologists or whatever. But that view is an ungenerous one, given the work that a body such as the Administrative Review Council does. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak briefly on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I think the recommendation of the Administrative Review Council was the genesis of the original Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Bill, but it was not the finishing point. The Bill went beyond the original recommendation. I do not want to get into the business of defending the Administrative Review Council. Indeed, I take on board some of Senator Stone's comments about the dangers that attach to specialist bodies advising on their own particular areas. They can very quickly become arcane groups which have views that are simply not able to be understood by the outside world. This is a fairly technical piece of legislation and therefore I think we need to look at it on its merits rather than simply consider how it came to be before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I say in passing that it would be my suspicion that the Attorney-General's Department did not have access to the range of submissions before the Committee. I think we all started out with some apprehension, given the range of applications that emanated for a third television licence in Perth. But when I delved into the matter a little further my concerns were assuaged considerably, because it seems on close examination that what emanated from all of those 17 applications over a three-year period was a considerable tightening up of the practice and procedures of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Although it was a contest between megalitigants who had no compunction at all about hauling themselves and their opponents off to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) and the Federal Court of Australia at every conceivable opportunity, I think the end result was that they themselves bore the burden of costs and rendered a public service, perhaps unintentionally, in defining some of those procedural areas. To then propose legislation based on what is in a sense a collective single instance seems to me to be a dangerous approach. Therefore, when one considers that this legislation is only tinkering at the edges, it becomes really a gallant attempt, and no more, to try to limit the rights of access of applicants to the AAT in respect of judicial review of administrative decisions.

Having read Senator Stone's dissenting report, I wish to mention the second half of that report, in which he expresses some concern about the vagueness of language and the difficulties that would confront those with the onus of proof in satisfying the Tribunal that these matters could not be dealt with elsewhere. That is a very valid comment, and I do not think it needs to be taken in isolation, because there are a number of other undesirable aspects to the Bill that will have the end result of making it much more uncertain and difficult terrain for applicants who do not have unlimited access to funds and might therefore be dissuaded from taking actions to assert their rights. It seems to me that at the end of the day-as Senator Bolkus outlined-if the Act were simply to require that a matter be dismissed when the respondent had established that an applicant had alternative remedies, there would be little difficulty. But to reverse the onus, and to put an applicant through a very uncertain number and quantity of hoops, seems to me just to make the area even more complex and not provide a more satisfactory solution. What is proposed here may have started out on the right track, but ultimately it does no more than confuse the area and simply puts another difficulty in the way of those seeking remedies and, of course, it does not take away the right of anyone to approach the High Court of Australia under its original jurisdiction, or indeed the Federal Court under the Judiciary Act. Whilst that is the case, it can ultimately have no binding effect, because it will simply mean that, if a litigant is dissuaded from approaching the AAT in this manner, that litigant will go elsewhere, and the people who are likely to be able to afford elsewhere are the very people that perhaps provided the original basis for the Bill.

This legislation is not going to catch those players-and I do not accept that they are guilty of any tactical or other offence, although I think all of us would recognise that applicants at all levels and in all jurisdictions very frequently use litigation for the purpose of tactical delay. That is not a practice that should be encouraged, and I think it is generally discouraged by the courts by orders of costs-and to the extent that interest can be paid at commercial rates, there should be very real disincentives to ensure that tactical opportunities are not taken at the expense of substantive issues. But I do not regard this particular provision as doing much to remedy that abuse. All it will do is unnecessarily complicate an already very complex area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I would ask the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) whether the Government is seeking advice from the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) about the need for including the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) on its schedule of notifiable diseases. As I understood it, the NHMRC supplies a list of recommendations which the States either accept or reject. Some of the diseases are notifiable by all States. All States have accepted on the schedule the following: anthrax, brucellosis, diphtheria, gonorrhoea, hepatitis A, hepatitis B, leprosy, malaria, poliomyelitis, syphilis, tetanus, typhus, cholera, smallpox, yellow fever, and so on. As the Senate would know, many of those diseases are treatable and, while the NHMRC still recommends that they be compulsorily notifiable diseases, the States have seen fit to continue to include them on their lists.

Because AIDS has not been added to the list, we have a situation where various States have made their own decisions. We have a hotchpotch of notification, not the national approach that I think would be more appropriate. All Australians have been made well aware that AIDS is a fatal disease and is highly contagious via a person's bloodstream. If the NHMRC is sincere in its fight against this dreaded disease-and I do not doubt that for one second-I believe that it must include it on its schedule. I wonder about the reason for this lack of action by the Council. Perhaps it considers that it is best done in some other way. I know that the Council presently receives notification from the various States, but it seems extraordinary to me that the Council has not seen fit to make the recommendation on its schedule. It makes me wonder whether the Council is seeking the views of the Government before taking action. If it is, I would be concerned because I believe that the Council should be acting in an entirely independent fashion. This paper is the annual report of the Australian National University. I want to use the time available to me to say something about this great institution-sadly, an institution at present without a chancellor. Honourable senators will have heard Senator Margaret Reid at lunch time saying something about Sir Richard Blackburn, who died recently, and in due course the university will select a new chancellor. It is a very fine university. It is unique in this country, partly because half the university consists of the Institute of Advanced Studies, the other half being a normal university with faculties and undergraduate students. It is the most eminent university in Australia in terms of the honours which have been heaped upon its academic staff and in terms of the eminence in which they are held. It is a university with innovative management practices.

I draw to the attention of honourable senators the practice which has now been introduced in the Institute of Advanced Studies at the university of taking from each school one per cent of its budget each year and reallocating that money. The schools themselves may get back the money, but it is then reallocated on the basis of competitive bidding from within the Institute. This represents an effort to open up certain administrative practices and the option of new funding even within a fixed budget allocation. But in the year ahead the university faces a further one per cent real cut in its available resources, and this is on top of the real cuts in resources which it has taken already. This is coupled with a requirement placed on Australian universities and colleges of advanced education to take in more students, to extend the places and opportunities available and to do so with fewer resources-fewer resources per institution in some cases. I suggest that there is a limit to the extent to which universities, in seeking to accommodate the Government's wishes, can do this-the extent to which they can extend their intakes of students with diminishing real term allocations of resources, the money they need to operate.

The Government has to understand that whatever benefits there may be in economic terms from reducing the resources and allocations to an institution such as the Australian National University, there are also associated costs. These costs have to be understood. Costs may occur first of all in the teaching program itself, because the only way in which a university can carry out these functions in the end is by altering class sizes, staff-student ratios and so on. But there are likely to be real costs in terms of the educational mission of the institution-the mission that it performs on behalf of all Australians and on behalf of this society. Whatever the economic purposes of the university and whatever the economic functions of education may be, they are not the most important or the total functions of a university in Australia. There are functions which relate to liberal education, to the achievement of liberalising influences in our society which do not have immediate economic returns and which cannot be measured in economic returns.

How are we to regard the teaching of Italian renaissance literature in Australia if we are to apply purely economic judgments? When a government says that it wants universities to be more economically aware, what is it saying? Is it saying that the teaching of some languages is to be devalued because there is no immediate economic return or that the teaching of Italian renaissance literature is to be devalued? I accept the relationship between economic functions and some kinds of learning, but they are not the only functions. Those of us who serve on the Council of this university, representing this Senate, share the concerns of our fellow members of the Council that the Government is asking too much. We will make the efficiency gains; we are already doing so. But there comes a time when this university can do so no longer. On behalf of all Australian universities, I ask the Government and the Ministers in the Government to understand the pressure under which they are placing Australian higher education.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITTEE TO REVIEW AUSTRALIAN STUDIES IN TERTIARY EDUCATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

At a time when debate about education is notable for the very heavy use-as Senator Peter Baume has already said-of economic jargon about productivity and efficiency, competitiveness and responses to market forces, it is certainly refreshing to receive the report of the Committee to Review Australian Studies in Tertiary Education. Honourable senators should read it because it puts the whole debate about education policy in a much broader and, I think, a far richer context. Donald Horne wrote about this report when it was released. He said that we needed to encourage the habit of looking for Australian answers to Australian problems. Part of our economic failing is due to the fact that we, as a culture, have not encouraged creativity. We have not been innovative because we do not have a sufficient sense of the richness of our own society and culture. We have often followed slavishly the leads of other countries. The recommendations of this report would certainly help the debate on the education system at the tertiary level that we need for Australia now and in the ensuing years.

I want to raise a couple of points in the very short time that I have. When the report was released-and I note that it was released around the time of the election-the then Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, said that specific recommendations would be taken up in this year's Budget deliberations. The outcome of those particular deliberations is not at all clear-except that the Government probably has decided not to accept anything. As far as I am aware, there was no direct reference to the report's recommendations in any public statement made by the Government at the time of the Budget or even subsequent to that. So I am afraid that this excellent report seems to have gone the way of a number of excellent reports that have been presented to this Government-they have simply been put on a shelf. Since this is a rather attractive report, perhaps the thought is that it will look good sitting on a shelf rather than being implemented.

Obviously there are a very large number of matters in this report. I cannot canvass them all but I would like to raise one in particular. This relates to recommendation No. 29, which deals with the situation of a tertiary institution seeking to fill an academic post. The recommendation relates to bringing academic appointments into line with entrance requirements in other areas of employment. Fairly obviously, this is an area for a fair amount of debate in the academic community, and we need to go carefully in this regard. While I accept wholeheartedly the need for Australian solutions to Australian problems, here we are talking about a richness; we are not talking about parochialism. We need to be careful that we do not seek to cut off the Australian academic scene from that international body of knowledge and practice. We need a balance in this matter.

I am very much aware that Australian academic positions in certain areas have been put under enormous pressure because of the tightening of education budgets in other countries. Hence, often when an academic position is advertised there may be a small number of Australians applying and a very large number of eminently qualified overseas applicants. That puts tertiary institutions under a great deal of pressure. I believe that these things can be handled with some sensitivity to the fact that we obviously need a reasonable Australian development. We need Australian perspective in all our areas of study and, at the same time, we need to make sure that, if there is the possibility of getting hold of an eminently qualified overseas specialist in some area, we should look very closely at accepting such a person so that our students can have the very best. I realise that the report canvasses those types of qualifications. I thought the matter was worth while raising because I know that it is an area that has caused a great deal of concern. Hopefully, it is an area where continuing debate may eventually arrive at a more satisfactory solution than the one we have at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

This report to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) will be historic, since it will be the last report of the Curriculum Development Council, presuming that the Government continues with its announced plans for the abolition of the Council. It is somewhat ironic, as those senators who have been here for some time will remember, that during the Fraser Administration there was an attempt to get rid of this Council and the Senate majority-then comprising the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats-resisted that. So the Curriculum Development Commission, as it was at that stage, continued in a somewhat limbo existence producing money from its publications but, in fact, not having a budgetary allocation. When the Labor Party was re-elected to office, the then Minister, with much fanfare, acknowledged that we were about to have back the Curriculum Development Council. It has now been killed off and we do not really know what is going to replace it.

The present Minister, Mr Dawkins, has outlined a number of recommendations in a number of publications. These included The Challenge for Higher Education in Australia and the Budget-related paper Skills for Australia. The Government is probably pursuing the most fundamental change to the Commonwealth's participation in education since the days of the Whitlam Government. Undoubtedly, we will have a number of debates on this. I am sure Senator Peter Baume, who has recently spoken about the Australian National University annual report, will be prominent in those debates as he has been in the past, as will a number of other senators.

I am concerned about this because the work of the Curriculum Development Council has been very well received, not only here but also overseas. It has developed a number of curriculum materials and has undertaken a number of studies that have received international recognition. It is one of the few bodies established by the Commonwealth which actually produces resources from the sale of its publications. When one looks at those one notes that the Council has done very well for a body which is seeking to address the very problems that the Government now says we need more research into. It seems odd in that way to be looking at the Council's abolition, particularly, because it will be replaced by this overarching National Board of Employment, Education and Training. I am not at all sure that this overarching board necessarily will have the attention to detail or be able to call on the good will and expertise that the Curriculum Development Council has been able to call on.

I warn the Government that, if it feels it is able simply to wave a wand and elicit the good will of the education community for these innumerable changes that have taken place, that is not necessarily the case. There are many in the education community who object to the chopping and changing that the previous Government and now this Government have engaged in. The education community committed itself, for example, to the participation and equity program, which was supposed to be the very cornerstone of the Government's education policy, and then found in the next Budget that the program was reduced by half and in the following Budget abolished. The Government actually took out the program that two years previously it had called the cornerstone of its education policy. If that is not a cynical use of the people in the education community, who put a great deal of effort into developing programs and who in many cases reoriented their whole careers to take account of the Government's announcement, I do not know what is. Surely it was reasonable for them to have done so on the basis of the Government's announcement that the participation and equity program was the very cornerstone of the Government's education policy and to have thought that that would last at least for longer than two years. I have a number of other concerns I would like to raise but, unfortunately, time precludes me from doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

The annual report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission is, again, historic because it is the Commission's last report. Surely this must be of concern to the Australian Labor Party if it has any heart. Let me quote Mr Whitlam, the Prime Minister who established the Schools Commission. In his book, The Whitlam Government, he described his Government's education policies as `designed to widen the educational options of all children and ensure that parental income and attitudes placed no restrictions upon the educational opportunities of any child'. Mr Whitlam said that the transformation of education in Australia was the most enduring single achievement of his Government. Certainly, no Government senator has chosen to stand up here and talk about the achievements of the Commission. The extraordinary report of the Karmel Interim Committee for the Australian Schools Commission probably for the first time directed the minds of Australians to the need for across the board allocations so that every child in Australia, no matter whether that child be in private or in State schools, lived in the country or in the city, came from a high socio-economic background or had very poor, unemployed parents, would be given an equal opportunity to develop his talents and skills for the betterment of this country.

Rather than produce reports which stood outside governmental service and criticised fearlessly the Government, pointing to the needs which had not yet been fulfilled, it became the Government's handmaiden.

We all know that every government is constrained by economic structures, that governments are not able to meet what we may consider to be the optimum situation. But at least there should be some voice in the community saying, `This is the optimum situation'. We are then able to judge the Government's ability to meet its demands against that criterion. That makes for good education debate. It may not be what any government, any executive, would want, but at least it makes for a rigorous education debate in the wider community. We can see how far short we have fallen from what we hoped we might be able to do.

As I say, the Schools Commission was circumscribed by this Government. Eventually its reports became nothing more than one might expect from a government department. A government department is different from a commission. The job of a government department is to carry out the policy directives of the Executive, to give advice to the Executive as to how those policies might be carried out, to warn the Executive that some policy decisions may not be in the best interests of the country. If, at the end of the day, the Executive insists, the department's job is to seek the best ways to carry those policies out. A commission's job is not that. A commission's job is to report to the public on the needs and requirements of the education system.

Unfortunately, the Schools Commission is to be replaced by a board which will not even bother reporting openly to the Parliament or to the public. For the first time since 1972 when the Whitlam Government established the Schools Commission and the other commissions we are about to disappear behind closed doors in this area. It is one of the most retrograde steps we have ever taken in any important area of debate in this country. I hope that the Government will see the error of its ways before it establishes the proposed board and will allow its reports at least to be made public so that we can have a general, open and public debate, rather than seek to cover this area in the mysterious corridors of bureaucracy and government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC) is another historic report in that it is the last report of the Commission, which is about to be abolished. Under the Government's proposed advisory structure, the advisory role carried out to date by the Tertiary Education Commission will be carried out by a higher education council which will give a secret report to a national board of employment, education and training, which, in turn will give a secret report to the Minister. Hence, another source of vital information in the general education debate will be taken away from us. The Government and the Executive may feel that this is fine, but I think it should be deplored by the Parliament. The Parliament has been able to rely on these reports for a critical assessment of how we are doing in the tertiary education area, an area which is so vital to the economic health of Australia.

The higher education council will not have any real capacity to undertake research on its own cognisance. It will be a department operation. No longer will the higher education institutions-the universities, and the colleges of advanced education, the institutes of technology and, now, the universities of technology-have an opportunity to make known, openly and fearlessly, their requirements as they perceive developments in education. Whilst received with some misgivings by universities and other higher education bodies, the Tertiary Education Commission has proved to be a very useful device.

The Acting Chairman of the Australia Vice-Chancellors Committee, Professor Brian Wilson of the University of Queensland, describes the `substantial in-house capacity' of CTEC as it now stands to `gather and evaluate information about universities and colleges'. He says that this is one of its great strengths. Unfortunately, that capacity is to be taken away. We do not know what will replace it but undoubtedly whatever does replace it is likely to be an in-house operation, although not in-house to the universities and colleges of advanced education but in-house to the Executive. The Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University, Professor Peter Karmel, has remarked that there are conflicting tendencies in the movement undertaken by the present Government with regard to higher education policies. He was reported in an article which appeared in the Australian on 17 October as saying:
The concern about efficiency and effectiveness-
in higher education-
has resulted in two opposite manifestations: First a wish to rationalise and co-ordinate by fiat, and second, a push towards deregulation and market orientation.

I wish to emphasise the first manifestation, `a wish to rationalise and co-ordinate by fiat'. The Executive has done what all executives tend to do, that is, abolish organisations which stand apart from government, which make a critical assessment and give dependent information, making a direct decision without reference to anybody else.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
