SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) records its agreement with the view expressed on behalf of the Government by the Minister for Industrial Relations, the Honourable Ralph Willis, MP, that `it is quite fundamental to our prospects of economic recovery that we keep increases in our labour costs broadly in line with those of our international trading competitors. Not to do so would jettison the great opportunities provided by the very large devaluation of the Australian dollar and place us in dire economic peril'.
(b) notes that increases in our labour costs will, on the Government's own predictions, be substantially in excess of those of our trading competitors; and

(c) expresses its disappointment at the Government's failure to understand that the decision to proceed with the national wage case on 28 October 1987 will contribute to the worsening of the problem the Minister has identified.

The Opposition is bringing this motion forward for debate today on a day when the wages case is proceeding with the approval of the Government. We do so knowing that, at this stage, it is too late to influence the Government's decision, taken presumably over the last week, to proceed with this case. But we wish to proceed with the motion, nonetheless, because this is an area which is of fundamental importance to the economic management of Australia. We believe that the decision which has been taken by the Government is very wrong and we believe that it is important that our view should be on the record at this time.

The sad fact for the wage and salary earners in Australia is that across the board money increases of this sort which are not based on productivity increases and on a real capacity to pay, will not produce better real wages for the working men and women of Australia and that is not just the Opposition's view. The reality is that, over recent years, whilst this Government has supported a succession of wage rises, the real wages of the workers of Australia have declined because the rate of inflation has been higher than the rate of wage increases and the wage increases themselves have contributed to that inflation.

The reality is that our real wealth has been diminishing and, as a result, our real wages have been diminishing. There is no escaping the fact that if we wish to have a higher standard of living and if we wish the work force of Australia to have higher real wages-and that is what an increased standard of living requires-that can only occur if there is increased production of real wealth in Australia. The failure of the Government to achieve that is one of the signal failures of recent times.

The Commonwealth gave a very early indication of what attitude it was going to adopt with respect to the wage increase that is now being considered as long ago as last February. The wage case was being argued last February. The argument which gave rise to the decision was made in March this year. In the record of that case the Commonwealth indicated:

In the Commonwealth's view, the prospects for the viability of the system would be best ensured-in terms of both initial commitment and ongoing compliance with its requirements-if the Commission were to determine in this case a second increase under the first tier, to apply from a prospective date in 1988.

In English, that means that in February this year the Government was arguing that it was likely that there would need to be a further across the board increase in wages which would take place some time in 1988. We were told in the Senate and in the House of Representatives today that the Government is supporting the increase at the earliest possible date consistent with that statement-an increase on 1 January 1988. Senator Gareth Evans in this place, in a rather oblique way, and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in the House of Representatives in a much more direct way have both confirmed that, notwithstanding the very significant economic changes which have occurred since February this year, there has effectively been no change in the Government's position with respect to that wage rise.

That is a rather startling fact. In our view, it is a very odd response for the Government that, notwithstanding the changes that have occurred, it sees no need to revise an attitude which it adopted in February this year. The purpose of this debate is to demonstrate why, in the Opposition's view, that obduracy on the part of the Government is wrong and it stands condemned out of its own Minister's mouth. Just a week ago it was common ground between the Government and the Opposition that changed circumstances had made the continuance of the wage case a matter which had to be reconsidered. Only seven or eight days ago counsel appeared before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on behalf of the Commonwealth, instructed by this Government, and said:
The dramatic instability in world stock exchanges, driven primarily by the slump in share values in the United States has created a very uncertain economic and financial environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened since that time?
—Senator Stone interjects and asks me, `What has happened since that time?'. I think the only fair answer to that question is that things have become even more uncertain.
—A great deal more instability.

—There has been a great deal more instability. Since Mr Merkel made that submission on the instructions of the Commonwealth Government, there has been a further decline in the stock market, a further period of uncertainty, a weakening of the Australian dollar and our concerns are far greater today than they were even a week ago.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very serious matter which goes to the future economic management of this country and to its welfare. For that reason I want to emphasise what appeared to me to be the clear admissions on the part of the Government itself: the case which the Opposition has been putting forward since the last Budget has been strengthened by the recent occurrences in the share market. We face a period of very considerable uncertainty which makes the automatic granting of wage rises to the whole of the Australian work force an exercise in economic folly. On 23 October, less than a week ago, the Hon. Ralph Willis, who is the Minister responsible for the conduct of the wage case on behalf of the Government, made it quite clear in an interview on radio in the Australian Capital Territory that very significant difficulties are emerging for Australia because of what has occurred on the international scene. I quote in part from that interview where Mr Willis said that what has happened on the stock exchanges has unknown ramifications for the real economy. Mr Willis, quite properly I believe, was unable to say precisely what the ramifications would be, but he was prepared to go on to say what some of the flow-on effects on the Australian economy might be. He said:

For instance, if there was a big crash in confidence in share markets that could flow on to commodity markets which could mean changes in our terms of trade, a further reduction in our terms of trade, effects on our exchange rate, on interest rates, on investor confidence, on capital flow, on consumer confidence, I mean the whole array of effects could be very considerable . . .

Again, I emphasise the fact that that is not a statement from a supporter of the Opposition. That is not a statement from some columnist or journalist. It is not a statement from some critic of the Government. It is a statement from a senior Minister of the Government who was a long-standing servant of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). I adopt his words, because I agree with them, as expressing much of the uncertainty that now faces Australia in these very difficult times.

Until a week ago it was common ground between the Government and the Opposition that there should be an adjournment of the case and that Australia faced a situation of very considerable uncertainty and risk. If anything, as Senator Stone's interjection pointed out, the situation has worsened since then. The American dollar has declined internationally, and at the same time the Australian dollar has declined against the American dollar. In other words, the apparent weakness here in Australia is greater than the apparent weakness of other countries facing similar difficulties. A little later I will talk about the comparative decline in the stock exchange, because Australia has shown a far greater decline than almost any other country. We are in a situation of developing and continuing uncertainty. What the Opposition seeks from the Government is a sober, reasonable and responsible response to the situation that Australia faces. We believe that it is vitally important that the Government should set itself to minimise the damage which the changed economic circumstances can work on Australia and to better equip Australia to deal with the difficulties that lie ahead.

It is perhaps worth noting in this context that, even without the recent shocks, it was the view of the Opposition that there was room for very great concern about the economic settings established by the Government. We took the view that, in the circumstances that faced Australia-circumstances of growing international debt, continuing massive balance of payments deficits, continuing low investment and so on-Australia was already at risk before the international problems emerged over the last couple of weeks. We were totally in agreement with the words of Mr Willis, who addressed the ACTU Congress before the shocks to the stock exchange and who used the words which we have used in our motion. Mr Willis said:

It is quite fundamental to our prospects for economic recovery that we keep increases in our labour costs broadly in line with those of our international trading competitors. Not to do so would jettison the great opportunities provided by the very large devaluation of the $A and place us in dire economic peril.

Again, I emphasise that those words-words such as `dire economic peril'-were uttered prior to the shocks which have affected us over recent weeks. I stress those comments by Mr Willis because I want to emphasise that there is no partisan bias in the assessment which the Opposition has made in this place, in the House of Representatives and in our public statements elsewhere. The reality is that it is clear that Ministers such as Willis and Walsh share the assessments and the concerns which have been expressed by the Opposition. The odd situation that we face is that the Government is apparently not prepared to act on those concerns.

I think any fair and objective observer would be deeply puzzled by the failure of the Government to act this week in the way that it acted last week. The Government has in no way publicly changed the assessment that was made last week. It has simply said, `We will proceed with the national wage case'. The reason for that is quite clearly that the Government does not see itself as being able to carry the trade union movement. It does not see itself as being able to withstand the bullying of the trade union movement on this issue. I think the Government's assessment is wrong. The reality is that in a time of crisis the nation will respond and the work force will respond. The Government has grossly underestimated the good faith of the Australian work force and its readiness to face up to action that will prevent Australia from facing increases in unemployment, higher inflation, reductions in real wages through that and the very many other negative circumstances which can flow from wage rises that cannot be afforded.

This time of crisis is in fact a time of opportunity. It is craven on the part of the Government to be lying down in front of the threats of people such as Mr MacBean, who told us that any delay of the wage case would see a rash of industrial action by unions bypassing the Arbitration Commission to seek pay rises direct from employers. That was a reported threat from Mr MacBean on the 23rd of this month. The day before, Mr Crean is reported as saying:

It would be ``an extremely dangerous situation'' if it was suggested on the basis of one day's trading on the stock exchange that a wages policy which had worked effectively for four years should be changed.

We have had a lot more than one day's trading on the stock exchange now. We have now had some weeks of perilous trading. I believe that, if the Government was prepared to exercise the leadership that it was elected to show, it would be able to carry the Creans and the MacBeans of this world in the same way as, during a time of very considerable peril for Australia in the international recession in 1982-83, the then fairly unpopular Government of Malcolm Fraser, which was just a few months short of defeat, was able to carry the idea of a wage freeze. The reality is that circumstances provide an opportunity. The real tragedy for Australia is that the Government has not shown enough courage to grab the opportunity that has been offered to it.

I emphasise that the Opposition is not arguing for a wages freeze. It may well be that, when the full assessment of the circumstances facing Australia is possible in a few months time, that sort of action is what we will be required to advocate. But what we are saying is that there should be no interference with genuine second tier negotiations. I remind the Senate that, at the moment, under the national wage case principles, the work force is entitled to negotiate wage increases of up to 4 per cent on the basis of genuine improvements in productivity obtained through changes in work practices and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —How genuine are many of them?

—In this debate I may not have time to deal with that in detail, but I hope to come back to it. There is clear evidence that in some sections of the metal industry there have been some genuine attempts to come to grips with productivity increases that would warrant a wage increase. In the building industry there is one appalling example of the 4 per cent being used as something of a rort. I will not develop that at this stage; I may have time to come back to it. The important point I wish to make at this moment is that what we are saying is that a wage rise of the sort which is now before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which is in no way based on an assessment that there is an increase in productivity or capacity to pay for that wage rise, is a thoroughly destructive and dangerous thing to be undertaking at a time of very considerable uncertainty.

SPEECH.PARA: They are our concerns, and our view is that the urging of postponement of that case was the clear and simple duty of the Government. That clear and simple duty has been totally ignored by it. It has caved in in a quite craven way to the views which have been expressed by the trade union movement. I wish to pick up a little more on the point which was again raised by interjection by Senator Stone. Of course, there are a number of elements in the second tier wage negotiations about which we are very greatly concerned. But we are also concerned that other rises have been obtained by the trade union movement using its industrial muscle. The building industry is the classic example. It is likely to get rises this year of about 16 per cent-a 4 per cent first tier rise, a 4 per cent second tier rise, a 3 per cent superannuation increase and 5 per cent severance pay. I mention that in the context of Mr Willis saying that we should have wage rises comparable with those of our trading partners. They demonstrate the extent to which this Government is prepared to sell out on the principle which was expounded so clearly by Mr Willis when the trade union uses its muscle on the employers and on the Government. All of this is happening in circumstances where, since 9 October, just a few weeks ago, the Australian dollar has again devalued by about 6 per cent against the yen and the pound, and by approximately 3 to 4 per cent against the United States dollar. All of this peculiar attitude towards the capacity of our economy to pay increased wages is occurring in those circumstances.

I mentioned earlier in my speech that the decline in stock market prices was more significant in Australia than has occurred in most comparable markets. For example, in a table published today showing the declines which have been measured since Friday, 16 October, we see that there has been a 32 per cent reduction on the Sydney Stock Exchange, as against a reduction of just under 16 per cent in Tokyo. We find in London a 28 per cent reduction and in New York a 20 per cent reduction. So the decline in Australia is worse than the decline elsewhere. Who could imagine, who could even vaguely suggest, that the United States, Japan or the United Kingdom would be currently considering an across the board wage increase in today's circumstances? That thought is enough to de-monstrate the cloud-cuckoo-land approach which is being adopted by the Government in this matter. It knows and every member of the Australian work force knows that in no other country would this sort of approach be adopted. It is a peculiarly Australian syndrome for a system to believe, as apparently the Arbitration Commission is ready to believe and as the Government here is prepared to believe, that at a time of such critical difficulty across the board wage rises can be afforded.

One of the elements of our motion today is that increases in Australian labour costs will, on the Government's own predictions, be substantially in excess of those of our trading competitors. I wish to turn to that to justify that assertion. If we look at the Government's own papers, and at the figures published by the Government as part of the Budget, we find that in 1986-87 our nominal unit labour costs increased by 7 1/2 per cent, and this compares with an average of around 3 per cent for our major trading partners. This year nominal unit labour costs will grow, according to the Budget, at about 6 per cent, which is still double the rate expected for our trading competitors. Although that is a very slight improvement on last year's performance, it is nowhere near enough. I remind the Senate that Mr Willis said there must be movement broadly in line with our trading partners. We have movements of something like twice the rate of our trading partners.

The poor unit labour cost performance reflects the fact that wages have been growing too far ahead of productivity. In 1986-87 national productivity actually fell. For 1987-88 the Budget Papers forecast that there would be only a negligible improvement in productivity, and this is in spite of the promised genuine productivity offsets under the second tier of the wages system. Again I am reminded of Senator Stone's interjection. It is very odd that the process of the second tier wage negotiations is not producing, according to the Government's own figures, the productivity increases that one ought to find if that is a genuine exercise.

The only way that we can improve this woeful productivity performance is by increasing investment and by ensuring a more flexible approach to wage determination and industrial relations in general. We must restrain nominal wage growth. If we have wage increases which continually outstrip productivity, that will increase our unit labour costs and exacerbate our rate of inflation. That means that workers' living standards and those of the unemployed will be eroded.

This speech is not about how to reduce the living standards of Australians. What the Opposition is putting forward is that there is a genuine way of increasing the living standards of the working men and women of Australia, and this Government is ignoring the real means which are available to it to provide the higher living standards which are certainly the objective of the Opposition and, one would imagine, the objective of both the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. In the limited time which remains, I wish to refer to those means which are available to us to do something about increasing wealth in this country and paying the workers of Australia more, instead of less, as has occurred under this Government. I do not want to talk in fancy, theoretical terms. The production of wealth is a fairly straight forward matter and is clearly comprehended by people who work for a living. Let me cite one of the really high profile examples of the changes that can be affected, namely, the Robe River mine in Western Australia, which was the subject of a quite bitter dispute with the trade union movement, and yet a classic example of how we can increase the production of wealth in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what was the attitude of the Government to that experience?

—The attitude of the Government of course was to regard the whole thing as a disgrace, whereas I think the figures show that the attitude in opposing change is what is truly disgraceful. The simple fact is that when Peko-Wallsend Ltd took over the Robe River mine last year, production was running at 840 tonnes of iron ore per month, averaged out over the company's total work force. That is a fairly simple way of indicating what that company was producing. For every man and woman it employed, it produced 840 tonnes of ore for each month of production. What has been the effect of the changes in work practices which were wrung out of an unwilling trade union movement at that mine? The changes are quite remarkable, because the figures which I was able to obtain on recent production are that productivity has risen to 1,714 tonnes per month. There is an increase from 840 tonnes to 1,714 tonnes per month. That is an increase in productivity, not of 5 or 10 per cent, but of 103 per cent. That is the path to increased wealth-productivity increases. That is the path to increased real wages in this country. And that is not an isolated example.

SPEECH.PARA: In this chamber we have a number of members of the Government Party who have been members of the trade union movement. I would say to them that I have yet to meet anyone in the construction industry who does not believe that we could double productivity if we had a sensible approach to working on commercial sites in this country. I have yet to meet anyone engaged in that industry who would deny that productivity could be doubled. That is what this Government should be talking about before the Arbitration Commission. It should be talking about the production of greater real wealth which will sustain real wage rises for the working men and women of Australia. All that would be required in that major industry would be the simple reform that people do a fair day's work for a fair day's pay. It would require no fancy economic theory; it would simply require an honest day's work for an honest day's pay. That is what we should be talking about in Australia today, because the removal of absurd work practices and the pursuit of higher productivity on the part of both management and labour is the essential change that we must pursue. Any discussion on wages policy in this country which ignores that fact is a discussion based on nothing-it is a nonsense.

What we are seeking to promote, whether by the promotion of employee share ownership or by the promotion of the abolition of absurd work practices, is a higher level of productivity. I hope that it is not only retired trade unionists who will be prepared to acknowledge the importance of profitability and the importance of incentive in obtaining productivity gains and higher real wages. I do not have time to quote, as I had hoped to do, what was said by Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon in his paper to the Economic Planning Advisory Council in February 1986. Basically Mr Fitzgibbon argued that significant productivity gains can be achieved if employees are provided with real involvement in the viability of their enterprises by way of incentives and awards which encourage productivity. The Opposition has offered the Government a perfectly sound policy on employee share ownership which could be one of the contributing factors towards achieving higher productivity in this country. I want to see some sign that the Government is prepared to pick up some of these initiatives and to try to get a more productive economy and culture.

Even before the crash of the stock market, Australia had major ongoing problems. According to the Government's own Budget figures, we had the promise of even greater foreign debt, with a $11 1/2 billion trade deficit predicted by Mr Keating. We have and had higher inflation than our trading partners. We have higher interest rates than our trading partners. We have low investment in new industry in Australia-and that has continued year after year under this Government. We have high nominal wage rises which deliver declining--

TALK.START.PARA: —How was it under Malcolm Fraser's Government?

—It was very much higher. The Minister at the table who interjects should look at the private investment figures and see the enormous decline since this Government came into power. We have a Government which is delivering declining real wages to the work force of Australia and which on its own figures delivered no productivity growth this year and expects to deliver low or no productivity growth next year. That is the reality on which the real wages received by the Australian work force will be based. The Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia want higher real wages for the Australian work force. They know that will come only through increased productivity of the work force and increased investment.
—Be honest!

—The sort of caterwauling of the ex-union apparatchiks who helped destroy this country will not remove the truth. The truth is that unless the Government pursues higher productivity the real wages in this country will continue to decline. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney's proposition now before us on the question of wages and the general balance of labour costs deserves close scrutiny. The average unit labour cost in Australia is much lower than it was when Mr Howard was Treasurer. I would like to point out also that many more people are employed now than when Mr Howard was dismissed by the voters. It is obvious that any significant increases in unit labour costs will affect those industries to which export markets are an essential component. Products that originate in Australia can find overseas markets provided only that they are priced competitively compared with other products on the market.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has abundant supplies of raw materials and consequently has the edge on many of its overseas competitors. The supply of raw materials being both abundant and close at hand can in many instances constitute a comparative advantage to Australian producers. The costs of manufacturing depend not only on the provision of raw materials, though, but also on the labour and other costs necessary for production. Consequently, the statement on this matter by Mr Willis, the Minister for Industrial Relations, sums up the position very well. He said:

It is quite fundamental to our prospects of economic recovery that we keep increases in our labour costs broadly in tune with those of our international trading competitors. Not to do so would jettison the very great opportunities provided by the very large devaluation of the Australian dollar and place us in dire economic peril.

I believe that our fundamental trading position demands that the costs of labour be contained. A breakout of average weekly earnings significantly above the levels of our trading partners must adversely affect the role of Australian goods on overseas markets. Naturally, these goods may be present on overseas markets only if the costs of production are contained and the finished price therefore competitive. Consequently, any cost blowout will cause a further depreciation in the Australian currency and a decline in product sales.

The world will not keep paying the same rate in other currencies for the Australian dollar if our inflation rate is greater than those of our principal trading partners. On this point I believe the Government and the Opposition are on similar ground. The point of departure is that this Government understands, and has practised, effective means of cost containment and has not advocated the sorts of policies favoured by the Opposition which would lead to massive cost blowouts. Members of the Opposition have regularly talked in this place and in the community about the need to deregulate the labour market. The chief target of their policies has been centralised wage fixation, and they seem to believe that collective bargaining will result in wage levels that reflect a company's ability to pay. The best illustration of this philosophy is what happened in 1981. The then Fraser-Howard Government started talking of the resources boom and effectively lifted the lid on wages. Indeed, quite a few collective bargains were made and the general result was a wages explosion of 13.1 per cent. When this figure is compared with the consumer price index (CPI) figure for 1981 of 11.3 per cent we see that in one year there was an increase in the level of real wages of nearly 2 per cent.

When that Government realised the folly of all this it clamped on a wages freeze. What that meant, of course, was that where labour unions were strong and alert pay rises were soon obtained and in other areas workers were left behind. Naturally, the wage freeze froze those levels of inequality. I would also like to point out that these wage increases bore no resemblance to a company's ability to pay. Such rises were obtained by the law of the industrial jungle.

When this Government came to power in 1983 the inflation rate was around 11 per cent and so was the rate of unemployment. The growth of wages was nearly two percentage points higher still in the previous year-so honourable senators opposite should know all about cost blowouts and the effect they have on our overseas markets. After all, they presided over the last major blowout and they experienced the results of it at first hand.

The Government has supported the concept of centralised wage fixation. Under that system the rate of wage movements since March 1983 has been 32.4 per cent and the CPI has recorded 34 per cent in the same period. This means, of course, that a fall in wages of 1.6 per cent has taken place. Since 1986 the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions have put in place a more complex version of centralised wage fixation. The two-tier system is a response to the need to have wage fixation determined in the large part by an industry's ability to pay. This is achieved by the granting of a first tier rise with a second tier to be granted on productivity offsets. The maturity of the trade union movement in accepting and advocating this system is to be commended. The union movement and the Government both understand that wages must broadly follow productivity in order for us to continue to be competitive both on the Australian domestic market against imported goods and also on the international market against other goods.

In the current national wage case the Opposition is desperate to try to exploit the nervousness created by the stock market fall over the last 10 days. The current wage fixation method has the virtues of a national wage fixation system-which is the only way to contain costs-as well as those of a system which recognises the fundamentals of productivity in wage determination. The recent problems on the stock market as yet appear not to be over. However, the impact of the drop in share values has yet to be determined. A fall in productive investment may indeed follow but it needs to be remembered that the current value of stocks on the market is that of early 1986. The market has inflated greatly since that time, in fact since 1984. The value of stocks has risen to a level that is hard to sustain given the price to earning potential or the PEP. However, one thing is certain. The very foundations of the financial market would shake if they thought that there was any serious chance that the Opposition would succeed in getting the Commonwealth to adopt the policy of collective bargaining or a rerun of 1981.

Opposition members have been described as doom and gloom merchants. The recent spate of books which talk about the end of the financial world as we know it are probably widely read in Opposition ranks. The Opposition seems to perk up every time some crisis emerges. It is, though, largely consistent. It generally opposes pay rises when times are good and when they are bad. The story of the little boy who cried wolf once too often is particularly apt. The financial market sees Opposition policies as generally unworkable and proposed with a degree of financial and industrial incompetency.

Of course, the Opposition does not oppose every single pay rise. It is quite happy to see the Australian Capital Territory doctors get massive pay increases and it seems unable to understand why this Government has refused to grant such a rise. The real curse during the Fraser years was not only the blowout of wage rates. On that basis the Fraser-Howard Government was not successful either, but it was keeping a massively overvalued dollar that really spelled disaster.

Since 1983 Australia has experienced a massive decline in commodity pricing. The resultant decline in Australian currency has been a boon to Australian manufacturing industry. The Australian dollar has dropped since March 1983 from 222 to 98 yen and from US95c to US68c. Australia can now build up overseas markets that once were not open because of uncompetitive pricing. This Government cannot and will not abrogate its responsibilities and end centralised wage fixation. To do so would almost certainly lead to enormous cost blowouts which would destroy the competitive advantage Australia now currently enjoys. Consequently, the Government will continue to support the present wage fixing system as the only viable alternative.

The creation of around 800,000 jobs since March 1983 and the successful fight against inflation which has seen the CPI drop dramatically have come about because of some semblance of order in wage fixing. The Government will naturally continue with the system that so dramatically brought an end to the double digit inflation and double digit unemployment of the last year of the Fraser-Howard Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In attempting to bring even-handedness and open-mindedness to our consideration of this motion the Australian Democrats are striving for realism and in the next few minutes I hope to do something towards getting to the realities of this motion. We favour less politicking; we believe that that is in everybody's interests. We see this motion as an attempt to focus on the relationship between competitiveness and wage restraint. We see it being essentially a political motion and therefore we will be opposing it.

SPEECH.PARA: The major thrust of the motion suggests that to increase wages is to threaten our international competitiveness. The Australian Democrats see this as being a simplistic observation and we reject it as being simplistic. Of course we acknowledge the fact that, in essence, employers tend to see things this way. Clearly, however, our international competitiveness is dependent upon much more than our labour costs. I would like to take a moment or two to put things in perspective.

If we were to see our competitiveness purely and simply in terms of wage levels in this country we would see the Filipinos as being in a much more competitive situation than we are because their wages are dramatically lower than ours. We would all hesitate to identify with the proposition that Australian workers should, in terms of our wage levels, be in the same position as Filipino workers. Quite obviously much more than that is inherent in our international competitiveness. Clearly there is an element relating to the quality of the products which come from our labour effort. I cite the classic of the Mercedes car which for decades has been an expensive item but which is internationally renowned as being a most successful product.

There are many historical reasons why Australia now finds itself in a relatively less competitive situation than we might desire. This situation in the 1980s reflects years of protectionism. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in his recent visit to the United States, must have been embarrassed by our history in this regard. He urged the world's leading trading nation to abandon its position of protectionism when our history essentially shows that we have been rigorously protective. Historically we have relied heavily on primary produce and in that regard we are relatively disadvantaged.

We envisaged that the 1980s would be the period of the mineral resource boom but that did not come to fruition. So, once again, we are finding ourselves relatively disadvantaged. Because of this history we lack the sorts of manufacturing skills which would allow us to be as competitive as we would like. In other words we are disadvantaged by our history. These factors must be taken into account if we are to analyse realistically our present circumstances. It would be more meaningful for us to see our competitive position as being a composite of wages and exchange rates. I cite the Treasury's analysis and the Treasury index, the tool that has been created by the Treasury for us to analyse more realistically our competitive situation. The Treasury has compiled, and frequently publishes, statistics that hopefully allow us to analyse a more realistic composite of labour costs acknowledging exchange rate variations and changes. I cite statistics from the Treasury publication Round-up, which uses an index of unit labour costs and prices adjusted for exchange rate changes. It makes a comparison, in its recent issue, of our relative competitiveness from 1969 through to mid-1987. It is interesting to make the observation that we have become more competitive, rather than less competitive, in recent years.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because the exchange rate goes down.

—That is precisely the point I am making. When we take into account the second component-namely exchange rates-and we put that in composite with the labour cost unit, Australia is not as uncompetitive as we are occasionally led to believe and as the thrust of this motion would have us believe.
—Why don't you let the dollar go down to zero?

—No, that would be quite unrealistic. The honourable senator is asking me to adopt an unrealistic and stupid attitude. In fact, I am trying to encourage the honourable senator to adopt a much more realistic and insightful attitude than this motion asks. Even if we did as Senator Messner asks and rejected this rather meaningful index and looked at another index laid before us by the Treasury-in other words, the indices of average real labour costs-we would see that Australia is more competitive now than it was in, say, 1981-82 under the Fraser Government. If we look in simple terms at the index that I have cited, in 1981-82 the base would have been 118.7. In March 1985 it had dropped, and therefore we had become more competitive, to 109.8. In September 1986 it had dropped to 78.1, which suggests that at that time we were vastly more competitive than we had been in 1981-82. This indicates a dramatic improvement in our competitiveness, yet this motion asks us to accept the fact that somehow or other we are an endangered species and we should identify with the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I was fascinated this morning to see on the Today program George Negus interview former Prime Minister Fraser. The significance of the interview was that today an endorsed analysis of the Fraser era of government was released. In that interview Mr Fraser admitted that probably the greatest or major failure of his government-although he was reluctant to admit any failure by his Government-was the wages explosion and blowout in 1981-82. Therefore, I am puzzled by Senator Chaney's motion. It seems to me that in essence this motion admits and suggests that, having learnt a lesson from that wages blowout and explosion, the Opposition has done a 100 per cent turnaround. The only other interpretation one could make is that in essence it is a hypocritical motion that does little more than play politics. One can choose between only those two alternatives, if one accepts the admission by former Prime Minister Fraser this morning that a major failing of his Government was the wages blowout of 1981-82.

I turn now to the evidence of the past five years. Presumably, if we are to make any realistic judgment in 1987, we must do it in terms of recent evidence. If we are really attempting to look at reality, I do not believe that it is unreasonable for the Government to support a pay rise of $6.50 per week right now in 1987. Budget table No. 4 acknowledges that the Australian worker has incurred a considerable reduction in real wages over the past five years. In fact, there was the wages blowout that I referred to in 1981 through to the end of 1983 when there were increases in real wages of 3.6 per cent and 2.6 per cent. Since then there has been a steady reduction in real wages, if we take average weekly earnings converted to real terms. Almost year by year and quarter by quarter there have been reductions in real wages. It does not seem reasonable that the Australian worker should accept an indefinite continuation of that reduction. In fact, we suggest that there is evidence that the present Government has been much better able to reduce wages than its Liberal Government predecessor and, in fact, former Prime Minister Fraser admitted that this morning.

It is also true that in relation to the incidence of industrial disputation this Government has been more successful than its predecessor, and I refer here to the incidence of industrial disputation from 1976 through to 1987. Looking at it in terms of working days lost or working days lost per 1,000 employees, from 1976 through to 1982 there was a dramatic increase in the level of industrial disputation. In fact, from 1983 onwards there has been a considerable decrease. I am simply citing the fact that there has been a good deal more discipline, control and responsibility in the labour force in terms of its demands and expectations under this Government than was the case under the previous government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should compare South Australia with Queensland; that is a very interesting comparison.

—I am sure that a comparison State by State would bring out this simple fact and, in fairness, we must acknowledge this. All we are asking for in this debate is acknowledgment of reality. Restraint is also evident when we consider the more recent attitude towards wage fixation which suggests that under our two tiered system we should acknowledge movements in productivity. The system says that, if there has been a 4 per cent improvement in productivity, it is not unreasonable for those who have given rise to that improvement in productivity to make claims upon it. That is the mechanism that now applies. In terms of this mechanism great restraint has been shown by the work force and it is true that the majority of potential claimants has not recently made claims upon the percentage increase in productivity. So all we are doing is citing the fact that there has been obvious restraint by the work force, which reflects a relatively positive and co-operative industrial relations climate. The efforts of the present Government in this regard must be acknowledged if we are being fair, open-minded and even-handed.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to cite some inherent contradictions in the posture of the Opposition in the past two weeks. I am teased by the fact that Senator Chaney in addressing this motion in the chamber this afternoon has urged seriousness-and I think that is a responsible thing to do-and has urged that we adopt an extremely serious posture and attitude towards the stock market crash. Senator Chaney drew parallels with the Great Depression; he cited the possibility of an extremely serious recession and over and over again he used the word crisis. I must admit to being a modern day Keynesian in this respect and I would not be surprised to see a sudden return to Keynesianism in our economic thinking as we move into this crisis predicted by Senator Chaney. In hindsight, the lessons of the 1930s are that mild stimulation would have been the more appropriate action. In fact, for the first five or six years of the crisis of the late 1920s and the 1930s governments moved in the opposite direction. My colleague Senator Powell cited a recent article by Professor Kenneth Galbraith who has been acknowledged by both sides of the chamber in the past few days as an appropriate commentator--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—I am afraid it is, and the honourable senator will see that if he looks at Hansard. Professor Galbraith cited the fact that the policy of excessive restraint was inappropriate, and he drew our attention to the fact that, if we are moving into crisis and mild recession, a policy of mild and moderate stimulation might be quite appropriate. The mild and moderate stimulation sought in the case placed before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission today is in the order of 1.5 per cent. I think we would have to judge that to be a mild and moderate stimulation. If we are to accept the advice of Professor Galbraith and the economic lessons of history, we would not judge that to be irresponsible. When we align that with the obvious moderation, responsibility and restraint of the Australian worker over the last four years, I do not think it is an unreasonable expectation. Although this motion may suggest that the Opposition has learnt a lesson from its blowouts in wages in 1981-82, it does not seem to have learnt from the lessons of the thirties. I am teased by this apparent contradiction in the arguments that it has advanced in this chamber over the last ten days or so. So much for the inadequacies and contradictions that the Opposition has brought to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, wages have to do with much more than competitiveness. They have very much to do with relative standards of living. A wages system is also about equity and about how we distribute or redistribute wealth. As well, it is about how we control or affect the accumulation of wealth. I appear to have been very much on the side of the present Government in my previous comments. I would now like to become a little more critical of the Government. I acknowledge the fact that a great deal of restraint, discipline and responsibility has been apparent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yin and Yang.

—Yin and Yang, as my colleague observes. We have moved towards greater flexibility in wage settlement at the workplace level, and this system comes up for review in May of next year. The work force is becoming increasingly restive about the situation in which it is finding itself. It is saying that it has been restrained and responsible for some time. When the position comes up for review in May next year, I think that there is some danger of a potential breakout. I believe that when we look at the fact that 90 per cent of workers have since mid-last year received wage increases of less than $10 a week, but realise that during the same period there has been a 10 per cent increase in prices, which in reality means that there has been a $45 per week increase in their cost of living, we need to be careful that we do not expect excessive restraint. If that happens, we may find ourselves with a work force which asks why it should live with the consequences of the last ten days on the stock markets, which is probably a reasonable question for workers to put.

SPEECH.PARA: I now move to examine the Government's record in relation to wealth distribution or redistribution. In that regard the Government's record has been grossly inadequate. During the campaign the Australian Democrats constantly cited the degree to which the present Government has sold out Australia's disadvantaged and has favoured the rich and nouveau rich. We have seen a veritable explosion of millionaires, though many may have been cut down substantially in the last ten days. But the fact is that this Government has sold out disadvantaged Australians in favour of the new rich.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense.

—It is not nonsense. I shall proceed to cite the clear evidence of that. In this chamber on 11 May my colleague Senator Powell cited the evidence of the extraordinary explosion of poverty in this country in the last four or five years and quoted evidence from the National Institute of Economics and Industry Research which spelt out chapter and verse the fact that poverty has run riot in this country since the present Government sold out disadvantaged Australians in favour of the rich in our society. The tables of evidence are recorded in Hansard as Senator Powell elaborated on that argument. In fact, by any measures of poverty-and there are a number-the number of poverty stricken Australians has increased dramatically. It has increased to the stage where the present Government in its last campaign chose to make it a major issue and to grandstand on a policy whereby it pledged to do away with poverty among Australian children by 1990. We saw precisely the same Prime Minister standing in precisely the same place--
—What was wrong with that?

—It was fine, but it was just a grandstanding exercise which said that the Government's priority one for the next two years was to be poverty-an attack on the very poverty over which it has presided in the last four or five years. In doing so, the Government has abandoned its previous priority one which was, as will be recalled, to rectify unemployment among the youth of Australia. That was the Government's first priority in the previous 18 months. It is interesting to notice the manipulations in the context of a political campaign. Not only has the Government sold out disadvantaged Australians in terms of the creeping poverty that we have observed in the last four or five years, but this Government's so-called tax cuts of marginal tax rates from 60c to 49c in the dollar clearly advantaged the rich Australians as opposed to the disadvantaged Australians, the ones whom they are supposed to be representing.

SPEECH.PARA: During the campaign we cited the irony of the fact that the Government has sat back and presided over the negative gearing rort whereby the Bonds have been able to put together financial actions of $10m, have gobbled up our media systems and have written it off in a negative gearing formula which allows such people to right such sums off in their tax claims. We cited in the election campaign the fact that the present Government, once again favouring the rich, allows superannuation funds to be carried off-shore and invested overseas at a tax advantage, when the Australian economy would be well served by a policy which would force the investment of these vast sums of Australian's hard earned savings on this continent to generate wealth for Australians. Also in the campaign the Australian Democrats cited the simultaneous explosion of poverty and the ironical growth of the new rich under a Labor Government. The most neglected Australians under this Government are those who have shown the very wages constraint, discipline and responsibility which have enabled us to remain relatively competitive-and not uncompetitive, as Senator Chaney would have us believe.

What I have tried to do in this debate is to cite the realities. We believe that in this motion the Opposition is doing little more than playing crude politics. We believe that the motion ignores the realities of its own years and of its failure in that regard compared with the present Government. We believe that the Opposition is unfairly failing to acknowledge the responsibility of the Australian work force in recent years. We believe that the lesson of economics in what is appropriate reaction to the movements in the stock market casinos of the past ten days is mild stimulation of the economy. In fact, the most appropriate reaction is to sustain confidence and to say to the work force, `We acknowledge your responsibility, we have confidence in our economy'. To offer a mild stimulation of 1.5 per cent increase in wages is not irresponsible, but may be judged by any standards to be economically appropriate. Although we are disenchanted-indeed, disgusted-by the degree to which the Labor Government has sold out the growing mass of Australia's disadvantaged in favour of Australia's grossly rich, on balance we support the Government on this occasion and reject the motion of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking for the Government earlier in this debate, Senator Foreman raised the hoary old chestnut that Australian Labor Party parliamentarians have been raising for far more than half a decade now-that is, that in 1980-81 the Fraser Government adopted a free-market, collective bargaining approach to wages determination and that that had disastrous consequences for the wages explosion at that time.
—You don't disagree with that, surely.

—It is patent nonsense. In fact, it was not the small element of collective bargaining that was introduced at that time which caused the wages blowout; the blowout was caused by the flow-ons resulting from the mindless continuation of the concept of comparative wage justice, which was endorsed at that time by a weak Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That caused the wages explosion. Wage increases which may have been justified in some sectors of industry at that time automatically flowed through to other sectors where they could not be afforded and were not justified. Had we had a truly deregulated labour market at that time, those flow-ons simply would not have occurred. So let us lay to rest this nonsense we continually hear from the Labor Party that we had a free market for wages determination in 1980-81. I hope that that will also lay to rest similar comments that we heard from Senator McLean.

SPEECH.PARA: For the Australian economy to perform to its optimum and maximise economic growth for the benefit of all Australians, wages must reflect economic reality. That is the import of the statement by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) to which Senator Chaney referred in moving this motion. Our present wage structure does not reflect economic reality. In Budget Paper No. 2 the Government forecasts that the two-tier system of wage determination will run its full course. Thus, the Government is expecting most wage earners to get a 1.5 per cent increase from the first tier, a 4 per cent increase from the second tier plus an increase in relation to superannuation. Thus, overall average weekly earnings will increase by some 6.5 per cent. In terms of overall labour costs, this represents an increase of between 7 1/2 per cent and 8 per cent in the current financial year. This is double the increase that our major trading partners will experience. It follows a 7 1/2 per cent increase in wage costs in 1986-87, which compares with a 3 per cent increase for our major trading partners. So for two successive years we have had increases in labour costs which are double those of our major trading partners.

Meanwhile, in 1986-87 national productivity fell. Furthermore, the Budget Papers forecast that there will be negligible productivity improvement in this financial year. This is despite the supposed productivity offsets to accompany the 4 per cent second tier wage increases. Clearly, the wage restraint so far exercised has been insufficient when related to productivity. Comparative wage rates are already higher than those of our trading partners, but they will increase by twice the rate of those of our trading partners over the next 12 months. It should be noted that I am not making a wages comparison with low wage countries which our trade union leaders might be quick to condemn as using sweated labour. I am comparing our situation with countries with comparable standards of living-the United States of America, Japan, Britain and European countries. Our present wage levels and the rate of increase of those wages is way out of kilter with those countries. Even with our devalued currency it makes it difficult for Australian industry to compete on export markets or against imports.

Clearly, the rhetoric of the Minister for Industrial Relations concerning wage restraint is at odds with reality. The success which he claims has simply not been achieved. Honourable senators might ask why this is the case. It is because the Government has allowed wages determination to remain in the hands of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, instead of adopting a more market oriented system. In practice, this means that wage determination is in the hands of the most powerful unions. The combined effect of the excessive power of some unions and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission ensures a downwards rigidity in real wages. External adverse developments, such as declining commodity prices or collapsing share markets, and internal recession due to seasonal conditions or other factors, are not sufficiently reflected in an erosion of real wages. The Commission has a ratchet effect on both money and real wages. The gains which are made are protected, regardless of the state of the economy or of our competitiveness in world markets. The inability of the Commission to exercise any final authority and its pathetic and desperate attempt to maintain and extend its own role in the wage fixation and industrial relations system by cajoling the unions to co-operate in its pretence of authority has led to a widespread belief that industrial relations-far from being a new province of law and order-is a province for the exercise of arbitrary power and coercion.

Mr Justice Higgins's dream has come to a sorry end. As a result, the union movement in Australia considers itself-with some justification-to be beyond the law. It is organised so as to exercise monopoly control over labour markets and to prevent the settlement of disputes on a freely negotiated basis between employers and employees in a specific firm or group of firms. The union movement is determined to exercise a wider degree of control over the future of profitable investment, while making no commitment to the profitability of that investment, as we have seen in its production of Australia Reconstructed.

Reflected in information from the Department of Industrial Relations is the fact that the number of new industrial stoppages which commenced in the three months from May to July 1987 is 10 per cent higher than for the same period last year. It is a disastrous situation now when we consider that May to July last year was a period of unusually high disputes. This demonstrates that it is the industrial muscle of trade unions and not productivity improvement which is being used to obtain second tier 4 per cent wage increases.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about all the unrecorded disputes?

—That is right; we do not hear much about those at all. They add to the difficulties that we experience in the industrial relations environment. The Minister for Industrial Relations was living in fantasy land when he claimed on Monday, 26 October, that the Government was insisting on 100 per cent cost offsets in return for the 4 per cent rise under the second tier. Where was the 100 per cent cost offset when on the same day the railway workers in Victoria were awarded the 4 per cent second tier increase, despite only partial agreement by transport authorities and unions on the required trade-offs under the national wage guidelines? Negotiations between management and the two unions-the Australian Railways Union and the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union-resulted in little more than three-quarters of the $10.7m in offsets that were required to meet that 4 per cent increase. This was despite management having earlier lowered its request from $12m in trade-offs to that amount of $10.7m. Needless to say, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission succumbed to the industrial blackmail of the unions, as indicated in a statement by Commissioner Neyland. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not appropriate that I attempt to apportion blame for a totally unsatisfactory state of affairs which resulted in the travelling public of Victoria and those users of freight services suffering massive inconvenience over the last few months and it is an endeavour to avoid any further disruption that the Commission is taking the action it is today.
In other words, the Commission awarded the 4 per cent second tier increase purely to secure industrial peace, not in return for any productivity improvement.

Where was the 100 per cent cost offset in the building industry? It is well known that in the wages settlement in that industry the second tier deal that was struck did not comply with the national wage guidelines. We can only conclude that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and employers went along with it because of widespread threats of industrial action. This jack-booted approach has gained wage increases of 16 per cent, as the Secretary of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia is ever ready to boast. Employees gained four per cent from the first tier, four per cent from the second tier, three per cent through superannuation and five per cent in severance pay. Yet there is no evidence of productivity improvement in the building industry anywhere near matching this wage increase.

Where is the 100 per cent cost offset on the North West Shelf project? Unions there rejected an offer of a 16 per cent increase in remuneration and walked out on the most critically timed project in our history. They demanded increases which would have cost employers more than $1,000 per week for every employee-a total of $200m. The unions rejected the original offer of 16 per cent from employers because they had to work a full week to receive a $70 termination payment for each week employees had worked as part of the package. For every week they were on strike they needed to work almost nine weeks on the offered package before they caught up to their old package. Local industries shut their doors, laid off innocent and loyal workers and pleaded with banks not to close them down because of a dispute not of their making.

Local workers were not receiving anything like the Burrup conditions but were being forced to pay the price for the irresponsible and greedy attitudes of imported workers who treated this project like they have treated other major sites around Australia-drastically extending construction, dramatically increasing costs and leaving behind on completion a local industry component to carry the burden. The only winners in the dispute were the airlines and petrol stations on the way to Perth which catered for the exodus of over two-thirds of the imported work force on their way for a `break', and the Government, which will reap an additional $19m in increased fringe benefits, payroll and pay as you earn tax on the offered package. The Federal Government, which was quick to disparage employers in the Robe River dispute, has been strangely silent in condemning the union thuggery with regard to the North West Shelf dispute.

In light of these examples, the Government can only demonstrate that it is fair dinkum about restoring our international competitiveness by reversing its decision to proceed with the national wage case, or at least opposing an across the board 1.5 per cent increase. Unless this occurs, any export oriented or import competing business will have its competitive position further destroyed. The devaluation of our dollar has given us breathing space to get our wages structure in order. This benefit is being whittled away on two fronts: firstly, wage increases are not being matched by productivity improvement and, secondly, there have been further productivity increases in excess of our own in overseas countries.

The simple fact is that even if we do achieve what the Government, despite its stated intent, has not been able to achieve, that is, productivity improvement to match wage increases, we are only treading water. We are maintaining our present position which, in itself, is unsatisfactory. All it means is that we are not going further backwards. To achieve the necessary improvement in our position, so that we can achieve real economic growth, we need productivity improvement significantly greater than any wage increases. But, as the Budget Papers acknowledge and the Australian Bulletin of Labour, June 1987 edition, indicates:
Productivity performance has been extremely poor over the last year or two.

Granting short term real wage increases at inappropriate times, such as now, or maintaining real wage increases when they ought to be falling, ensures a poorer performance of the Australian economy, a lower rate of growth and, therefore, lower real wage growth over time. So, inappropriate wage increases, by lowering the real rate of growth in the economy, ensure that wages are lower than they could be in the long run, and so is the capacity of the economy to deal with the social evil of poverty. It also causes the waste of immense human resources through a high level of unemployment.

Employment growth in 1987 has diminished markedly compared with 1986 across all States and Territories. The drop in Australia's unemployment has bottomed out with the Budget predicting a slowing in employment growth and an unemployment rate little changed, on average, from the 8.3 per cent in 1986-87. But worse than that, the September 1987 issue of the Australian Bulletin of Labour differs from the predictions of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It says that the seasonally adjusted figures on unemployment highlight the extent of the continuing unemployment problem in most of the country and that, with the exception of Victoria and the Northern Territory, a steady growth in unemployment is readily apparent. This is borne out in other figures, such as the ratio of job vacancies to unemployment. This ratio has come down slightly compared with corresponding levels last year. This means that there are more unemployed people per job vacancy, that is, the overall labour market has slackened.

The teenage unemployment rate remains at a very high level. Teenagers, particularly early school leavers, are still being locked out of the labour market, in part because their relative wages are too high. Some freeing up of teenage wage rates was a necessary first step to ensure that teenagers had a range of job options before unemployment benefits for this group were abo-lished. As Senator Chaney has said in moving this motion, the Opposition is not urging a wages freeze, but we do oppose first tier, across the board wage increases. All increases should relate to second tier principles and be directly related to productivity improvement. A number of changes are necessary to achieve this: firstly, better direct communication between employers and employees at enterprise level. This has been achieved in a number of enterprises over the past decade. I cite Mitsubishi Motors in Adelaide as one example. But it must be extended. Better communication at the enterprise level will be helped by changing the union structure to an enterprise, rather than a craft, basis.

Secondly, we must facilitate easier employee share acquisition. Encouraging employees to acquire a direct financial interest in the prosperity of the business for which they work will achieve the three objectives of greater reward for effort, improved productivity and greater industrial harmony. Central to this is the abolition of existing tax penalties which act as a disincentive to greater employee share acquisition. Thirdly, we must encourage profit sharing as another way of giving employees a more direct personal interest in their company's success. By establishing a direct link between the remuneration of a company's employees and its profitability, profit sharing helps employees and employers to recognise that they have a shared interest in the prosperity of their company. Like employee share ownership, this will improve industrial relations, break down the `them and us' attitude and encourage employers and employees to work together to improve the productivity and efficiency of their enterprise.

Overseas experience strongly supports the introduction of these initiatives. A number of studies in the United States over the last decade have shown that companies with employee share ownership and profit sharing plans consistently outperform their competitors and generate higher profits and more new jobs.

Fourthly, we must abandon the mindless support for the concept of comparative wage justice, which, as I mentioned at the outset, was mainly responsible for the 1980-81 wages blow-out. This concept is pervasive in the Australian union movement. It is clearly contrary to the second tier concept where wage increases should be based on productivity improvement at the enterprise level. The phenomenon of the flow-on under comparative wage justice ensures that wage increases in a particular industry or enterprise are rapidly generalised to others, irrespective of their profitability or capacity to pay. Comparative wage justice also means, in general, that uniform wage rates apply across Australia to the detriment of the decentralisation of industry and to the detriment of the cost advantage earlier enjoyed by States like my own State of South Australia which allowed it to compete with the eastern States while having accompanying lower costs of living and thereby enjoying a comparable standard of living. Comparative wage justice also squeezes relativities, minimising rewards for skill or labour scarcity.

I support Senator Chaney's motion because it reinforces the need for wage increases to be granted only on the basis that I have outlined in the latter part of my remarks. Wage increases should only be granted directly on the basis of productivity improvement. That is the import of Senator Chaney's motion which I strongly support and bring to the Senate's attention. It reads:
That the Senate-

(a) records its agreement with the view expressed on behalf of the Government by the Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon. Ralph Willis, MP, that `it is quite fundamental to our prospects of economic recovery that we keep increases in our labour costs broadly in line with those of our international trading competitors. Not to do so would jettison the great opportunities provided by the very large devaluation of the Australian dollar and place us in dire economic peril';
(b) notes that increases in our labour costs will, on the Government's own predictions, be substantially in excess of those of our trading competitors; and

(c) expresses its disappointment at the Government's failure to understand that the decision to proceed with the national wage case on 28 October 1987 will contribute to the worsening of the problem the Minister has identified.

It is essential that across the board wage increases, which will result from a continuation of the national wage case, be abandoned and that all wage increases in future be on the basis of productivity so that we can obtain real growth in this nation for the benefit of all of us and thereby improve our competitive position and our trading position with other countries.
