The speech read as follows-

The Bill before the Senate makes a number of important changes to procedures associated with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. These have been announced previously either as part of the 1987-88 Budget package or decisions taken as a result of the efficiency scrutiny into the payment of pharmaceutical benefits conducted earlier in 1987.

Honourable senators are well aware of this Government's scrutiny of all areas of expenditure and in regard to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in particular, the measures implemented last year to better target assistance on those in greatest need especially families who require large numbers of drugs.
The changes incorporated in this Bill, although less significant than the changes made last year, maintain this momentum in achieving value for the taxpayers' dollar and improving efficiency.

Amendments included in this Bill will make significant changes to the operation and activities of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). The role of this Committee is to advise the Minister on the listing of drugs and medicinal preparations as pharmaceutical benefits.

The Government is concerned about the increasing cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme over the last two years, much of which has been caused by greater prescribing of expensive drugs. For example in 1986-87 the average price of drugs supplied to pensioners under the scheme was $8, some 24 per cent higher than the previous year. As mentioned in the Budget Papers, the major changes implemented in November 1986 are expected to save about $100m in 1987-88. If these changes had not been introduced expenditure on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme would have reached an estimated $970m in 1987-88, an increase of 58 per cent in the two years since 1985-86.

This Bill includes amendments that will require the PBAC to take account of comparative effectiveness and cost in recommending drugs as pharmaceutical benefits and in considering any change to prescribing restrictions applying to pharmaceutical benefits.

In the past the PBAC has not been required by its statutory charter to take costs into account when making its recommendations. In practice it has taken price into account when considering drugs of similar efficacy and toxicity, but only as a secondary consideration.

The obligation to consider comparative effectiveness and cost will require the PBAC to give consideration to alternative forms of treatment, for example surgery, in making recommendations. The Committee will not be allowed to recommend the listing of a particular drug which is substantially more costly, unless it is satisfied that, at least for some patients, the drug provides significant therapeutic advantages over alternative therapy.

The Government has no objection to paying high prices for new drugs that offer significant therapeutic advances over existing drugs or other forms of treatment. But it does not believe the taxpayer should foot the bill for very expensive drugs that offer only minimal advantages over much cheaper alternatives.

To assist the Committee to take account of these wider considerations, the Government intends to significantly upgrade secretariat support for the PBAC, with greater utilisation of specialist consultants to advise on selected areas of drug therapy.

Together with the upgrading of the PBAC secretariat, the Minister will be empowered to increase membership of the Committee by up to three; all of the additional members must be medical practitioners.

This enlarged membership, additional secretariat support and greater resources to engage consultants complement the provisions in the Bill for the PBAC to appoint sub-committees to provide the best available advice in this technical area.

In addition this Bill deals with the Minister's power to remove an item from the list of pharmaceutical benefits. The proposed amendment will enable the Minister to act quickly when circumstances change, for example where a cheaper alternative drug becomes available. When taking action under the proposed amendment the Minister will be required to have regard to previous views expressed by the PBAC.
Clause 4 of the Bill requires that the declaration removing an item from the list of pharmaceutical benefits under these circumstances be tabled in the Parliament and be subject to disallowance.

I turn now to two other provisions of the Bill, which arose out of the efficiency scrutiny of the payment of pharmaceutical benefits. Honourable senators will be aware of delays which have occurred in the past in paying pharmacists for pharmaceutical benefits they had supplied.

A major initiative to prevent delays in paying pharmacists claims and reduce processing costs has been to encourage pharmacists with compatible computers to submit claims on floppy disks or via modem to the central claims processing facility. This method of submitting claims has a number of advantages which include more rapid and accurate processing. The Bill provides for a cash incentive of 2.5c per pharmaceutical benefit to be paid to pharmacists and other approved suppliers who utilise this claims transmission system. The incentive payment may be paid for a period of two years to each supplier using this system. The rules governing the payment of the incentive will be made by the Minister, published in the Gazette and laid before each House of Parliament for its scrutiny.

The provisions in the Bill will formalise interim arrangements under which the incentive has been paid to eligible pharmacists since 1 July 1987. Earlier this year the Government announced that the incentive would be paid to all pharmacists, and other approved suppliers, who are ready to submit computer-readable claims by 1 November this year. Already the proportion of pharmacists participating in the claims transmission system has jumped from 11 per cent in February to more than 37 per cent at the end of September.

A further initiative to prevent delay in reimbursing pharmacists is provided for in clauses 5, 6 and 7 of this Bill. This is the establishment of an alternative payment system whereby the reimbursement to pharmacists is calculated based on processing a random sample of prescriptions submitted in each claim. The proposed arrangement provides pharmacists with greater flexibi-lity in the ways they can receive reimbursement and will also assist the department in handling peak work loads which occur from time to time.

Pharmacists will be able to participate in this arrangement by voluntary election. The Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Department of Finance have been involved in the development of the sampling arrangements. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia has been consulted and has given its approval in principle to the sampling arrangements. Further consultations will take place on the detailed rules which will govern this alternative payment method. The Bill provides that a copy of the rules be published in the Gazette, as well as being tabled in each House of the Parliament.

It is expected that the rules will preclude from these arrangements very small pharmacies and those with computers capable of submitting data under the claims transmission system. The rules will specify how samples will be selected and how sample sizes will be determined for each pharmacy.

To minimise the sampling variation in payments and take account of high priced items, the rules will allow pharmacists to submit up to 10 per cent of items in a claim for full processing, with the remainder to be reimbursed by the sampling method.

In order to encourage pharmacists to choose this method of processing, the rules will provide that sample claims will receive both priority in processing and an incentive payment of 2.5c for each pharmaceutical bene-fit covered by the claim.
Clause 7 of the Bill will extend the Commonwealth's recovery power to any overpayments made under the sampling method.
Together with the other provisions in this Bill the sample processing arrangements are expected to contri-bute significantly to the efficiency of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

While it is impossible to be precise about the expen-diture savings flowing from the changes in PBAC procedures, these have been estimated at $5m in this financial year. These will be offset by the additional expenditure of $0.5m for additional staffing and consultancies.

The operational savings from the claims transmission incentive and sample processing will depend on the number of approved suppliers participating. If 50 per cent of approved suppliers participate in the claims transmission system and a further 25 per cent elect to have their claims processed by the alternative payment method, the gross operational savings are estimated at $7m and $3.5m respectively in a full year. Offsetting these savings would be the incentive payments themselves, amounting to $1.25m and $0.6m per annum respectively.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was explaining that, when the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) introduced the original Medicare legislation, he told everyone that we would have the best and the cheapest health and hospital care. I had been through health care and I had explained what second rate medicine we are now offering Australian citizens and what third and fourth rate hospital care we are now offering the people of Australia. I talked about the waiting lists and explained how they had all grown since the introduction of Medicare and how 64.4 per cent of Australian families with children had been forced to cover themselves with private insurance to enable them to get a bed. I said that, apart from that, there was a very poor group and that the Australian Bureau of Statistics had produced a survey which indicated that 46 per cent of married couples with children on $126 a week were now forced to cover themselves with private hospital insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the Government did not like these figures so it took action to try to force those people who were privately insuring back on to the hospital queues. The Government did that by stating in its 1986 Budget that the private hospital bed subsidy was abolished. It took away the subsidy for the private hospitals and so forced hospital insurance contribution rates to rise. In the May mini-statement the rebate for private in-patients for hospital services was lowered from 85 per cent to 75 per cent and the maximum gap of $20 was removed. The Government, in doing both those things in 1986 and 1987, attempted to force these people who were struggling to maintain private insurance back on to the already bloated hospital queues resulting in increases in private insurance, as I have already said. It is really a disgrace. It is patent rubbish and nothing more.

At the time of the introduction of Medicare we warned that the entrepreneurial exercises of the Edelstens of this world would pull the whole system down, make it impractical and unworkable and send everyone bankrupt. I repeat that I found it very interesting that Mr Hawke's letter, from which I quoted earlier, also stated that two out of three families would be paying less for Medicare. This statement very quickly followed the statement of the Minister, Dr Blewett, who said that nine out of 10 people in Australia would be paying less. The additional information that Mr Hawke gave was that the system would lower our inflation rate by reducing the cost of living. At that stage inflation was running at 8.6 per cent. Once the Government removed the health insurance cost from the pockets of the people and put it into tax, where it is not taken into account by inflation, the inflation rate dropped to 5.9 per cent. But then it promptly grew again and by December 1986 it was 9.8 per cent. So we have a 2.7 per cent reduction in the inflation rate by just taking money out of people's pockets and putting it into the insurance funds and saying, `You do not pay the insurance company; you now pay Medicare through tax'. People are still paying for Medicare. If we add that 2.7 per cent reduced inflation rate to the 9.8 per cent, which is what it was in December 1986, we find that it is 12.5 per cent. The statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the new health care system would lower the inflation rate is nothing but a load of rubbish.

I have said that I believe the Government's system is in tatters and that it is sending the country broke. This is not just my opinion; it is the opinion of many people around Australia. Let me just quote from Professor Penington as the Government considered it was worth while to ask him to advise it on such health matters. He said:
The cost of the present system is out of control.
That was Professor David Penington. He also said:
I personally feel an enormous concern about the present state of the public sector health institutions. I feel they are facing a very critical period for their future as to whether they will survive.
He also said:

It has been a tribute to the ethical standards of the medical profession that growth in the utilisation and cost has not been far greater than it has been in the past ten years. The growing waiting lists at public hospitals and the increased numbers of services provided under Medicare with the rapid growth in areas such as private pathology, now well ahead of the Budget estimates, mean a rethink of medical policy was overdue.

Warnings have been given to the Government on many occasions. The Government pushes ahead with its policy through ideology alone, nothing else. If we look at the December 1986 consumer price index figures, we find that, while the inflation rate was running at 9.8 per cent, the cost of health services was running at 26.2 per cent. Similarly this year, while inflation is running at 8.3 per cent on the most recent figures, the cost of health services is running at 20.9 per cent. The whole thing is sending us broke and it is time that the Minister abided by all the advice that he has been given by both the Opposition and Professor Penington who have advised the Government to abolish bulk billing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Notice of intention to move a number of amendments at the committee stage has been given. I do not propose to deal with those matters now, but rather will leave that to the committee stage. I shall not, therefore, at this stage reply to any of the matters that were raised in the second reading debate. However, a couple of people mentioned Medicare, so I will give a few facts. I know that it is always awkward when facts collide with ideological prejudice, but this is a very important issue and a few facts should be put on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Total spending on health as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) in Australia has declined in recent years, albeit marginally. It currently stands at around 7 1/2 per cent of GDP, which is somewhat higher than in the United Kingdom where it is just under 7 per cent of GDP and somewhat lower than in Canada where it is just over 8 per cent of GDP. In the United States of America, which is the purest example of the sort of health system the Opposition would like to see Australia have, total health expenditure as a proportion of GDP is 11 per cent. If we were to spend 11 per cent of GDP on health care, that would entail expenditure of almost an additional $10 billion, for an outcome which would be certainly no better. Few people would argue that the health service delivery in the United States is any better than it is in Australia. There are pretty fundamental economic reasons why that sort of outcome has been produced.

If one were to look to maximise costs on health expenditure, it would be difficult to devise a more effective formula for doing that than to abandon any attempt at controlling charges while simultaneously allowing unlimited private insurance-that is, private insurance for unlimited amounts and at an unlimited charge for specific services-and simultaneously on the Budget to pick up the cost of providing medical services to the aged, the infirm and a few other groups. That is the formula which the Opposition would foist upon the country. It is a formula which would maximise costs. It is true that to a significant extent it would transfer what is presently public expenditure, and therefore on the Budget, to private expenditure, which would lead to a major increase in total spending on health, with no better outcome.

What the Opposition, because of its ideological bigotry, fails to recognise is that the market system does not work in the provision of health care unless one is willing to ban private insurance. Once private insurance is in place, it is a matter of no consequence to the individual how many services the individual either demands spontaneously or demands following prompting by a member of the profession. If that private insurance co-exists with a system which does not attempt to impose any control on service delivery, including a charge for services, one has a formula for maximising costs. If anybody wants the market system to operate effectively in the area of health service delivery, the formula for doing it is fairly clear, and this may well reduce total costs: One must outlaw private insurance and then go all the way down the social Darwinist road; that is, establish a policy and practice under which people who cannot afford to pay directly from their own pockets for medical services either remain sick or die. Nobody is suggesting that we do that. But the Opposition, following its practices of many years, refuses to acknowledge what anyone moderately well informed about market theories should know, which is that the market system will not work in conjunction with a system of insurance. The whole set of assumptions upon which the operation of a market is based fall to the ground. I do not propose to delay the second readings of the Bills any longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the adjournment tonight I want to raise the two-faced attitude of this Government to sexism. It is an old adage that, if you protest too much, there must be something behind it. Senator Ryan, on behalf of the Government, certainly does protest high and low against sexism around the country-and so she should. But what I want to raise on the adjournment is whether she does so with the vehemence with which she does it because she is aware that senior Ministers in her Government do not believe and/or practice what she preaches. Apparently, we had yet another example today of a senior Minister in the Government behaving in a very sexist fashion.
—Who did?
—A senior Minister of a government that professes to be anti-sexist.
—Who did?

—If Senator Walsh will just wait for a minute, I will get to the point. When it comes to sexist Ministers, this Government got a very generous slice of the cake. Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Home Affairs, answered a serious question from Senator Haines. He then sat down, and on the way down he added something to his answer. Perhaps it was not audible to everyone in the chamber, but I know it was audible to some, and certainly audible to some in the Press gallery. Irrespective of whether it was audible in the chamber, it was audible to the media and to those in offices who listened to tapes of the broadcast. What Senator Ray said as he sat down-and it is as clear as a bell on the tapes-is `bitch'. It is not a term that I would normally use in this chamber; henceforth I will say that he followed up his answer with a word that rhymes with witch, but begins with `b'. Having said it once, that is probably enough. We all know that that terminology is sexist. We all know it is a derogatory term to use when describing a woman. In case some honourable senators did not know that, I refer them, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to the following definition of `bitch' in one dictionary. It says it is a derogatory term of a woman, especially a lewd or malicious or treacherous one. That is, I would have thought, hardly an appropriate description for a Minister in this Government to apply not only to another member of this chamber, but to a female member of this chamber and, added to that, a female member of this chamber who happens to be the leader of a party.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not the first time that this Government, through its Ministers, has shown that it is not prepared to practise what it preaches in this respect. I turn my mind back to, I think, February of this year when Senator Evans, in a discussion on the placing of Government Business, without much provocation made the following comment:
Perhaps I should say that I so move on the principle that if rape is inevitable one might as well, if not enjoy it, at least succumb with such grace as one can muster in the circumstances.

The reference, of course, is to a throw-away line which I employed in the course of the debate on the placing of business . . .

I would have thought that Senator Ryan, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, would not have approved of that sort of terminology, whether it was a throw-away line or used as a matter of substance. Senator Ryan commented, `I think some in the Senate could be offended by it'. She was, of course, right as there were a significant number of people in the Senate who were offended by it, and the people who read about it in the media, following the coverage of his comments, were equally offended. Senator Evans said to the chamber that it would be perfectly apparent from what he had said that he was not repeating the standard chauvinist cliche. I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that one cannot slip in sexist remarks and then put up one's hands and say, `I did not mean it; I was distancing myself from the use of that sort of terminology'. One either avoids that sort of terminology or one does not. Senator Evans was simply unable to help himself in this respect.

In my view he compounded the problem and showed the views that he really holds because following an interjection of mine, when he was attempting to clarify his remarks, he responded that amongst the things that frightened him was Senator Vanstone, in addition to the other women on the back bench of the Opposition. This was clearly a sexist stereotyping of a group of women as a pack, and the negative connotations that go with that. I do not need to go on about that experience. It got a lot of unfortunate coverage.

I raise another purported example of sexism demonstrated by Government Ministers and, might I say, senior Government Ministers. The Times on Sunday of 8 March this year carried a report entitled `All's not WEL with Walsh'. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) was in the chamber some time ago, and perhaps he would like to come back and comment on this. In the course of the discussion the famous Budget-slasher-
that is Senator Walsh-

I have given honourable senators three examples of where I believe Ministers of this Government have, by the remarks they have chosen to make, flippantly or otherwise, demonstrated that they do not believe all their Government preaches. I give a further example, one that pertains not to any particular Minister, but to the material put out by this Government. Secondly, although one could not say that one objects to this practice, all honourable senators from now on must be very careful-leaving aside the efficacy of the Standing Orders, because this place has to run on common sense-if they give notice of a question, particularly a long one, not to change one or two words of it when reading it out and expect the Minister to be able to respond. All such questions will be put on notice, because if I had read out the answer to Senator Haines's original question or had not been concentrating, I would have misled this chamber and would have had to come in and apologise for it. I think the key word in Senator Haines's original question was the word `without'. She altered the question to say `with or without permission' and changed the whole nature of the question.

So I think Senator Vanstone-I see her acknowledging this-could at least understand that I was angry. There is no excuse, in a moment of anger, for reacting in a sexist way. I acknow-ledge that. If I have done that, I withdraw what I said. But I am not certain in my own mind whether my remark-which was inaudible not only to the chamber and the Hansard reporters but also to the tape recorder-was directed at Senator Haines or at the nature of the question. It is less than five years since Mr Fraser yielded the Prime Ministership and even today we are very close to the events in which he was involved. The biography attempts to cover some of those events. I have had the pleasure of reading the biography. Malcolm Fraser was the Prime Minister under whom I served as a Minister in his Government and his last Cabinet. I have even written a review of the biography. Whether or not it is published is another matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The biography recounts many of the achievements of Malcolm Fraser, Prime Minister, but as honourable senators will have noticed in the newspapers, it has given rise to some controversy already. Some people have drawn upon a single half page in a book of well over 400 pages where Mr Fraser's relations with Mr Howard are mentioned, and on another part of the book which deals with some conversations he had with Sir John Kerr in 1975. As I said, the book outlines many of the achievements of Malcolm Fraser as Prime Minister. I do not think it does him justice in terms of some of the recent things he has done. I have come here tonight to tell the Senate that earlier this year, on 30 July, Malcolm Fraser delivered the Daniel Mannix memorial lecture in Melbourne. It was a splendid lecture. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In tonight's adjournment debate I would like to speak on the world economic crisis facing us. I want to refer particularly to the American President, because I believe that President Reagan, as a Republican President, has been guilty of the most irresponsible behaviour during his presidency. I will develop that theme. I noticed yesterday an article in the Australian Financial Review by Paddy McGuinness headed `Action must be directed at world system'. I think he summed up the position when he said, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a single major culprit. It is the United States. It is the US which has insisted on running a Budget deficit of immense and uncontrollable proportions, and which has failed to face up to the issue of either raising taxes or reducing expenditure to bring down the deficit.

When one considers Mr Reagan's presidency one sees that he has allowed $1.8 trillion to be committed to an escalating arms budget between 1984 and 1988. This figure is based on the Department of Defense estimates and does not include expenditure on military related items in other departments. The escalating development of the military-industrial complex is a matter of great concern. Ultimately, there is a great deal of waste in those resources, whether they are used or not. Unfortunately, the Star Wars development is just the most recent escalation of that arms race in the threat to take war into outer space.

I believe that these excessive defence expenditures-which are like a bottomless pit of waste, whether the weapons are used or not-account for 28 per cent of the current United States Budget, which is, of course, a 5 per cent increase during the period of Mr Reagan's presidency. The outcome of the Reagan Administration's strategy will be to put the cost on future generations by borrowing from tomorrow rather than facing up to taxing today. This strategy of increasing armament expenditure on the never-never payment principle must be acknowledged as a major cause of the crisis the world faces today.

The raft of debt on which the American economy now floats is truly staggering. The result is a debilitating deficit which is a prime cause of the current crisis. I am not suggesting that that is the only activity that has occurred. The Vietnam War was financed in an inflationary way. There have been other factors, such as the two oil crises. The 1982 recession was, in part, alleviated by an increase in defence expenditure, but that was at the expense of higher interest rates which have had a devastating effect on Third World countries and left the Third World with a crippling debt. We might well ask: What is the result of the seven-year Reagan presidency? Today the United States is no longer an independent nation. For the first time in its history it now depends on foreign capital to finance the day to day activities of government.

The United States national debt has doubled over the last five years. Interest on the debt alone will be in the vicinity of $125 billion. The United States trade deficit reached $220 billion last year; that is, 1985-86. It was $75 billion for the first six months of the 1986-87 financial year and is estimated to be $155 billion this year. The current United States Budget deficit is $148 billion. President Reagan has belatedly announced that he will discuss with Congress possible steps to reduce this deficit. However, until last week President Reagan had refused to consider an increased tax on wealthy people and reduced defence spending.

Felix Rohatyn, Chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York, wrote in the New York Review of Books on 11 June this year an article entitled `On the Brink' in which he successfully predicted the crisis that has occurred in the stock market over the last couple of weeks. He pointed out:
Even if the US was able to reduce its trade deficit by 20 billion dollars a year, by 1995 the external debt would be about 1.5 trillion.

That is United States dollars. The interest alone on that debt would be in the vicinity of $US120 billion a year. Another aspect of this problem is that in order to service the debt the United States domestic market is absorbing an ever increasing amount of foreign goods. The political reaction to this problem has been to attempt to erect prohibitive trade barriers that, of course, will adversely affect Australian exports.

The fact that the crisis has been deeper in the United States and the United Kingdom requires us to look at the reality of what has occurred under these New Right governments-the regimes where New Right leaders have presided. The time has come for us to examine the experience of the New Right. Untrammelled market forces have resulted in an unparalleled growth of corporate debt, in many cases fuelled by unbridled takeover activity. To the end of last year the total long term and short term debt of non-financial institutions in the United States was about $1.6 trillion. I again quote Felix Rohatyn:
There is no precedent or analogy for the worldwide financial structure that has been created in recent years.

One and a half trillion dollars per day flows through New York's clearing house interbank payment systems (CHIPS), which processes all the domestic and foreign payments passing through New York banks.
This amounts to one third of (the United States) annual gross national product.

Incidentally, it is worth noting that the London Eurodollar market now turns over $300 billion every working day or $75 trillion a year-that is, a volume at least 25 times greater than the level of world trade. As Felix Rohatyn has said:
The relationships between exchange rates and trade, between interest rates and economic activities, between fiscal and monetary, have become less and less predictable.
The famous Peter Drucker, an expert on corporate affairs, confirmed this point recently in the Los Angeles Times when he described Wall Street brokers in the following way:
A totally non-productive crowd which just is out for a lot of easy money. When you reach the point where traders make more money than investors, you know it's not going to last.

With short term profits the only aim, the daily business news, particularly in the United States, was of speculative real estate deals, assets stripping, hostile takeovers, strategic bankruptcy and risk arbitrage. Huge fortunes were made in days with not a single productive result. Last week the rug of New Right attitudes was pulled away to reveal a very bleak future for the world and a real danger of millions of ordinary people suffering because of the greed of the free marketeers. In the last few years we have seen the United States turn from being the world's biggest creditor nation to being the world's biggest debtor.

The counterpart to this is the growing trade surpluses of Japan and Germany. Neither the United States deficit nor the surpluses of Japan and Germany are sustainable. But, in the absence of orderly sensible policies to deal with this problem, the world is likely to be engulfed in trade wars, slow or negative economic growth and, consequently, reduced living standards. There is a growing global imbalance between the industrialised countries and the less developed countries because of the international debt problem. The adoption of monetarist policies by many countries, accompanied by high interest rates and depressed commodity prices, has resulted in an absurd situation. It is a situation in which despite substantial debt rescheduling, there has actually been a net transfer of resources from poor countries to rich countries. The total outstanding debt of developing countries is estimated at nearly $1 trillion. Debt repayment obligations in some countries exceed total visible export earnings.

No government or banker should regard the present situation as sustainable. However, it is not so much the size of the debt that counts; rather the increased amount of export earnings required to service it. Debt repayment for many Third World countries now amounts to half, two-thirds or, in some cases, more than all exports. As an ever increasing number of debts are tied to United States interest rates, export servicing costs rise every time United States interest rates rise. Already the world stock of debt is larger that the world domestic product.

It has also been estimated that world annual interest payments are larger than the increase in world income. Under these conditions it is inevitable that a growing proportion of income will be absorbed by interest payments. This is not only unsustainable but also imposes deflation on the world economy by pre-empting resources which otherwise could finance increased imports for other countries' exports. This is how the problems of the Third World debt threaten all the world, particularly Australia because of our commodity exports. It is therefore obscene to concentrate media attention and analysis on millionaires and yuppies-the superficial analysis that has been characteristic of our Press-and not look at the hunger, degradation and even death facing millions of people throughout the world because of the failed New Right policies which are based simply on greed and which are unsustainable. Socialist International, the organisation of Labor, Socialist and Social Democratic Parties, in a book entitled Global Challenge, which is a prescription by an economic committee of Socialist International, has proposed alternatives which I am sure many thinking people will now look at to see how the industrialised north and the less developed south should co-operate. Because I have stretched the indulgence of the Senate, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard proposals numbered 3, 5 and 18 contained in the recommendations of Global Challenge.
Leave granted.
The proposals read as follows-

3 Institutional reform should not delay policy changes in the existing agencies. The shocks suffered by the world trading system in the early 1980s, clearly illustrated the need for major changes. An international trade system, serving both North and South should:
Be non-discriminatory between northern countries.
Be dynamic, allowing Third World countries to participate in the gains from trade.
Allow southern countries to adopt interim measures for planned trade, to develop their own industrial base and to pursue policies for social accumulation and basic needs.
Provide security of access to northern markets.
Include safeguard arrangements for effective appeal against abuse of planned or managed trade.
Foster structural adjustment through mutually reinforcing programmes for recovery of spending, trade and payments.
Meet the needs of weaker trading partners, through long-term credits to support their development deficits.
Meet the needs not only of trade in manufactures, but also of trade in agricultural products and services, through price stabilization agreements.
Provide an adequate framework in both accounting for and accountability of transnational companies, including joint development agreements.
Be multilateral, while admitting the role of regional trading areas or common markets in both northern and southern countries.

5 It must be acknowledged that the United States-and several other members of the Group of Ten-have deliberately blocked progress in the multilateral system, on development issues, on trading reform, and on new programmes, agencies and initiatives. The US has not only threatened to withdraw from other agencies following its abandonment of its commitments to UNESCO, but has refused to negotiate on a range of issues in the international community. We welcome a dialogue with those in the United States who are attempting to pose realistic international policy alternatives for a new administration.

18 We propose a commitment to an additional spending of $100 billion a year to make possible a new decade of recovery and development. This is ten per cent of current global arms spending. We are not suggesting a naive formula by which the world would decrease its arms spending each year by a tenth in favour of spending for development. But we do advocate that the target for a global budget to recover income and trade, and restructure and redistribute resources, should, over ten years, be at least equivalent to current global arms spending. We should be spending a trillion dollars a year more than now on additional resources to sustain global development and transform the current global crisis.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening in the adjournment debate we heard from Senator Vanstone, Senator Peter Baume and Senator Childs. I must say that I was very disappointed, to put it mildly, with the comments of Senator Vanstone. However, I can understand her frustration in working from her shadow portfolio, given the record of her Party in relation to the status of women issues. I understand that because of that frustration she is ever seeking to draw attention to some issue that she thinks may put herself or her Party in a more favourable light. I think the manner in which she chose to do it this evening was totally inappropriate, and I think Senator Ray more than ably covered the attack on him. If indeed as Senator Vanstone suggests the three Ministers she mentioned were guilty of sexism, I am not quite sure why two of them over four years have consistently supported the Government in its efforts to recognise the important role of women in Australia and why they have both participated in developing women's policy both within Cabinet and within their own portfolios.
—Who's the odd one out?

—Senator Ray, of course, has just become a Minister and I know that he has also taken on that commitment within his Department because, as Senator Vanstone well knows, this Government has a strong record in relation to women's policy. It is quite ludicrous to accuse Ministers of not supporting women's policy when in the Budget document that has been produced one can look closely at the initiatives in every single portfolio-one can look at Senator Ray's portfolio, Senator Walsh's portfolio and Senator Evans's portfolio. I sympathise with Senator Vanstone because I can understand her frustration. There are many people within the Liberal Party and many women members of the Liberal Party who share her frustration. Dame Beryl Beaurepaire, who was mentioned in Question Time today, I am sure shares many of Senator Vanstone's frustrations. I do not think that it is fit and proper for Senator Vanstone to misrepresent Ministers in this place just because she happens to be frustrated about her party's current stance in relation to women's policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to Senator Peter Baume's contribution. Senator Peter Baume tabled the Daniel Mannix memorial lecture, `Robert Menzies: In search of Balance'. I am sure that honourable senators will welcome this addition in Hansard and will look forward to reading it. Senator Childs made an important contribution and I will not attempt to summarise the important issues that he raised. One point that I noted that I think would have a great deal of support within the community was his highlighting that it was the greed of many of the free marketeers that is now having such a devastating impact on the world economy. He also talked about the escalation of the arms budget of the United States of America under the Reagan Administration, he highlighted the excessive budgeting of the United States in regard to Star Wars and he said that ordinary Americans were suffering as a result. Of course, the cost of maintaining the arms race is at the expense of a more stable economy. Senator Childs also commented on the impact of the New Right and the tremendous growth in the corporate sector debt which I know in current economic circumstances is of great concern to all of us.
